Kane Bidco Limited, a private limited company incorporated under the laws of Jersey (the “Issuer”), is offering £ ––––– million in aggregate
principal amount of its GBP-denominated –––––% Senior Secured Notes due 2027 (the “GBP Notes”) and € **––––– million in aggregate principal**
amount of its EUR-denominated –––––% Senior Secured Notes due 2027 (the “EUR Notes” and, together with the GBP Notes, the “Notes”). The
offering of the Notes (the “Offering”) is being made to provide permanent financing for the Issuer’s indirect acquisition (the “Acquisition”) of the
entire share capital of True Potential Group Limited, a private limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales (the “Target”).
The proceeds from the Offering, together with cash on the Issuer’s balance sheet, will be used to repay and cancel the Bridge Facility (as defined
herein) (the “Refinancing”) and pay fees and expenses in connection with the Offering and the Refinancing. The amounts drawn under the Bridge
Facility were used, together with shareholder contributions, to (i) pay the Purchase Price (as defined herein) for the Acquisition, (ii) repay in full
and cancel the existing indebtedness of the Target, (iii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Acquisition, the repayment and cancellation
of the existing indebtedness of the Target and the entry into the Bridge Facility Agreement (as defined herein) and the Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement (as defined herein) and (iv) provide funds for the Issuer’s balance sheet.

The Notes will mature on –––––2027. Interest will be paid on the Notes semi-annually in arrear on –––––and –––––of each year, beginning
on –––––2022. The Issuer may redeem one or both series of the Notes in whole or in part at any time on or after –––––2024 at the redemption
prices specified herein. Prior to –––––2024, the Issuer may redeem all or, from time to time, a part of either the GBP Notes or the EUR Notes at
a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, in respect of
such redeemed Notes, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium as described herein. Prior to –––––2024, the Issuer may redeem up to 40%
of the aggregate principal amount of either the GBP Notes or the EUR Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, with
the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at the redemption price set out in this offering memorandum (the “Offering Memorandum”). Prior
to –––––2024, the Issuer may also redeem, during each twelve-month period commencing with the Issue Date, up to 10% of the aggregate
principal amount of either the GBP Notes or the EUR Notes outstanding (including Additional GBP Notes (as defined herein) or Additional EUR
Notes, (as defined herein) if any), at its option, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the GBP Notes or the EUR Notes
redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any.

The Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax law. Upon the occurrence
of certain specified change of control events, the Issuer will be required to offer to repurchase the applicable Notes at 101% of the principal amount
thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any.

The Notes will be the general senior obligations of the Issuer, will rank pari passu in right of payment with all existing and future indebtedness of
the Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes (including the obligations of the Issuer under the Revolving Credit
Facility (as defined herein) and certain Hedging Obligations (as defined herein), if any), will rank senior in right of payment to any existing and
future indebtedness of the Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes and will be effectively subordinated to any existing
and future indebtedness of the Issuer and its subsidiaries that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the
value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness.

The Notes will not be guaranteed by any subsidiaries of the Issuer (including the Target and its subsidiaries following the Acquisition). On the Issue
Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein), the Notes will be secured by limited recourse third-party security over the shares
in the Issuer held by Kane Midco Limited (the “Parent”) and any structural intercompany receivables owed to the Parent by the Issuer (the “Issue
**Date Collateral”). In addition, within 30 days following the Completion Date, the Notes will also be secured by the Issuer’s material bank accounts,**
its shares in the Target and any structural intercompany receivables owed to the Issuer by the Target (the “Post-Completion Date Collateral” and,
together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”). The property and assets that will secure the Notes will also secure the Revolving Credit
Facility and certain priority hedging obligations (the “Super Senior Obligations”) on a first-ranking basis. Pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor
Agreement (as defined herein), in the event of a distressed disposal of the Collateral or an enforcement of the security interests over the Collateral,
the Super Senior Obligations and certain other indebtedness permitted under the Indenture (as defined herein) to be incurred on a priority basis
will be repaid with the proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral in priority to the Notes. The validity and enforceability of the security interests
will be subject to the limitations described in “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of Security and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations”. The
Collateral may be released in certain circumstances.

There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”)
for the listing of, and permission to deal in, the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”) in Guernsey, the
Channel Islands. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the
Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The Exchange is not a regulated exchange for the purposes MiFID II or MiFIR.

**Restatement of 2020 Financial Information**

In connection with the preparation of the Interim Financial Statements, we restated certain profit and
loss and balance sheet information as at and for the year ended 31 December 2020. Unless otherwise
indicated, such financial information as at and for the year ended 31 December 2020 presented in this
Offering Memorandum is the restated information as it is presented in the Interim Financial Statements.

Administrative expenses for the year ended 31 December 2020 have been restated from £42.5 million
to £39.9 million. In October 2019, the Target Group undertook a share buy back from FTV – True, LLC
and re-financed the Target Group’s financing facilities, in the process legal and arrangement fees were
incurred which were incorrectly capitalised as “other intangibles”. During the period the directors of the
Target have reassessed the nature and treatment of these costs and have reclassified them from “other
intangibles” to “borrowings”, reducing creditors: amounts falling due in more than one year. The
related amortisation has been reclassified from “administrative expenses” to “interest”. The
comparative financial information has been restated to effect this change with £19.5 million being
reclassified from “other intangibles” to “borrowings” and £2.3 million from “administrative expenses”
to “interest” at 31 December 2020. There has been no impact on reported profit or net assets as a
result of this reclassification.

Operating profit before goodwill amortisation for the year ended 31 December 2020 has been restated
from £66.0 million to £68.6 million.

Operating profit for the year ended 31 December 2020 has been restated from £50.6 million to
£53.1 million.

Interest payable and similar charges for the year ended 31 December 2020 has been restated from
£31.1 million to £33.6 million.

Tax on profit for the year ended 31 December 2020 has been restated from a credit amounted to
£6.3 million to a tax amounted to £7.3 million. The adjustment is relating to a reduction in the deferred
tax charge in 2019 by £13.6 million offset by an equal and opposite increase in the deferred tax charge
in 2020, which is with respect to a deferred tax charge that was recognised in 2019 and reversed in
2020. The reversal in 2020 was incorrectly treated as an in-period adjustment rather than a prior year
adjustment. There is no impact on the closing deferred tax liability as at 31 December 2020.

Profit for the period for the year ended 31 December 2020 has been restated from £25.8 million to
£12.2 million.

**Non-GAAP Measures**

In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain financial measures, referred to as “Non-GAAP
**Measures”, that are not recognised by UK GAAP and that may not be permitted to appear on the face**
of the Financial Statements or footnotes thereto.

Non-GAAP Measures used in this Offering Memorandum are AUA, AUM, CAT-Managed Assets,
Run-Rate Adjustments, Gross Asset Inflows, Integrated Flows, Client AUA Churn, Net Revenue, Net
Revenue Margin, Recurring Net Revenue, Adjusted Net Revenue, EBITDA, EBITDA Margin, Operating
Cash Flow before Taxes, Cash Flow Conversion and Free Cash Flow. For additional information on the


-----

calculation of these metrics, see below and refer to “Summary Historical Financial and Other
_Information—Other Financial and Operating Information—Other Financial and Operating Information”._

- “AUA” refers to our assets under administration, representing the total market value of all financial
assets invested on the True Potential platform as at a certain date.

- “AUM” refers to our assets under management, representing the total market value of all financial
assets invested in TPI Funds (as defined in this Offering Memorandum) as at a certain date.

- “CAT-Managed Assets” represents AUM on which the Central Advice Team (as defined in this
Offering Memorandum) advises as at a certain date.

- “Run-Rate Adjustments” represents the difference between the annualised platform fees, fund
fees and advice fees that would have been earned during a period based on financial assets
invested as at the end date of the period less the actual platform fees, fund fees and advice
earned over the period.

- “Gross Asset Inflows” represents total assets added to AUA during a period.

- “Integrated Flows” represents the percentage of Gross Asset Inflows that were invested in TPI
Funds (as defined in this Offering Memorandum) during a period.

- “Client AUA Churn” represents AUA outflows during a period as a percentage of average AUA
for the period.

- “Net Revenue” represents turnover minus cost of sales for a period. Net Revenue is equivalent
to gross profit as presented in the Financial Statements.

- “Net Revenue Margin” represents Net Revenue for a period divided by average AUA for the
period.

- “Recurring Net Revenue” represents revenue received during a period from retained clients who
have assets on the platform and are receiving advice from us.

- “Adjusted Net Revenue” represents Net Revenue adjusted for Run-Rate Adjustments.

- “EBITDA” represents profit before taxation plus interest payable and amortisation and
depreciation.

- “EBITDA Margin” represents EBITDA divided by Net Revenue.

- “Adjusted EBITDA” represents EBITDA adjusted (i) for run-rate adjustments to reflect assets as
at the end of the period and (ii) to include exceptional items adjustments.

- “Operating Cash Flow before Taxes” represents EBITDA minus change in net working capital
and maintenance capital expenditures.

- “Cash Flow Conversion” represents Operating Cash Flow before Taxes divided by EBITDA.

- “Free Cash Flow” represents Operating Cash Flow before Taxes plus taxes paid and
discretionary capital expenditures.

When reviewing performance, the directors use a combination of GAAP measures and Non-GAAP
Measures. We believe that Non-GAAP Measures are a useful indicator of, among other things, our
ability to incur and service our indebtedness and can assist certain investors, security analysts and
other interested parties in evaluating us. Non-GAAP Measures have limitations as an analytical tool,
and you should not consider them in isolation. Some of these limitations include the following: (i) they
do not reflect our capital expenditures or capitalised product development costs, our future
requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; (ii) they do not reflect changes in,
or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; (iii) they do not reflect the interest expense, or the
cash requirements necessary, to service interest or principal payments on our debt; (iv) although


-----

depreciation and amortisation are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortised will
often need to be replaced in the future and Non-GAAP Measures do not reflect any cash requirements
that would be required for such replacements, (v) they do not reflect the impact of certain cash charges
resulting from matters we consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations and (vi) other
companies in our industry may calculate Non-GAAP Measures such as EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA
differently than we do, limiting the usefulness of such Non-GAAP Measures as comparative measures.

Certain key performance indicators and other non-financial operating data included in this Offering
Memorandum are derived from management estimates, are not part of our Financial Statements or our
accounting records and have not been audited or otherwise reviewed by outside auditors, consultants
or experts. Our use or computation of these measures may not be comparable to the use or

**Overview**

True Potential is a fully integrated technology-led wealth manager, serving investors and advisers
across the United Kingdom. Total assets under administration (“AUA”) on our platform as at
30 September 2021 were approximately £18.8 billion, of which £16.5 billion were assets under our
management (“AUM”), which are assets invested in our range of exclusive investment funds. With our
strong heritage in the North East of England, we have expanded, since inception in 2007, to become
one of the fastest growing financial services businesses in the United Kingdom, employing
approximately 380 full-time staff and working with approximately 4,500 financial advisers. We provide
financial advice, investment platform services and portfolio investment solutions to UK retail clients.

Our aim is to revolutionise the way wealth management is delivered. We believe that by using
technology to deliver financial services, we empower financial advisers and their clients to take control
of their futures. By providing what we call “hybrid advice”, blending technology with expert financial
advice, we are able to offer clients the access and support they need 24/7, while ensuring that they
have an adviser to speak to whenever needed.

We are privileged to work with approximately 17% of UK financial advisers and their clients through
either our fully integrated model or through our software offering, meaning we can have a real impact
on how UK households invest their money and save for retirement.

We grow through accelerated adviser recruitment and client and AUM acquisition. We offer certain
advisers seeking capital to fund their growth a loan of 2% of their total assets under management when
they become “Wealth Management Partners”, which is our term for our team of self-employed
restricted advisers who are focused on the investment opportunities on our platform and in our
portfolios. Our recruitment programmes have contributed to rapid growth in our AUM from £6.0 billion
as at 31 December 2018 to £16.5 billion in our own funds as at 30 September 2021.

True Potential is primarily made up of the following businesses:

- True Potential Investments (“TPI”), which provides our purpose-built, in-house proprietary wealth
management platform and our own exclusive investment fund range;

- True Potential Wealth Management (“TPWM”), which is our wealth management advice
proposition with 844 self-employed Wealth Management Partners as well as our 40-member inhouse team of financial advisers and support staff (the “Central Advice Team”);


-----

- True Potential Adviser Services (“TPAS”), which provides technology, adviser support and
compliance services to approximately 598 financial advice firms with approximately 3,600
individual advisers representing more than one million clients; and

- True Potential Administration LLP (“TPA”), which is the in-house authorised corporate director
(“ACD”) for the 34 underlying funds of the True Potential Portfolios (“TPI Funds”).

As a fully integrated wealth manager participating in all parts of the value chain, we service all stages
of the wealth management process. We benefit from synergies across our ecosystem, with our
distribution, investment management and technology capabilities complementing each other. Our fully
integrated ecosystem enables and benefits from a multi-channel distribution model with multiple fee
streams. New investments pass through the True Potential platform and are invested in our ten
exclusively managed risk-weighted investment portfolios (the “True Potential Portfolios”), enabling us
to capture economies across the value chain. Our multiple distribution channels include (i) our wealth
management advice channel TPWM, (ii) our adviser support services channel TPAS and (iii) a
direct-to-consumer (“D2C”) and auto-enrolment pension channel, where clients do not receive
financial advice. Assets that originated via these distribution channels then flow primarily to TPI, where
they are held and managed. Our multiple fee streams in TPI include (i) platform fees, (ii) fund fees and
(iii) performance fees, while TPWM also benefits from financial advice fees and TPAS also generates
revenue from service fees.

Our revenue has become increasingly diversified across channels, resulting in robust AUA and AUM
expansion, supported by a growing recruitment programme that has led to double-digit revenue
growth and margin expansion. From 31 December 2018 to 30 September 2021, AUA on the True
Potential platform increased by £11.1 billion, or 143.6%, and AUM invested in TPI Funds increased by
£10.6 billion, or 177.3%. Our Net Revenue for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021 was
£165.3 million, which was generated from gross revenue of £260.4 million, and our EBITDA was £122.6
million, representing an EBITDA Margin of 74.2% and an EBITDA compound annual growth rate
(“CAGR”) of 67.8% from 31 December 2018 to 30 September 2021. Adjusted EBITDA for the
twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021 was £160.0 million.

Gross Asset Inflows grew from £2.2 billion in 2018 to £4.2 billion in 2020 to £4.9 billion in the nine
months ended 30 September 2021. Over recent years, organic growth has been the “traditional” route
for Gross Asset Inflows through adviser and productivity growth and remains a strong underpin. The
majority of Gross Asset Inflows in 2018 and 2019 came from organic channels, most notably through
TPWM, which accounted for approximately 52% in 2018 and approximately 40% in 2019, and TPAS,
which represented approximately 43% in 2018 and 24% in 2019. In recent years, management has
been reinvesting cash flows into various recruitment initiatives, increasing the level of inorganic growth
given the market opportunity.

**Competitive Strengths**

**_Fully integrated business model drives capture of top of funnel flows and provides a competitive_**
**_edge_**

We have developed a full suite of capabilities across the value chain, all underpinned by a proprietary,
purpose-built and innovative technology platform that allows us to drive superior financial
performance.

The top of funnel flows are sourced through three distribution channels – (i) our wealth management
advice channel TPWM; (ii) our adviser support services channel TPAS; and (iii) a D2C and autoenrolment pension channel. These assets are held on the True Potential platform and are primarily
invested into TPI Funds held on this platform with a smaller portion of the AUA held in third-party funds.
As a consequence, we have well-diversified revenue attributable to the three distribution channels and
we earn fees across the whole value chain: advice, platform and investment management fees.

Each of our capabilities servicing the wealth management value chain has differentiating attributes,
such as:


-----

- Advice: an at-scale national firm of advisers comprising a team of 844 Wealth Management
Partners and 40 Central Advice Team members, providing advice on True Potential’s investment
proposition.

- Platform: innovative platform seamlessly integrated with advice offering and unified with
investment solutions. The platform has won many awards over the years, most recently the UK
Platform Awards 2021, where True Potential’s platform was voted as the Best Platform Service and
Best Platform Provider.

- Investment solutions: offering competitively priced investment products that provide multi-layered
diversification and attractive risk adjusted returns. Recently, TPI has been named ‘Best for Digital
ISAs’ in the ‘Best Buys 2021 Awards’ by Boring Money.

The proportion of Integrated Flows, calculated as TPI flows divided by total flows, which increased from
89.3% in the year ended 31 December 2018 to 93.0% in the twelve-month period ended 30 September
2021, clearly demonstrates how unique our business model is. Even in absolute terms, Integrated
Flows have increased materially from £2.2 billion in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £6.3 billion
in the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021, representing a CAGR of 46.6%. The full
integration of True Potential’s business model allows us to offer clients significantly lower fees than our
main competitors, while maintaining strong profitability. While integrated solutions providers (e.g.
St. James’ Place ISA/Unit Trust and Pension, Quilter PCA and Hargreaves Lansdown), wealth
managers (e.g. Schroders Personal Wealth, Rathbones and Brewin Dolphin) and independent financial
advice firms (i.e. firms representing a typical UK independent financial adviser charging structure and
having more than five advisers) charge all-in fees of approximately 2.3%, 2.3% and 2.0%, respectively,
True Potential charges clients all-in fees of approximately 1.7% of the amount invested.

Our £18.8 billion of AUA, of which 88% is AUM held in TPI Funds, and our network of 844 Wealth
Management Partners give us significant scale to operate in a very competitive market environment.
Additionally, the proprietary purpose-built technology platform operated by True Potential is already
used by approximately 17% of the total UK adviser population. Finally, we are fully licensed as a fund
manager, platform operator, investment manager, and pension operation and administrator (all within
TPI), and for advisory services (within TPWM). These attributes together underpin the significant
differentiation of our unique competitive strength.

**_High-quality, sticky adviser and client relationships drive high levels of recurring revenue_**

The differentiated technology and strong product set we offer have allowed us to attract and retain
productive advisers. This technology proposition offers full-spectrum support to advisers, driving
adviser productivity and satisfaction. Moreover, we leverage strong technology in the recruitment
process as this facilitates fast onboarding and, where required, a seamless asset transfer process.

We have also developed a structured recruitment process and targeted programmes, which allowed
us to rapidly expand our adviser firm from 456 advisers as at 31 December 2018 to 844 as at
30 September 2021, representing cumulative growth of more than 94%.

We have received consistent recognition from our adviser base for our platform quality, service ratings
and value for money propositions. In the Lang Cat Platform Analyser (Adviser Briefing, Issue Three:
June 2020), True Potential ranked:

- #1 for overall platform, achieving an NPS score of 4.48 (compared to the market average of 3.85);

- #1 for service rating, achieving an NPS score of 4.56 (compared to the market average of 3.59);
and

- #3 for value of fees charged, achieving an NPS score of 4.31 (compared to the market average
of 3.90).

The aforementioned high levels of satisfaction amongst advisers translate to sticky end clients,
demonstrated by our AUA retention rate of 97.6% since inception. The highest retention rate is


-----

observed amongst clients who were transferred with advisers hired under our client acquisition and
adviser recruitment programme. Meanwhile, AUA attrition has remained low over the last three years,
standing at 6.6% in the year ended 31 December 2020.

All of the above translate to a continued and sustained growth in Recurring Net Revenue, which
increased from £53 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £97 million in the year ended
31 December 2020, recording a CAGR of 35% and representing 89% of total Net Revenue.

**_Significant growth opportunity underpinned by structural market tailwinds_**

We operate in the fifth largest wealth management market in the world (Source: Global Wealth
Databook 2021), with £500 billion of assets managed by financial advisers in the UK (Source: The Lang
Cat). We have less than 4% market share of the £500 billion advice market, giving us plenty of
headroom to continue growing our business. In 2020, we were the fastest growing company in the
sector, achieving 34% growth in AUA; the next three fastest growing peers achieved assets under
administration growth rates of 32%, 18% and 17%, respectively (Source: Fundscape).

Within the UK wealth management market, we focus on the fastest growing segment of the UK wealth
market, the mass affluent, which includes investors with investable wealth between £100,000 and
£250,000. Given the tailwinds described below, this segment is expected to continue growing faster
than the market average. Moreover, we are positioned to continue benefiting from these trends given
our unwrapped products and hybrid advice model.

_Well-Positioned for Structural Market Growth_

We are well-positioned for tailwinds linked to the number of structural shifts that underpin the UK
wealth management market. According to an internal survey that started in 2013, we estimate that
there is a savings gap of £17,000 between the existing level of savings for retirement and the amount
necessary to generate a desirable income during retirement, and the UK government is expected to
continue adding initiatives that encourage consumers to save more, driving approximately 4% growth
in gross inflows each year. Recent initiatives included increasing tax savings and pension autoenrolment. Demographic trends are also favourable, with 22% of the population aged 65+ in 2030 (vs
18% in 2018), representing a source of sustained growth for us (Source: Office for National Statistics).

_Growth from Adviser Recruitment_

The average age of independent financial advisers in the United Kingdom is 58 years, and one in five
advisers plans to retire in the next five years (Source: The Private Office, 2020). The recruitment
programmes we have developed provide us with a unique edge to capture the assets under
administration from advisers retiring in the near term.

_Regulatory Tailwinds_

In terms of regulatory developments, the sector has seen a transition from defined benefit plans to
defined contribution plans, which shift the investment responsibility to individuals, driving demand for
financial advice. With the end of compulsory annuitisation, members of defined pension schemes are
no longer required to purchase an annuity with their retirement fund but instead have a variety of
options as to how they can access their retirement income. The increase in accessibility from pensions
freedom has given savers in defined contribution schemes greater and earlier access to their cash,
thus allowing them to make investment decisions at an earlier age and with more capital available.
These changes in regulation represent enduring growth opportunities for us.

_Changing Consumer Trends and Preferences_

Furthermore, the FinTech adoption rate in the United Kingdom has increased significantly, going from
14% in 2015 to 86% in 2021 (Source: Plaid), which represents a great opportunity for True Potential to
leverage our proprietary technology platform by providing advisers and clients an enhanced user
experience. The higher adoption of financial technology platforms and other products, as well as the
greater awareness of the importance of saving and investing, are trends that were clearly identified by


-----

-----

Over the years, the True Potential platform has been widely recognised by the market. At the UK
Platform Awards 2021, sponsored by Schroders, we were presented with two awards: Best Platform
Service and Best Platform Provider. In addition, we were named ‘Best for Digital ISAs’ in the ‘Best Buys
2021 Awards’ by Boring Money, as well as the ‘Best Fund Platform’ at the City of London Wealth
Management Awards 2021.

**_Attractive financial profile delivering strong cash flow generation_**

True Potential has demonstrated strong growth in revenue and Net Revenue, with revenue increasing
from £121 million to £185 million and Net Revenue increasing from £58 million to £108 million for the
years ended 31 December 2018 and 2020, respectively, implying a 24% revenue CAGR and a 36% Net
Revenue CAGR over that period. This has been the result of continuously growing our AUA and a
favourable market environment. We were able to grow our AUA from £7.7 billion as at 31 December
2018 to £18.8 billion as at 30 September 2021, implying a 38% CAGR thanks to strong net flows and
adviser recruitment that unlocks client asset acquisitions. Additionally, despite offering lower all-in fees,
our fully integrated model provides a buffer against wider market performance, which is observed by
the 23 percentage points increase in the EBITDA Margin from 51% in the year ended 31 December
2018 to 74% in the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021. This trend demonstrates our
operational leverage driven by highly scalable operations and significant investments in the platform.

True Potential’s track record of Cash Flow Conversion has improved over the last few years from 64.7%
in the year ended 31 December 2018 to 93.6% in the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021.
Despite investing in adviser recruitment and technology and infrastructure, we were able to continue
generating strong cash flows. Finally, our low level of maintenance capital expenditures gives us
flexibility on how to use our cash flow and significant interest coverage.

**_Structural and cultural focus on good customer outcomes_**

True Potential has a strong track record of creating products centred around clients’ needs, while
offering the products at competitive prices. Despite our fully integrated and technologically advanced
offering, we charge all-in fees that are lower than our main competitors. We charge all-in fees of
approximately 1.7% of invested assets, compared to the 2.3%, 2.3% and 2.0% all-in fees charged by
integrated solutions providers, wealth managers and independent financial advice firms, respectively.

With respect to our investment solutions, the ten portfolios offered by TPI are aligned with our ambition
to provide clients with products that match their risk profile. Since inception, these portfolios have
closely matched their benchmark, thus fulfilling their objective of offering important diversification to
clients’ portfolios. Since inception the portfolios have delivered higher returns than those from the
wider UK discretionary management market as measured by certain financial services firms.

When it comes to client engagement, we aim to provide a superior, seamless and primarily digital
journey with minimal manual intervention. Superior customer experience is underpinned both by the
consistency of client service offered through the Central Advice Team and a platform technology
designed to address needs of the end client. The Central Advice Team provides several client services
that differ from the platform, utilising integrated technology and a head office team to book
appointments or provide access to the live chat. Clients are given an online annual suitability review as
well as having unlimited access to a financial adviser and to the feature impulseSave, which enables
clients to top up investments via their app. Through the Central Advice Team, clients are not subject to
any initial fees or drawdown costs, but instead are charged a low ongoing fee. Finally, through our
enhanced digital offering, we empower customers to review their savings and communicate with
advisers to support saving for retirement.

**_Highly credible, visionary management team complemented by robust governance framework_**

We benefit from a well-established governance structure comprised of a highly credible and visionary
management team with a strong track record. Furthermore, our robust risk management and resilient
internal systems contribute to our success.


-----

The five co-founders, Daniel Harrison, David Harrison, Neil Johnson, Mark Henderson and Earl

**Our Strategies**

We have developed the following strategies to maintain and expand our market-leading positions,
make our businesses more profitable and exploit market opportunities.

**_Continue to focus on adviser recruitment and client asset acquisition_**

We have a strong record in growing our adviser network with the TPWM partner firm having increased
from 456 Wealth Management Partners as at 31 December 2018 to 844 as at 30 September 2021. Our
network of Wealth Management Partners is further complemented by our Central Advice Team of 40
advisers and staff as at 30 September 2021. We have developed a proposition for advisers looking to
monetise their client books and/or raising capital to further grow their client networks. This proposition
is extremely compelling, especially as the transfer of client assets is entirely digitised which leads to a
high conversion rate.

Given our superior technology stack and its consequential impacts on customer experience, we
remain a partner of choice for advisers and clients. There remains a sizable opportunity to target
advisers with our recruitment proposition. We estimate that approximately 24,000, or 87%, of the
approximately 27,500 financial advisers in the United Kingdom are addressable to our recruitment
proposition, with the small firms deemed the easiest to target. As reported by the FCA in July 2021, the
total number of financial advisers in the United Kingdom as at 31 December 2020 was 27,501.
Platforum has reported that 53% of UK financial advisers are in firms with fewer than 50 advisers
(Source: Platforum UK Financial Advisers, November 2020). The smaller firms in the market have seen
increasing regulatory costs and burdens over recent years, via increasing UK Financial Services
Compensation Scheme (the “FSCS”) levy and additional requirements relating to processing
personally identifiable data; therefore, to run a small advice firm is now particularly challenging. We are
better equipped to target advisers from these smaller firms given that we recruit adviser-by-adviser,
rather than at firm level.

True Potential is targeting further productivity gains through specific initiatives, including:

- _Additional sales initiatives. We use Business Development Managers to target additional sales_
opportunities. By making our digital products – Digital Direct Offer, impulseSave, Client Site
Transfer – available to our advisers, we stand to benefit from additional new money inflows onto
our platform and fund products.

- _Advisers focused on Occupational Pension Transfer (“OPT”) market. It is estimated that the_
current addressable market for defined benefit to defined contribution transfers is £782 billion
(Source: True Potential Due Diligence Report). The OPT process is centrally controlled with the
entire transfer process digitised end-to-end. Given the direct oversight from our head office, the
OPT process allows advisers to focus on the sales process while benefiting from the consistency
of a seamless customer journey and auditable transfer process. True Potential remains
differentiated in its approach with limited competitive threats given its technology advantage.

- _Client Service Transfer (CST) initiative. Advisers have the option to transfer their client business to_
our Central Advice Team. This allows the adviser to use the proceeds from the transfer to focus


-----

on building new client relationships and to pay for client leads to accelerate rebuilding their client
books.

We have an innovative platform that underpins our advice offering. The benefit of having started with
an in-house, purpose-built technology platform from the outset is that we have captured material data
on how our users – both advisers and clients – interact with the technology and the functions they
value. This allows us to make targeted offers on the channel with the highest client engagement
translating to a higher success conversion rate.

**_Further improve operational efficiency_**

True Potential has consistently recorded yearly increases in EBITDA Margin. This metric increased from
51% for the year ended 31 December 2018 to 74% for the twelve-month period ended 30 September
2021. The primary driver of our EBITDA Margin is our fully invested, scalable and proprietary
technology platform.

The core architecture of the platform has been provisioned with significant growth potential. For
example, just in terms of storage we have has contracted for 70 terabytes of private cloud capacity and
are currently at 40 terabytes usage. To complement this, we have contracted for 2,800 gigabyte
storage on the public cloud with only approximately 900 gigabytes currently being used. In the future,
our strategy is to continue migrating from the private cloud to a public cloud, which is offered by
Microsoft Azure – a platform-as-a-service (“PaaS”) approach whereby Microsoft manages the ongoing
patching of components. This change will bring us several advantages:

- the ability to focus on developing the components to meet the business needs, instead of
spending too much time on the underlying requirements of infrastructure installations and
maintenance;

- a more flexible cost structure, as we will only pay for what we use, when we use it, and with the
option to turn it off when it is no longer needed; and

- infinite scalability across the globe, as we will not need to project for and purchase expected
infrastructure upfront; we can initiate new projects instantly with the minimum required
infrastructure and scale up as we go.

We expect that the benefits of increasing scale through the business plan are also going to be evident
in the cost of the TPI Funds. The sub-fund managers are on tiered charging structures; as AUM
increases the effective pay away reduces as a result of the tiering. Enhanced scale will also allow us
to negotiate better terms with new sub-advisers we attract to the business.

Management actively reviews the operational set-up of True Potential to unlock cost savings. Two
recent examples include the insourcing of SEI activities and the recent ACD authorisation. SEI
provided the back-office technology and custodianship of the assets on the platform prior to 2018
when TPI built the platform in house. The re-platforming of the assets from the SEI system to the TPI
build system was seamless, which we believe is unprecedented in the platform industry. On the other
hand, Smith and Williamson provided the outsourced ACD function for the TPI fund range prior to the
launch of TPA in 2021.

**_Continue to develop True Potential’s investment solutions_**

Our objective is to deliver investment solutions that offer multi-layered diversification with attractive
risk/reward trade-off at a low cost. There is currently £16.5 billion of AUM in TPI Funds and 93% of total
inflows during the nine-months to 30 September 2021 have been invested in these funds. Since
inception, TPI Funds have delivered strong performance across its range of funds. Delivering the right
outcomes from the range of investment solutions is particularly important and TPI will continue to focus
on sustaining its record of investment outperformance for its customers.

We recently received FCA approval to launch seven new funds, two income funds and five funds
across our current risk categories, adding two new fund managers to our proposition. For the income


-----

portfolios, these managers will provide further diversification to income sources and reduce the current
UK bias. Adding a new manager across our current risk profiles will bring a growth-orientated style
based on their thematic approach to equity selection in our strategies.

TPI, being an integral part of True Potential, provides distinct advantages and allows for close
integration and collaboration across the group. In the future, we expect to develop additional products
to directly meet the needs of customers, including those focused on sustainability.

**_Continue to invest in data and analytics_**

We use technology to ensure end clients have the best possible experience whilst also allowing us to
bulk service clients without significantly growing our teams. Our ability to enable and transition clients
to a state of comfort in managing their own financial affairs online or within the app is key to achieving
this objective. A clear example of our success in this initiative comes from the Central Advice Team,
where we have approximately 30,400 clients serviced by 40 people. Furthermore, we can see a
growing trend in the numbers of client log-ins and returning client log-ins from Central Advice Team
clients and, specifically, clients tend to log-in ten times per month on the app and four times per month
on the web.

Client engagement has always been a key aspect in our business model because the most engaged
clients generally have more assets on our platform. For instance, the Central Advice Team clients
categorised as “Super Engaged” have, on average, assets with £328,000 invested with us, compared
to “Not Engaged” clients worth £93,000 and “Not Activated” clients with £48,000.

As a higher level of client engagement is associated with larger average portfolios, we have been
developing several initiatives with the ultimate goal of improving the engagement level with our clients.
True Potential introduced the next instance of the client facing suite, cNext, in January 2022. This
upgrade is the next level of evolution for True Potential’s client portal which will embed enhanced
analytics and machine learning to identify and customise client-relevant information and product
marketing.

As part of cNext, we have also laid the foundational client-visible features to enable improved
personalisation and hyper-personalisation going forward. The prior current client site had standardised
videos, blogs and articles for clients. In the new instance, these feeds are tailored to respective client
profiles and individual client circumstances and events building on insights gathered from the wealth
of personal information gathered within a standard factfind along with portfolio events, behaviour and
browsing history on the website and app. We also improved our capabilities to send tailored content
and push notifications on the web and our mobile app and enhanced our already available (via the
web) video chat to also be directly available within our mobile apps with no requirement for additional
third-party component installations (such as Zoom). Additionally, we are increasingly integrating open
banking features within our client site. This allows clients to aggregate their bank accounts and offplatform investments on a single view alongside their True Potential investments, in addition to allowing
the clients the ability to visualise their current spending habits and set budgeting targets for the future.
We are also offering rewards to clients as an additional pull feature. Engagement behaviour is useful
for us to improve targeted marketing by allowing relevant product information to be made available in
real time, which translates to a higher success rate. The key objective of these features is to encourage
the end client to self-service, but in doing so data is generated, tracked and analysed by us. We have
a deep data lake of approximately 40 terabytes developed over a span of 14 years that can be
leveraged to hyper-personalise and better service existing clients and enhance cross-selling.

In order to further leverage our well-established back-end system, we continue enhancing our backend data architecture and infrastructure with the development of our client analytics infrastructure and
cube. Client analytics is key to enabling the ease at which data are ingested from the various facets of
the True Potential system and denormalised from data into information that can be easily interrogated
by data analysts with a view to further understand clients, personalise our engagement with each
individual on a bulk scale and predict and influence their behaviour in future. Some advantages
coming from our improvements are: easily and automatically identifying and acting upon opportunities


-----

within the client bank; better predicting client behaviour based on categorisation and clustering; and
hyper-personalising the engagement with and experience of the end client. A final key component of
our strategy is bringing this engagement information back into the vNext system, so that if a client does
need to speak to us, we have an unrivalled visual of the client history and behaviour immediately
visible, thereby ensuring that the end client gets the best possible support.

**The Transactions**

**_The Acquisition_**

On 8 September 2021, the Issuer entered into a sale and purchase deed (the “Acquisition
**Agreement”) for the purchase from the persons named therein as senior partners (the “Senior**
**Partners”), the persons named therein as other shareholders (the “Other Shareholders”) and FTV-**
True, LLC (“FTV”, and, together with the Senior Partners and the Other Shareholders, in their capacity
as sellers under the Acquisition Agreement, the “Sellers”) of all of the issued and outstanding share
capital (the “Shares”) of the Target (the “Acquisition”). Completion of the Acquisition (“Completion”,
and such date, the “Completion Date”) took place on 21 January 2022 following the satisfaction of
certain regulatory conditions, including approval by the UK Financial Conduct Authority (the “FCA”) of
the Issuer’s acquisition of control over the FCA-authorised subsidiaries of the Target. Pursuant to the
Acquisition Agreement, the Issuer acquired the Shares for approximately £1,808.7 million (the
“Purchase Price”).

Pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement, the Cinven Funds indirectly acquired a majority stake in the
Target Group through intermediate holding companies, including Kane Feederco Limited, Kane Topco
Limited, the Parent and the Issuer. On Completion, the Cinven Funds acquired beneficial ownership of
a majority stake of 68.7%, with the Sellers reinvesting a portion of the sale proceeds and retaining a
31.3% minority interest.

**_The Financing_**

The Acquisition was financed as follows:

- the Cinven Funds and the Sellers contributed £1,795.2 million, directly or indirectly, by way of
equity (the “Equity Contribution”), of which £1,232.6 million was contributed by the Cinven
Funds and £562.6 million was equity reinvested by the Sellers; and

- the Issuer entered into a bridge facility agreement on 19 January 2022 (the “Bridge Facility
**Agreement”), which provides for term borrowings of £675.0 million (the “Bridge Facility”) and**
drew the full amount of available borrowings.


-----

In addition, the Issuer entered into a revolving credit facility agreement on 19 January 2022 (the
“Revolving Facility Agreement”), which provides for multi-currency borrowings of £100.0 million (the
“Revolving Credit Facility”). The Revolving Credit Facility was drawn in an amount of £50.0 million on
the Completion Date, providing the Target with cash for working capital liquidity.

The Equity Contribution, the full amounts drawn under the Bridge Facility and the amount drawn under
the Revolving Credit Facility were used to: (i) pay the Purchase Price for the Acquisition; (ii) repay in
full and cancel the existing indebtedness of the Target in an amount of approximately £615.0 million;
(iii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions (as defined herein) in an amount of
£45.1 million; and (iv) fund the Issuer’s balance sheet with £52.4 million.

The above financings are collectively referred to herein as the “Financing”. The proceeds from the
Offering will be used to repay and cancel the Bridge Facility (the “Refinancing”).

The Financing, the Acquisition, the repayment and cancellation of the existing indebtedness of the
Target and the Refinancing are collectively referred to herein as the “Transactions”. See “Use of
_Proceeds”._

**Our Principal Shareholders**

**_Cinven_**

Cinven is one of Europe’s largest and most established private equity firms. Cinven has been investing
since 1977 and has completed transactions valued in excess of €100 billion across six key sectors:
financial services, industrials and technology, media and telecommunications (TMT), business
services, consumer and healthcare. Cinven has offices in London, New York, Frankfurt, Madrid, Paris,
Milan, Guernsey and Luxembourg. Cinven has a highly experienced investment team of 119
professionals, including 32 partners, with one of the longest track records in the industry and
experience in dealing with localised and culturally specific aspects of European acquisitions. Cinven is
committed to supporting businesses on their growth trajectory and has a track record of value creation
focused on revenue growth and efficiencies, demonstrated by the fact that over 80% of value creation
in prior investments was driven by EBITDA growth, with about two-thirds of EBITDA growth from topline revenue growth. The limited partner base of the Cinven Funds comprises many blue-chip
institutional investors, including major pension funds, sovereign wealth funds and insurance
companies and no individual Cinven investor accounts for more than 5% of the equity committed to
the Cinven Funds.

Cinven has a long and differentiated track record of investing in the financial services sector, including
in highly regulated assets, where its track record includes the acquisitions of Compre, Guardian
Financial Services, Miller, NewDay, Partnership Assurance and Premium Credit Limited, in the United
Kingdom, Ark Life and Avolon in Ireland, Heidelberger Leben (now renamed Viridium Group) in
Germany, Skandia in Germany and Austria and Ergo Italia and Old Mutual Wealth in Italy. In addition,
Cinven maintains transparent and constructive relationships with regulators, having achieved
regulatory approvals over 40 times in different European jurisdictions as well as in Bermuda and
Singapore.

(9)  The Issuer entered into the Revolving Credit Facility on 19 January 2022. The Revolving Credit Facility has a total
commitment of £100.0 million and will mature four years and nine months after the Completion Date. The Revolving Credit
Facility was drawn in an amount of £50.0 million on the Completion Date. Borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility
are available to fund our general corporate purposes and working capital requirements and may be drawn in pounds
sterling, euros, US dollars or other currencies consented to by all of the relevant lenders. Kane Bidco Limited is the original
borrower and original guarantor under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. A mechanism is included in the Revolving
Credit Facility Agreement to enable certain of Kane Bidco Limited’s subsidiaries to accede as a borrower and/or a guarantor
under the Revolving Credit Facility subject to certain conditions. There is no requirement under the Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement for any affiliates of Kane Bidco Limited to accede as a borrower or a guarantor at any time.

**Ranking of the Notes . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will, on the Issue Date:

               - be general senior obligations of the Issuer;

               - be secured as set forth under “—Security”;

               - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and
future Indebtedness of the Issuer that is not expressly


-----

subordinated in right of payment to the Notes (including
the obligations of the Issuer under the Revolving Credit
Facility and certain Hedging Obligations, if any);

               - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future
indebtedness of the Issuer that is expressly subordinated
in right of payment to the Notes;

               - not be guaranteed by any Subsidiary (as defined in
“Description of the Notes”) or parent of the Issuer;

               - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future
Indebtedness or obligation (including obligations to trade
creditors) of the Issuer that is secured by property and
assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the
value of the property and assets securing such
Indebtedness; and

               - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future
Indebtedness of Subsidiaries (as defined in “Description of
_the Notes”) of the Issuer that do not guarantee the Notes._

**Security . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** On the Issue Date, the Notes will (subject to the Agreed Security
Principles) be secured by limited recourse third-party security
over the Parent’s shares in the Issuer and any structural
intercompany receivables owed to the Parent by the Issuer (the
“Issue Date Collateral”).

Within 30 days after the Completion Date, the Notes will (subject
to the Agreed Security Principles) also be secured by the
Issuer’s material bank accounts, its shares in the Target and any
structural intercompany receivables owed to the Issuer by the
Target (the “Post-Completion Date Collateral” and, together
with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”).

The Collateral will also secure the obligations of the Issuer under
the Revolving Credit Facility. In the event of enforcement of the
Collateral, Holders will receive proceeds from such Collateral
only after lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility have been
repaid in full. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Notes and
_Collateral—Creditors under the Revolving Credit Facility and_
_counterparties to certain hedging obligations and future_
_indebtedness ranking pari passu with the Revolving Credit_
_Facility that is permitted to be incurred under the terms of the_
_Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement will be entitled to be_
_repaid with proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral in_
_priority over the Notes”._

The security interests in the Collateral may be limited by
applicable law or subject to certain defences that may limit their
validity and enforceability. In addition, the security interests in
the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances.
Subject to the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, the
Collateral may be pledged to secure future indebtedness. For
more information on the security interests granted, see
“Description of the Notes—Security”. For more information on
potential limitations to the security interests, see “Limitations on

Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal
amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional
amounts, if any, to the date of the purchase (subject to the right
of holders of record on the relevant record date to receive
interest due on the relevant interest payment date). See
“Description of the Notes—Change of Control”.

**Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture will limit, among other things, the ability of the
Issuer to:

               - incur or guarantee certain indebtedness and issue certain
preferred stock;

               - pay dividends on, redeem or repurchase its capital stock;

               - make certain restricted payments;


-----

               - make certain investments;

               - create or permit to exist certain liens;

               - impose restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay
dividends or make other payments to us;

               - merge or consolidate with other entities, or make certain
asset sales;

               - enter into certain transactions with affiliates;

               - impair the security interests for the benefit of the Holders;

               - guarantee certain indebtedness; and

               - undertake activities other than those customarily
undertaken by a holding company.

Certain of the covenants and events of default will be
suspended if and for as long as we achieve investment-grade
ratings. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—
_Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade_
_Status”._

Each of the covenants in the Indenture will be subject to
significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the
_Notes—Certain Covenants”._

**Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes have not been registered under the Securities Act or
the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and will not be so
registered. The Notes are subject to restrictions on
transferability and resale. See “Notice to Investors”. Holders will
not have the benefit of any exchange or registration rights.

**Listing/No Prior Market . . . . . . . .** Application is expected to be made to the Authority to list the
Notes on the Official List and for permission to be granted to
deal in the Notes on the Official List. There can be no assurance
that the application to the Authority to list the Notes on the
Official List will be approved or that permission to deal in the
Notes thereon will be granted, and settlement of the Notes is not
conditioned on obtaining this listing or permission.

The Notes will be new securities for which there is no market.
Although certain of the Initial Purchasers have informed us that
they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not
obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at
any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that
an active trading market for the Notes will develop or be
maintained.

**Risk Factors . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should
consider carefully all of the information in this Offering
Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the
specific risk factors set forth in the “Risk Factors” section before
making a decision whether to invest in the Notes.

**Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes and the Indenture will be governed by New York law.
