###### RISK FACTORS

_An investment in the Notes entails risks. There are a number of factors, including those specified below,_
_that may adversely affect our ability to make payments under the Notes. You could therefore lose a_
_substantial portion or all of your investment in the Notes. Consequently, an investment in the Notes_
_should be considered only by persons who can assume such risk. You should note that the risks_
_described below are not the only risks that we face. The risks described below are all of the risks we_
_consider to be material. However, there may be additional risks that we currently consider immaterial or_
_of which we are currently unaware, and any of these risks could have the effects set forth above. Our_
_business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be materially adversely affected_
_by any of these risks. When the terms “we”, “us” and “our” are used in this section, (i) when referring_
_to operations, businesses, market shares or historical financial results, such terms refer to the Target_
_and its subsidiaries, (ii) when referring to the Financing and pro forma indebtedness obligations, such_
_terms refer to the Issuer and (iii) when referring to the Transactions, such terms refer to one or more of_
_the Issuer and the Parent._

**Risks Related to Our Business**

**_Difficult macroeconomic conditions could lead to asset price declines or volatility which may_**
**_adversely affect the market value of our AUA and AUM, which in turn could have a material_**
**_adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects._**

A deterioration in global capital markets, the global economy generally and the UK economy may
adversely affect our results because we derive a significant portion of our income from fees, which are
calculated as a percentage of AUA or AUM. We are directly exposed to changes in both equity markets
and fixed income markets, through the value of AUA or AUM. Our AUA and our AUM have increased
from £7.7 billion and £6.0 billion, respectively, as at 31 December 2018 to £18.8 billion and
£16.5 billion, respectively, as at 30 September 2021. These increases have largely been responsible
for our rapid turnover and EBITDA growth over this time period. If our AUA or AUM were to decrease
as result of adverse market conditions, our turnover and EBITDA could see slower growth or even
decline.

Factors that have had, and may continue to have, a material adverse impact on global capital markets
include political or regulatory change or uncertainty, supply chain difficulties, energy price volatility,
natural disasters, impacts of climate change, terrorist incidents, rising inflationary concerns, labour
market tightening, concerns over low levels of growth in developed and emerging economies and
corporate profits, rapid rises and falls in currency exchange rates, high levels of sovereign debt,
changes in inflation expectations and long-term low, negative or increasing interest rates and bond
yields. The continued impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, including the emergence of the Delta,
Omicron and potential other variants, may also adversely affect the global economy. The immigration,
trade and tax policies of the United Kingdom, Europe or the United States could also lead to major
changes in global trade flows, which could have a material impact on the global economy or could
lead to volatility and a decline in capital markets or particular asset classes, which might reduce the
demand for or value of investment assets.

In recent years, steady economic growth accompanied with a loose monetary policy has generally
resulted in low volatility across financial markets. However, this combination could change, and robust
performance in financial markets, particularly equity markets, is unlikely to continue indefinitely. Initially
to support recovery after the global financial crisis, and more recently in 2020 to support the global
economy during the lockdowns and restrictions imposed because of the COVID-19 pandemic,
quantitative easing measures implemented by record low interest rates or the purchase of government
debt set by central banks (e.g. the Bank of England, the European Central Bank and the U.S. Federal
Reserve) have helped loosen financial conditions and decrease borrowing costs, and these measures
may have led to the emergence of asset and liquidity bubbles that could be susceptible to rapid price
corrections as financial conditions tighten, including in the stock, bond and property markets. As a
result, these measures may directly decrease the investment returns on our products and portfolios,
thereby reducing our fee income. The withdrawal of accommodative policies may cause losses to


-----

investors and raise the risk of default on fixed income securities, including those in assets we manage.
Higher interest rates may make investing in our investment products less attractive than alternative
investment opportunities.

The True Potential Portfolios we manage include a range of assets that are denominated in foreign
currencies, including foreign equities and bonds. Some of this foreign currency exposure is hedged,
but the effect of exchange rate fluctuations on these assets could nevertheless lead to fluctuations in
the amount of fee income generated.

Furthermore, although a significant portion of the assets we manage come from pensions and
Individual Savings Accounts (“ISAs”), where flows are less sensitive to market fluctuations, in very
severe market conditions we may also experience an indirect impact on AUA and AUM through the
redemption of products by clients or lower sales figures. These adverse changes would impact the
stock of AUA and AUM and thus affect earnings negatively and potentially have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_We operate in an intensely competitive industry. Competitive pressures may result in a loss of_**
**_clients and their assets or compel us to reduce the fees we charge to clients, thereby reducing_**
**_our revenue and EBITDA._**

We are subject to competition in our business from other integrated solutions providers, wealth
managers and independent financial adviser firms, such as Aviva Wrap, Fidelity, Praemium, Prudential,
Quilter, Royal London, Standard Life Elevate, Standard Life Wrap, St James’s Place and Transact.
Some of these financial institutions have greater resources than we do and may offer a broader range
of financial products across more markets. We compete with other providers of investment advisory
services primarily based on the availability and objectives of the investment products offered,
investment performance, fees and related expenses, and the scope and quality of investment advice
and other client services. Some institutions have proprietary products and distribution channels that
make it more difficult for us to compete with them in certain circumstances. Substantially all of our
investment products are available without sales or redemption fees, which means that investors may
be more willing to transfer assets to competing products, leading to decreases in revenue and EBITDA.

In the event that we decide to reduce the fees we charge for investment advisory services in response
to competitive pressures, which we have done selectively in the past, revenue and operating margins
could be adversely impacted, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_Increasing investor preference in favour of passive products may result in a loss of our market_**
**_share, which could lead to a reduction in our revenue and EBITDA._**

While investment markets have generally experienced sustained growth in recent years, many active
funds have not performed as well as passive investments, which has led some UK investors to
increasingly focus on fees and related expenses and in turn favour lower fee passive investment
products. As a consequence, passive funds constituted 31% of assets under management in the
United Kingdom in 2020 and are likely to grow further, compared to 26% of assets under management
in 2017 (Source: The Investment Association, September 2021 and September 2018). Moreover, the
increasing adoption of technology and the growth of digital advisers have further driven the demand
for passive investment products. This is expected to lead to lower levels of fees in the asset
management industry and could possibly result in the consolidation of smaller players as scale
becomes increasingly important. Moreover, investment managers who place a greater focus on
cost-efficient passive products are gaining market share. However, this migration to passive investing
is occurring at a slower rate in the retail wealth compared to the institutional investor pools and is
favoured by the younger investors who have a far lower level of assets under management than the
older investors who are less inclined to switch to passive investing. While we believe there will continue
to be demand in the United Kingdom for strong performing active management at attractive pricing,
we cannot predict how much market share competitors offering passive investment products will gain.
The loss of market share in the United Kingdom to these competitors could adversely affect our


-----

revenue and operating margins, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_Underperformance, whether actual or perceived, of customer assets relating to our products,_**
**_solutions or funds under our management could have a material adverse effect on our business,_**
**_financial condition, results of operations and prospects._**

A substantial portion of our business involves the provision of advice-led wealth solutions (through
TPWM) and the management of multi-asset solutions and investment portfolios (through TPWM, TPI
and TPAS). As a result, a key factor in our ability to maintain and expand our customer base and our
network of advisers is the investment performance of the customer assets that we manage. Currently,
we offer our customers the opportunity to invest in 34 True Potential exclusive funds across ten
portfolios. Any sustained period of actual or perceived underperformance of the products, solutions or
portfolios we deliver, whether as compared to peers, customer expectations, benchmarks (as indicated
by the likes of Morningstar, for example) or internal targets, could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

When financial advisers select investment products or when customers select a wealth manager, one
of the key considerations is the historical investment performance of the products or solutions offered.
If we were to fail to provide satisfactory investment returns in our managed portfolios or wealth
management solutions, customers of such solutions (or customers generally) may choose to decrease
their investments with us or withdraw assets altogether in favour of better-performing services or
competing investment managers, which would lead to a direct reduction in the level of our AUA and
AUM and, as a result, lower fee income.

Investment underperformance as compared to competitors, customer or adviser expectations or
relevant benchmarks would also make it more difficult for us to attract new customers and advisers
and could damage our reputation and brands, which have in part been built around our investment
performance generally. As a result, our ability to attract assets from existing and new customers and
advisers might diminish, particularly given the competitive nature of the wealth management market.
Independent and restricted financial advisers and other intermediaries, who typically play a substantial
role in referring new customers to us and distributing our products, may reduce or cease
recommending some or all of our products to their customers, which could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_A majority of our revenue is based on customer contracts that are subject to termination without_**
**_cause and on short notice._**

Our revenue is predominantly derived from fund and platform fees, which are typically calculated as a
percentage of the market value of the value of our AUA and AUM. A high proportion of our wealth
management products permit our customers to reduce the aggregate amount of their investment with
little or no notice, or to withdraw altogether from such portfolios or contracts. If interest rates rise, equity
markets or fixed income markets decline or our investment performance underperforms, the rate of
redemptions and withdrawals could accelerate. Furthermore, changes in investing trends, particularly
investor preference for passive or alternative investment products, and in retirement savings trends,
may reduce interest in our products and may alter our mix of AUA or AUM. A substantial or systemic
withdrawal of AUA or AUM could result in lower platform fees and therefore revenue and, depending
on the extent of such withdrawals, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_Failure to effectively and efficiently attract, retain and onboard financial advisers and their clients_**
**_may materially and adversely affect our ability to grow our business._**

The primary growth channel for our business is through accelerated recruitment of restricted financial
advisers, through which we sell and distribute our products and solutions. We depend on our ability to
continually attract, train and retain high-calibre advisers under our recruitment programme in a
competitive market. As at 30 September 2021, we had a total of 844 advisers in TPWM, comprising
approximately 17% of the total market of financial advisers in the United Kingdom. The number of


-----

restricted financial advisers in TPWM has grown from 456 as at 31 December 2018 to 844 as at
30 September 2021. If we are unable to continue to grow our number of advisers, either as a result of
factors outside of our control (such as consolidation of our competitors leading to benefits from
economies of scale) or factors within our control (such as failure to offer competitive rewards and
compensations or to maintain a positive reputation), we may fail to achieve our strategic objectives or
achieve the anticipated benefits of our strategy, which could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_We may not be able to attract, integrate, manage and retain qualified personnel or key_**
**_employees._**

Our future operating results depend in significant part upon the continued contribution of our board of
directors, key senior management and technical, financial and operations personnel. Management of
our growth will require, among other things, stringent control of financial systems and operations, the
continued development of our management control, the ability to attract and retain sufficient numbers
of qualified management and other personnel, the continued training of such personnel, sufficient
internal succession planning for key roles and the presence of adequate supervision. The personal
connections and relationships of our board of directors and key management are important to the
conduct of our business. If we were to unexpectedly lose a member of our key management team, our
business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be materially adversely
affected.

In particular, the success of our business depends on our ability to successfully adapt to rapidly
changing technological, social, economic and regulatory developments. This necessitates a range of
specialist personnel, particularly in the areas of compliance and risk, technical support, finance and
controls, sales, administration and operations, and requires us to retain, recruit and develop the
necessary personnel who can provide the needed expertise across the entire spectrum of our business
and operations. The market for qualified personnel is competitive and we may not succeed in recruiting
additional personnel, or we may fail to replace departing personnel with suitable successors. There
may be a limited number of persons with the requisite skills to serve in this position and we cannot
assure you that we will be able to identify or employ qualified internal or external candidates within a
reasonable timeframe. Our efforts to retain and develop personnel may also result in additional
expenses, which could adversely affect our profitability. We cannot guarantee that key personnel,
including executive officers, will remain in our employment or that we will be able to attract and retain
qualified personnel in the future, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_We are exposed to risks arising from the conduct of our employees, advisers and representatives._**

Our decisions and behaviour, and those of our 844 self-employed restricted advisers who are focused
on the investment opportunities on True Potential’s platform and in its portfolios (the “Wealth
**Management Partners”), if they do not align with the principles governing our business, may lead to**
unfair treatment of our customers or otherwise result in unfavourable customer outcomes. Conduct risk
may arise where we or our Wealth Management Partners fail to design, implement or adhere to
appropriate policies and procedures, offer products, services or other propositions that do not meet
the needs of customers or fail to perform in accordance with their respective intended design, fail to
communicate properly with customers, fail to deal with complaints effectively, sell or recommend
unsuitable products or solutions to our customers, fail to provide them with sufficient information to
make informed decisions or provide inappropriate investment or financial planning advice to
customers, or fail to do any of the foregoing on a continuing basis after initial sales, among other
things.

Conduct risk remains the subject of close regulatory scrutiny. Given that regulation includes
principles-based rules and regulations, the rules and regulations may be subject to differing
applications and interpretations by regulators or market participants over time. Failing to protect the
interests of customers in this way and failing to demonstrate adequate suitability processes and
monitoring could lead to legal proceedings or regulatory enforcement actions. Furthermore, regulators


-----

may deem certain of our advisers’ customers to be “vulnerable” customers, which the FCA has defined
as someone who, owing to their personal circumstances, is particularly susceptible to detriment,
especially when a firm is not acting with appropriate levels of care. This finding may result in a higher
standard of conduct being required of us in relation to products and services offered to such
customers. Potential legal proceedings or regulatory enforcement actions could in turn lead to financial
penalties, reputational damage and, in the case of regulatory enforcement action, the suspension or
revocation of regulatory permissions, licenses or approvals. Moreover, if we fail to detect misconduct
on a timely basis, or at all, we may face additional reputational or financial damage, which could have
a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Our occupational pension transfer distribution channel is subject to higher regulatory and market
standards around suitability of advice. For instance, clients onboarded through occupational pension
transfers undergo a robust compliance process where client information is obtained and analysed
before a presentation is made to the client. The pension is then subject to continuous internal and
external compliance monitoring, including internal suitability file checks, expert P2P check and SMF16
checks. We are confident that we will continue to provide suitable advice which is fully compliant with
all FCA rules and guidance, as evidenced in November 2019 following a two-day visit from the FCA
that showed no material concerns over our occupational pension transfer business. However, any
failure to maintain our compliance could lead to financial penalties, reputational damage and the
suspension or revocation of regulatory permissions, licenses or approvals, which in turn could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects.

**_Any damage to our reputation could harm our business and lead to decreases in revenue and_**
**_EBITDA._**

We have spent many years developing our reputation for integrity, strong investment performance and
superior client service. Our brand is a valuable intangible asset, but it is vulnerable to a variety of
threats that can be difficult or impossible to control and costly, or even impossible, to remediate.
Regulatory inquiries and rumours can tarnish or substantially damage our reputation, even if those
inquiries are satisfactorily addressed. Actual or perceived failure to adequately address the
environmental, social and governance (“ESG”) expectations of our various stakeholders could lead to
a tarnished reputation and loss of customers. While we maintain policies, procedures and controls to
reduce the likelihood of unauthorised activities, we are subject to the risk that our associates or third
parties acting on our behalf may circumvent controls or act in a manner inconsistent with our policies
and procedures. Real or perceived conflicts between our clients’ interests and our own, as well as any
fraudulent activity or other exposure of client assets or information, may impair our reputation and
subject us to litigation or regulatory action. Any damage to our brand could impede our ability to attract
and retain clients and key personnel, and reduce the amount of assets under our management, and
in turn our revenue and EBITDA, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_Our business performance is underpinned by our technology and our operations could suffer_**
**_from technology interruptions, increased technology costs and an inability to successfully_**
**_anticipate, manage or adopt technological advances within our industry._**

The success of our business depends in large part on our information technology infrastructure and
software systems. We must record and process significant amounts of data quickly and accurately to
access, maintain and expand the databases we use for our business activities. Our capacity to execute
and process transactions and provide end-customers with a seamless and effective service depends
on our ability to store, retrieve, process and manage significant quantities of data on a continuous
basis. Accordingly, interruptions to or loss of our information processing capabilities through the loss
of stored data, computer equipment or software systems failure, telecommunications failure or other
disruption could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and prospects. Such disruptions could be caused by, among other things, terrorist
activities, computer viruses, third-party attacks, disease or pandemics. Any security or privacy breach
of these databases could also expose us to liability, cause us to incur expenses relating to the


-----

resolution of these breaches, harm our reputation and deter intermediaries and customers from
dealing with us. Although we maintain, and regularly assess the adequacy of, a disaster recovery plan
designed to effectively manage the effects of such unforeseen events, we cannot be certain that any
recovery plan will function as intended. A failure or inadequacy of our disaster recovery plan may have
a material adverse effect on our ability to support and service our customer base.

Additionally, information technology evolves rapidly and is characterised by short product life cycles.
We may not be successful in anticipating, managing or adapting to technological changes on a timely
basis, which could allow our competitors to serve customers more effectively. Although we seek to
upgrade our information technology hardware infrastructure on a regular basis, there can be no
assurance that our information technology infrastructure and software systems will continue to be
adequate for our business. For example, we could face risks associated with the release of a new
operating system that is vulnerable to cyberattacks, our capacity for storing data if we take on
numerous clients without preparing the necessary storage, or with the publication of a webpage that
could be exploited. While we believe that our existing information technology infrastructure and
software systems are sufficient to meet our current demands, our future growth may require additional
investment in these systems. We depend on having the capital resources necessary to invest in new
technologies to successfully offer our advances and process payments. We cannot assure you that
adequate capital resources will be available to us when we need to make such investments, which
could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and
prospects.

**_A cyberattack or a failure to implement effective information and cybersecurity policies,_**
**_procedures and capabilities could disrupt operations and cause financial losses._**

We depend on the effectiveness of the information and cybersecurity policies, procedures and
capabilities we maintain to protect our systems and data. An externally caused information security
incident, such as a cyberattack, a phishing scam, virus, ransomware attack, denial-of-service attack,
or an attack launched from within our organisation, could materially interrupt business operations or
cause disclosure or modification of confidential client or competitive information.

There have been increasing numbers of publicised cybersecurity incidents in recent years impacting
other financial services firms as well as firms in other industries. Our use of third-party vendors and
cloud technologies could heighten this risk. Should the technology operations on which we rely be
compromised, we may have to make significant investments to upgrade, repair or replace our
technology infrastructure or third-party vendors and may not be able to make such investments on a
timely basis. Although we maintain insurance coverage that we believe is reasonable, prudent and
adequate for the purpose of our business, it may be insufficient to protect us against all losses and
costs stemming from breaches of security, cyberattacks and other types of unlawful activity, or any
resulting disruptions from such events, which could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_We may experience security and privacy breaches of the systems we use to protect personal_**
**_data._**

Our databases contain personal data of our customers. This data includes information such as name
and date of birth, location information, banking information, credit history and other information that
may be considered personal or confidential. Our databases are vulnerable to interference by
individuals external to our business and by our own employees and service providers, and any misuse
could include fraud and identity theft as well as human error and accidental user activity. Despite the
security measures we have implemented to prevent unauthorised access to information stored in our
database, our systems may fail to adequately protect against physical or electronic break-ins,
computer viruses and similar disruptive problems.


-----

**_Our business may suffer if we are sued for infringing the intellectual property rights of third_**
**_parties, or if we are unable to obtain rights to third-party intellectual property on which our_**
**_business depends. We may not be able to defend our intellectual property rights against third_**
**_parties._**

Product development and differentiation in our industry requires the use of intellectual property rights,
particularly trademarks, licenses and trade secrets. In particular, we rely on a purpose-built proprietary
technology platform to deliver our products and services to our advisers and clients. We have not
historically sought to protect our intellectual property rights by obtaining patent protection, as our
platform would be extremely difficult to replicate. These proprietary rights are important to our business
and our ability to compete effectively with other market participants. We also rely upon trade secrets,
know-how, continuing technological innovations and licensing rights to develop, maintain and
strengthen our competitive position. Third parties may in the future assert claims that our systems,
services or products infringe their proprietary rights. Such infringement claims, even if without merit,
may cause us to incur significant costs in defending against those claims. We may be required to
discontinue using any infringing technology or services, pay damages or royalty fees, expend
resources to develop non-infringing technology, dedicate significant financial and management
resources to defend these claims, or purchase licenses or pay royalties for alternative technology.

We may initiate litigation to protect our trade secrets and know-how or determine the enforceability,
scope and validity of the proprietary rights of others. Any lawsuits that we initiate could be expensive,
time-consuming and divert management’s attention from other business concerns. In addition, we may
not prevail in lawsuits that we initiate, and the damages or other remedies awarded, if any, may not be
commercially valuable. In addition, any successful infringement proceedings may be economically
worthless for us if they take too much time and the intellectual property right, or the product developed
on the basis of it, becomes obsolete. Any such failure to protect our intellectual property could diminish
our competitive advantage and cause us to lose customers to competitors, which could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

**_Our investment management operations may subject us to fiduciary or other legal liability for_**
**_client losses._**

Fund and trust management and administration are complex activities and include functions such as
recordkeeping and accounting, security pricing, corporate actions, compliance with investment
restrictions, daily net asset value computations, account reconciliations and required distributions to
fund shareholders. Failure to properly perform operational tasks or the misrepresentation of our
services and products could subject us to regulatory sanctions, penalties or litigation and result in
reputational damage, liability to clients, the termination of investment management or administration
agreements and/or the withdrawal of assets under our management. For example, in connection with
the production of the quantitative models that we use to support investment decisions and processes,
including those related to risk assessment, portfolio management, trading and hedging activities and
product valuations, we use Morningstar as a provider of capital market assumptions, such as expected
return, volatility and asset class correlations. Errors in the design, function or underlying assumptions
used in these models and tools, particularly if we fail to detect the errors over an extended period,
could subject us to claims of a breach of fiduciary duty and potentially large liabilities for make-whole
payments, litigation and/or regulatory fines, which could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

On 23 October 2020, the FCA authorised our subsidiary, True Potential Administration LLP, to operate
as an internal authorised corporate director, or “ACD”, for the TPI Funds. Prior to this, we retained the
services of a third-party to provide certain investment management services separate from our
administration and management of the True Potential Portfolios ACDs are responsible for ensuring that
funds, such as the 34 exclusive funds we offer, operate within the rules and regulations of the FCA and
are run in the best interests of investors. However, if our internal ACD is unable to ensure that we are
operating within the FCA rules and regulations, we could be subject to financial penalties, reputational
damage and the suspension or revocation of regulatory permissions, licenses or approvals, which in


-----

turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or
prospects.

The role of authorised fund managers (“AFMs”) in our industry is currently subject to substantial
scrutiny. The FCA launched a review into AFMs (including ACDs) and released a report in June 2021
outlining weaknesses it discovered in the way in which AFMs operated, including (i) how well AFMs
understand their responsibilities for the funds they operate; (ii) whether these firms had adequate
controls, governance and resources to carry out their role; (iii) how effectively the AFM firms
considered their regulatory responsibilities, primarily under the Collective Investment Scheme
Sourcebook (COLL); (iv) how their oversight of delegated third-party investment managers considered
the interests of fund investors; and (v) whether they had appropriate resources for the nature and scale
of the business they carried out. The FCA expects all AFMs to consider the lessons in this summary
and how they should be applied to the way the AFMs conduct their business. While the primary focus
of the review was AFMs managing UK UCITS funds through a host model, all AFMs managing
authorised funds should also consider the implications for their business. While the FCA’s
observations are focused on conflicts and issues that arose in a host model, there are also useful
lessons for firms operating within a group structure. Our operating model was designed and
established with these lessons in mind. However, we are actively monitoring and managing resources
as the business grows. For example, we intend to appoint a third independent non-executive director
in 2022. If we are unable to continue to keep these lessons in mind as we grow, we could be subject
to review by the FCA, which could lead to financial penalties, reputational damage and the suspension
or revocation of regulatory permissions, licenses or approvals, which in turn could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects.

**_We are subject to operational risks, including the risk of direct or indirect loss resulting from_**
**_insufficient or failed internal and external processes, poor data handling, systems and human_**
**_error or from external events._**

We rely on our ability to manage a range of internal and external processes, systems and data,
including, for example: (i) platform administration and reporting services to advisers; (ii) processing
and reporting on a substantial number of transactions across numerous and varied products;
(iii) management of customer policies and assets; (iv) maintenance of the integrity of a significant
volume of data; and (v) compliance with relevant regulatory reporting requirements. Furthermore, the
long-term nature of our businesses means that accurate records must be maintained for substantial
periods.

We cannot predict or anticipate the specifics or timing of all possible operational and systems failures
that may negatively impact our business. The systems and processes on which we depend to serve
customers and advisers may fail due to IT malfunctions, business interruptions, intentional
interference, human error, non-performance by third parties or other external events. If systematic or
human errors or failed internal or external processes were to occur with respect to any of the foregoing
or similar risks, this could disrupt business operations, resulting in material brand and reputational
damage, regulatory action, and loss of customers or advisers, any of which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. We may also
be required to conduct detailed investigations of the circumstances surrounding the breach and
regulatory investigations may also follow. The costs involved in such investigations, including
management’s time and professional fees, could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operations or prospects.

**_If our outside service providers and vendors are unable to or do not fulfil their obligations, our_**
**_operations could be disrupted and our operating results could be harmed._**

We depend on a number of service providers and vendors such as telecommunication companies,
software engineers, data processors, software and hardware vendors and providers of credit score
algorithms who are critical to our operations. These providers include Microsoft Azure, Pulsant and
Morningstar, among others. Although we have implemented agreements and have established
monitoring controls for these service providers and vendors, our operations could be disrupted if we


-----

do not successfully manage relationships with them, if they do not perform or are unable to perform
their obligations, or if they are unwilling to make their services or products available to us at reasonable
prices, which could adversely affect our reputation, business, financial condition, results of operations
and prospects. Additionally, if we are forced to switch service providers or vendors, we cannot assure
you that we would be able to contract with a suitable replacement, or that the prices set by the new
service provider or vendor would be in line with current pricing.

In addition, we depend on banking systems to execute payment transactions in connection with our
business. A systematic shutdown or any other disruption of the banking industry or one of the banks
we work with would impede our ability to process funds on behalf of customers. Any of the foregoing
factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations
or prospects.

**_Our risk management policies and procedures may not be fully effective in mitigating our risk_**
**_exposure._**

Our business activities expose us to a wide variety of risks, including credit risk (including execution
settlement risk and overdraft settlement risk), liquidity risk, market risk (including market price risk,
foreign exchange risk and interest rate risk), operational risk (including IT risk and legal/compliance
risk) and reputational risk. For many of these risks we have established risk management policies,
some of which are set by or require approval from regulatory bodies. However, our strategies and
procedures for managing such risks may prove insufficient or fail.

Some of our methods for managing risk are based on observations of historical market behaviour and
we apply statistical techniques to observations to arrive at quantifications of our risk exposures. For
instance, we have limited exposure to credit risk as all of our accounts receivable are converted into
cash within a short period of time, with the exception of the adviser loan payments where recoverability
is monitored closely. However, these methods may not comply with regulations or accurately quantify
our risk exposures, especially in situations that do not have historical precedent. If our policies and
procedures are not fully effective or if we are not always successful in capturing all risks to which we
are or may be exposed, we may suffer harm to our reputation or be subject to litigation or regulatory
actions that could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations or prospects.

**_Our accounting policies and methods are critical to how we report our financial condition and_**
**_results of operations. They require management to make estimates about matters that are often_**
**_uncertain._**

Accounting policies and methods are fundamental to how we record and report our financial condition
and results of operations. Management must exercise judgment in selecting and applying many of
these accounting policies and methods so that they comply with generally accepted accounting
practices in the United Kingdom. Our financial accounts carry an inherent reliance on management’s
judgment. We have identified certain accounting policies in the notes to the Financial Statements in
respect of which significant judgment is required in determining appropriate assumptions and
estimates when valuing assets, liabilities, commitments and contingencies. These are primarily related
to accounting for the accrual of performances fees, the fair value of our investments and the
recognition and useful life of intangibles. Areas requiring more complex judgments may shift over time
based on changes in accounting policies or changes in our business mix. There is a risk that the
judgments exercised by our management team are erroneous and this could lead to inaccuracies in
the reported financial position and performance of our business.

We have established detailed policies and control procedures that are intended to ensure that these
judgments and the associated assumptions and estimates are well informed and applied consistently
and to ensure that the process for changing methodologies occurs in an appropriate manner. However,
because of the uncertainty surrounding our judgments and the estimates pertaining to these matters,
we may be required to make changes in accounting estimates or restate prior period financial


-----

statements in the future, and any such changes or restatements could have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects.

**_We are subject to the risk of litigation, governmental or regulatory investigations and other_**
**_claims._**

From time to time, we are involved in various litigation matters and governmental or regulatory
investigations, prosecutions or similar matters arising out of our current or future business. Our
insurance or indemnities or amounts we have provisioned may not cover all claims that may be
asserted against us, and any claims asserted against us, regardless of merit or eventual outcome, may
harm our reputation. Furthermore, there is no guarantee that we will be successful in defending
ourselves in pending or future litigation or similar matters under various laws. Should the ultimate
judgments or settlements significantly exceed our insurance coverage or provisions, they could have
a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects.

**_Examinations and challenges by tax authorities, or changes in tax laws or regulations or the_**
**_application thereof, could materially and adversely affect our reputation, financial condition,_**
**_results of operations and prospects._**

Our tax returns are prepared in accordance with applicable tax legislation, regulations and prevailing
case law. Certain tax positions we take are based on industry practice, the advice of professional tax
advisers and inferences drawn from considering similarities between our facts and circumstances and
those considered in case law. These positions may relate to, among other things, tax compliance,
gross receipts, payroll, property and income and profit tax issues. We cannot be certain that the tax
authority of the United Kingdom (the “HMRC”) will be in agreement with our view. We are subject to
periodic tax audits and any challenges made by tax authorities to our application of tax rules may result
in adjustments to tax payable by us, for example, because of adjustments to the timing or amount of
taxable income or deductions. If any such challenges are made and are not resolved in our favour, they
could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or
prospects. Additionally, changes in tax laws practice relating to tax, or the application thereof, could
increase the amount of tax we must pay, which could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operations or prospects.

**_Our insurance coverage may not be adequate to cover all possible losses that we could suffer_**
**_and our insurance costs may increase._**

We seek to maintain comprehensive insurance coverage at commercially reasonable rates under
terms that we believe are appropriate. Although we carry professional indemnity and directors’ and
officers’ liability insurance, our insurance policies do not cover all types of losses and liabilities and are
subject to limits and excesses. There can be no assurances that our insurance will be sufficient to
cover the full extent of all losses or liabilities for which we are insured and we cannot guarantee that
we will be able to renew our current insurance policies on favourable terms, or at all. Certain insurance
coverage may not be available or may be prohibitively expensive in future periods. As our insurance
policies come up for renewal, we may need to assume higher deductibles or co-insurance liabilities or
pay higher premiums. This would increase our expenses and reduce our EBITDA, which could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects.

**_Our expenses are subject to significant fluctuations that could materially decrease our Net_**
**_Revenue and EBITDA._**

Our operating results vary with our cost of sales, which can fluctuate meaningfully based on many
factors, including:

- changes in expenses that are correlated to our AUM, such as distribution and servicing fees and
sub-manager fees;

- changes in expenses related to adviser fees;

- expenses, including salaries and benefits, incurred to retain and recruit appropriate staff;


-----

- expenses incurred in connection with our strategic plan to strengthen our long-term competitive
position;

- expenses incurred to maintain insurance plans, including professional indemnity insurance;

- expenses incurred in connection with regulatory requirements;

- future changes to legal and regulatory requirements and potential litigation;

- changes in the costs incurred for third-party vendors that perform certain administrative and
operating services; and

- disruptions of third-party services such as communications, power, and mutual fund transfer
agent, investment management, trading, and accounting systems.

Our operating results also depend on the level of our operating expenses, which can vary significantly
for many reasons, including:

- variations in the level of total compensation expense due to changes in, among other things,
bonuses, employee benefit costs due to regulatory or plan design changes, our employee count
and mix, competitive factors, market performance, and inflation;

- changes in the level of our advertising and promotion expenses, including the costs of expanding
investment advisory services to direct retail clients;

- expenses and capital costs incurred to maintain and enhance our administrative and operating
services infrastructure, such as technology assets, depreciation, amortisation, and research and
development;

- a future impairment of investments that is recognised in our consolidated balance sheet;

- a future impairment of goodwill that is recognised in our consolidated balance sheet; and

- unanticipated costs incurred to protect investor accounts and client goodwill.

Under our agreements with TPA, we charge the TPI Funds certain administrative fees and related
expenses based upon contracted terms. A failure to accurately estimate our underlying expense levels
or a requirement to incur expenses relating to the mutual funds that are not otherwise paid by the funds
could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or
prospects.

**_Price and earnings inflation could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial_**
**_condition, results of operations and prospects._**

Approximately two-thirds of our operating costs are staff related. For the year ended 31 December
2020, and for the nine-month period ended 30 September 2021, personnel costs (including national
insurance contributions, expenses for pensions and similar obligations as well as other employee
benefits) accounted for £9.9 million and £13.0 million, respectively. If we cannot control such costs or
pass them through to customers, our profitability may be impacted. In addition, significant increases
in inflation could impact our unit costs in other ways and potentially impact profitability and capital
position, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and prospects.

**_Our business, financial condition and results of operation may be adversely affected by the_**
**_COVID-19 pandemic._**

In March 2020, the World Health Organization declared the outbreak of a new infectious disease known
as COVID-19, caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (commonly known as
SARS-CoV-2), to be a global pandemic. Measures initially adopted by governments to contain the
spread of COVID-19, including travel bans, closure of businesses and workplaces, quarantine and
elective self-isolation, led to many economies effectively shutting down.


-----

The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic globally and in the United Kingdom has been severe,
notwithstanding material monetary policy support, government support measures and regulatory
intervention. Vaccines have been developed, however, and are currently being rolled out (albeit
unevenly) across countries, with high inoculation rates in the United Kingdom allowing for a substantial
easing of public health restrictions and a recovery in economic activity. However, the Delta variant, the
Omicron variant and other potential variants of the virus are ongoing concerns, while there is
uncertainty in respect of a range of matters, including the extent, duration and intensity of the financial
consequences and potential customer behaviour and societal implications. In particular, the increased
infectiousness of the Omicron variant is placing significant strains on the health care sectors of most
Western countries, including the United Kingdom. Such strains could put pressure on public finances
and jeopardise the recovery in economic activity. In addition, the effectiveness of the vaccines currently
available for periods beyond six months is in doubt, which may require governments to acquire more
vaccines and to launch further campaigns to inoculate their populations.

Global financial markets have been monitoring and reacting to the COVID-19 pandemic. The spread
of COVID-19 has created significant volatility, uncertainty and economic disruption to the global
economy and may impact our business, financial condition and results of operations. Since our
revenue is based on the market value and composition of our AUA and AUM, the ultimate impact on
global financial markets and our clients’ decisions related to this event could adversely affect our
revenue and operating results.

Furthermore, while we have in place robust and well-established business continuity plans that
address the potential impact to our employees and our facilities, and a comprehensive suite of
technologies which enable our employees to work remotely and conduct business, no assurance can
be given that the steps we have taken will continue to be effective or appropriate. Additionally, we must
effectively manage the ongoing risks of a remote workforce, ensure a safe working environment for
employees working onsite in our offices and adequately manage the post-pandemic transition from
remote to onsite or a hybrid working environment. In the event that our employees become
incapacitated by COVID-19, our business operations may be impacted, which could lead to
reputational and financial harm.

There can be no guarantee that any similar pandemics or outbreaks will not occur in the future or that
the effects of the current global pandemic will not deteriorate further. If such pandemics or outbreaks
occur in the future, they could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
results of operations or prospects.

**Risks Related to Regulation**

**_Our business is subject to comprehensive regulation in the United Kingdom, and we face risks_**
**_associated with compliance with these regulations._**

We are subject to comprehensive regulation in the United Kingdom. Regulatory agencies have broad
regulatory and administrative powers over many aspects of financial services businesses, which may
include governance, systems and controls requirements, conduct of business requirements (including
marketing and selling practices, advertising, customer documentation and service standards), intragroup transactions, product authorisation and governance, solvency, market conduct, liquidity, risk
concentration and permitted investments. Regulators are mainly concerned with market integrity,
financial stability and the protection of customers rather than with the interests of the shareholders or
creditors of financial services firms.

We are subject to regulation by the FCA. The FCA has broad powers, including the authority to grant,
vary the terms of or cancel a regulated firm’s authorisation, to investigate sales and marketing or
advice practices and to require the maintenance of adequate financial resources. The FCA has the
power to take a variety of investigative, disciplinary or enforcement actions, including customer
restitution, public censure, fines or sanctions and (in practice) to require compensation. The FCA may
make enquiries of the companies that they regulate regarding compliance matters and, like all UK


-----

regulated financial services firms, we face the risk that the FCA could find that we have failed to comply
with applicable regulations or have not commenced corrective action as required.

We are required to contribute to compensation schemes such as the UK Financial Services
Compensation Scheme (the “FSCS”) in respect of banks and other authorised financial services firms
that are not able to meet their obligations to customers. In the future, increased provisions in respect
of these costs are likely to be needed for firms required to make FSCS contributions, including us. The
ultimate cost to the industry, which will also include the cost of any compensation payments made by
the FSCS and, if needed, the cost of meeting any shortfall after recoveries on the borrowings entered
into by the FSCS, remains uncertain but may be substantial and may have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Furthermore, we are subject to unfair contract terms legislation, namely the Unfair Terms in Consumer
Contracts Regulations 1999 (the “UTCCRs”), which apply to business-to-consumer contracts entered
into prior to 1 October 2015, and the Consumer Rights Act 2015 (the “CRA 2015”), which replaced the
UTCCRs and applies to business-to-consumer contracts entered into with effect from 1 October 2015.
Under the UTCCRs and the CRA 2015, a consumer may challenge a standard term in a contract on
the basis that it is unfair and not binding on the consumer, although the remainder of the contract
continues to bind the parties if it is capable of continuing in existence without the unfair term.

The Consumer Protection from Unfair Trading Regulations 2008 (“CPR”), which implemented the EU
Unfair Commercial Practices Directive and remains part of domestic law in the United Kingdom by
virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 following the United Kingdom’s exit from the
European Union, prohibits certain practices that are deemed “unfair” within the terms of the CPR. Such
practices include misleading actions or omissions, aggressive sales tactics and failures to comply with
the requirements of professional diligence. Possible liabilities for misrepresentation or breach of
contract, in relation to an underlying credit agreement, may result in unrecoverable losses on accounts
to which such agreements apply. The UK Competition and Markets Authority may also take
enforcement action.

A determination that we have failed to comply with applicable regulation could have an adverse impact
on our reported results or on relations with our regulators and current and potential customers.
Regulatory action could result in the suspension or revocation of regulatory authorisations,
permissions or approvals, customer restitution, financial penalties, adverse publicity or reputational
harm, and an inability to continue to do business. This may also result in regulators subjecting us to
more intense scrutiny than would otherwise be the case, which in turn may result in higher compliance
costs, fines or other sanctions. Any of these matters could divert management’s attention from the dayto-day running of our business and may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, results of operations and prospects.

Changes in laws and regulations, as well as changes to the manner in which they are interpreted or
applied, or uncertainty over the application or interpretation of new or revised laws, could limit our
activities in the future or could significantly increase the cost of regulatory compliance. Our employees

-----

From time to time, regulators may launch a review of a particular product or industry. While we may
not be specifically targeted, these reviews could negatively impact our reputation or demand for our

key part of our recent flows, the FCA set out a package of measures in June 2020, promising in a press
release to “maintain its focus on firms providing transfer advice”. Some of these measures, such as a
ban on contingent charging, impacted our business, and if future reviews result in further new rules on
how advice should be provided to customers in this area, could lead to decreased demand for
