**Overview**

True Potential is a fully integrated technology-led wealth manager, serving investors and advisers
across the United Kingdom. Total AUA on our platform as at 30 September 2021 were approximately
£18.8 billion, of which £16.5 billion were AUM, which are assets invested in our range of exclusive
investment funds. With our strong heritage in the North East of England, we have expanded, since
inception in 2007, to become one of the fastest growing financial services businesses in the United
Kingdom, employing approximately 380 full-time staff and working with approximately 4,500 financial
advisers. We provide financial advice, investment platform services and portfolio investment solutions
to UK retail clients.

Our aim is to revolutionise the way wealth management is delivered. We believe that by using
technology to deliver financial services, we empower financial advisers and their clients to take control
of their futures. By providing what we call “hybrid advice”, blending technology with expert financial
advice, we are able to offer clients the access and support they need 24/7, while ensuring that they
have an adviser to speak to whenever needed.

We are privileged to work with approximately 17% of UK financial advisers and their clients through
either our fully integrated model or through our software offering, meaning we can have a real impact
on how UK households invest their money and save for retirement.

We grow through accelerated adviser recruitment and client and AUM acquisition. We offer certain
advisers seeking capital to fund their growth a loan of 2% of their total assets under management when
they become Wealth Management Partners. Our recruitment programmes have contributed to rapid
growth in our AUM from £6.0 billion as at 31 December 2018 to £16.5 billion in our own funds as at
30 September 2021.

True Potential is primarily made up of the following businesses:

- TPI, which provides our purpose-built, in-house proprietary wealth management platform and our
own exclusive investment fund range;

- TPWM, which is our wealth management advice proposition with 844 self-employed Wealth
Management Partners as well as our 40-member in-house Central Advice Team;

- TPAS, which provides technology, adviser support and compliance services to approximately 598
financial advice firms with approximately 3,600 individual advisers representing more than one
million clients; and

- TPA, which is the in-house ACD for the TPI Funds.


-----

As a fully integrated wealth manager participating in all parts of the value chain, we service all stages
of the wealth management process. We benefit from synergies across our ecosystem, with our
distribution, investment management and technology capabilities complementing each other. Our fully
integrated ecosystem enables and benefits from a multi-channel distribution model with multiple fee
streams. New investments pass through the True Potential platform and are invested in our ten True
Potential Portfolios, enabling us to capture economies across the value chain. Our multiple distribution
channels include (i) our wealth management advice channel TPWM, (ii) our adviser support services
channel TPAS and (iii) a D2C and auto-enrolment pension channel, where clients do not receive
financial advice. Assets that originated via these distribution channels then flow primarily to TPI, where
they are held and managed. Our multiple fee streams in TPI include (i) platform fees, (ii) fund fees and
(iii) performance fees, while TPWM also benefits from financial advice fees and TPAS also generates
revenue from service fees.

Our revenue has become increasingly diversified across channels, resulting in robust AUA and AUM
expansion, supported by a growing recruitment programme that has led to double-digit revenue
growth and margin expansion. From 31 December 2018 to 30 September 2021, AUA on the True
Potential platform increased by £11.1 billion, or 143.6%, and AUM invested in TPI Funds increased by
£10.6 billion, or 177.3%. Our Net Revenue for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021 was
£165.3 million, which was generated from gross revenue of £260.4 million, and our EBITDA was £122.6
million, representing an EBITDA Margin of 74.2% and an EBITDA CAGR of 67.8% from 31 December
2018 to 30 September 2021. Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021
was £160.0 million.

Gross Asset Inflows grew from £2.2 billion in 2018 to £4.2 billion in 2020 to £4.9 billion in the nine
months ended 30 September 2021. Over recent years, organic growth has been the “traditional” route
for Gross Asset Inflows through adviser and productivity growth and remains a strong underpin. The
majority of Gross Asset Inflows in 2018 and 2019 came from organic channels, most notably through
TPWM, which accounted for approximately 52% in 2018 and approximately 40% in 2019, and TPAS,
which represented approximately 43% in 2018 and 24% in 2019. In recent years, management has
been reinvesting cash flows into various recruitment initiatives, increasing the level of inorganic growth
given the market opportunity.

**Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition**

Our results of operations and financial condition are affected by a variety of factors, a number of which
are outside of our control. Set out below is a discussion of the most significant factors that have
affected our financial results during the periods under review and which we currently expect to affect
our financial results in the future. Factors other than those presented below could also have a
significant impact on our results of operations and financial condition in the future.

**_Levels of AUA and AUM_**

The most significant components of our revenue are the fees, including fund fees and platform fees,
that are charged as percentages of our AUA and AUM. Fund fees and platform fees represented 33.1%
and 22.2%, respectively, of our total revenue for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021.
Accordingly, the levels of our AUA and AUM are the main determinants of our fee revenue. As at
30 September 2021, we had AUA of £18.8 billion and AUM of £16.5 billion. For the twelve-month period
ended 30 September 2021, our Net Revenue was £165.3 million.

As further discussed below, our levels of AUA and AUM are driven by levels of inflows and outflows that
correlate with how many financial advisers and end clients we have during the relevant period. In
addition, investment market conditions impact our AUA and AUM levels, such as the economic
environment in the United Kingdom and internationally and our prior investment performance, as well
as structural factors, such as demographic trends, the accelerating adoption of financial technology
and regulatory tailwinds.

Advisers who have joined True Potential have proven to be productive, and this productivity has been

_Total Number of Clients and Client Retention_

As at 30 September 2021, we had approximately 1.2 million total end clients using our services. Our
overall end client retention rate is 97.6%, with strong client retention no matter if clients have been
transferred to True Potential with advisers hired under our client acquisition and adviser recruitment
programme (99.3%) or have been referred to True Potential by a Wealth Management Partner or a
TPAS firm (95.8%).

Our strong client retention corresponds to low Client AUA Churn. Our Client AUA Churn for each of the
years ended 31 December 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the nine-month period ended 30 September 2021
have remained below 10%, as shown in the chart below. The primary driver of Client AUA Churn has
been regular business where clients begin drawing down income, with transfers and closures
(i.e. clients withdrawing their funds in order to close their account) driving a lower percentage of Client
AUA Churn since 2019. In addition, because client funds are fully invested, a percentage of assets is
periodically sold in order to provide the funds to pay fees. Such amounts, which have not historically
been tracked as a component of Client AUA Churn, equalled 1.1% of average AUA for the twelve
months ended 30 September 2021.

management process. The proportion of Integrated Flows, calculated as TPI flows divided by total

period ended 30 September 2021, clearly demonstrates how the uniqueness of our business model
and how we capture economies across the value chain. As a result, the full integration of True
Potential’s business model allows us to offer clients significantly lower fees than our main competitors,
while maintaining strong profitability. See “Our Business—Competitive Strengths—Fully integrated

Overhead costs (including management bonus) increased from £28.6 million to £34.5 million at a
CAGR of 15.6% from 31 December 2018 to 30 September 2021, while Net Revenue increased at a
CAGR of 46.2% for the same period. Cost base of overhead costs (other than direct variable costs
deducted in Net Revenue) are largely fixed in nature, mainly relating to staff costs. Head office costs
are incurred at our headquarters in Newcastle and include, among other things, office rent,
maintenance of the building and the surrounding area, service costs, heating costs and building
insurance. Our overhead costs increased at a slower rate than Net Revenue, driving operating leverage
and an increase in our EBITDA Margin.

Recruitment costs are incurred by regional sales directors who acquire potential new wealth managers
to drive sales. From 31 December 2018 to 30 September 2021, the increase in the recruitment and
training costs for new advisers reflects higher recruitment of advisers and regional sales directors to
support the growth in our 2% and 8% propositions in our client acquisition and adviser recruiting
programme.

Sponsorship and marketing costs are incurred for online or paper-based marketing campaign
materials that are sent to clients and include marketing from firms such as Google to advertise our
services and grow our platform. Sponsorship and marketing costs were higher in 2018 following an
increased effort to attract additional D2C customers.

Staff costs related to the employees of the business include salaries, bonuses, national insurance,
recruitment, training and qualification costs. The increase in staff costs during this period is mainly due
to the growth in our full-time equivalent employees as a result of our business scaling.


-----

Technology costs relate to running our platform and standard IT costs that entail variable costs specific
for systems such as utilising the cloud, which is a pay-as-you-use service. The IT costs during this
period are mainly relating to outsourcing, platform running costs of SEI platform, which we transitioned
off in 2018, as well as software licenses.

Professional and regulatory costs include consultancy, insurance, legal, audit and CASS audit services
fees, as well as the FCA levy, which includes our contribution to the Financial Services Compensation
Scheme and the Financial Ombudsman Service. The increase in the professional and regulatory costs
from 2018 to 2021 are mainly driven by higher insurance costs and increase in FCA fees. Other costs
in our overhead costs are related to sundry costs of our business.

Other costs include insurance costs, including our professional indemnity insurance, public liability
insurance and employers’ liability policies, as well as miscellaneous costs related to items such as
telephone and telecommunications, subscriptions and licenses. Our costs are impacted by
depreciation, an accounting method used to allocate the cost of our tangible assets, such as fixtures,
fittings and computer equipment, over its useful life. Fixtures and fittings depreciate over five years,
while computer equipment depreciates over three years. Our costs are also impacted by amortisation,
which is calculated on a straight-line basis, primarily relates to the 2016 investment in True Potential by
FTV and the 20-year useful life on recruitment acquisitions.

_Economic Environment in the United Kingdom and Internationally_

The economic environment in the United Kingdom and internationally has affected, and will continue
to affect, our results of operations. Factors such as the strength and volatility of capital markets, interest
rates, inflation, consumer spending, business investment and exchange rates all affect the economic
environment, investor confidence and, ultimately, the volume and profitability of our business. Such
conditions impact the value of customer investment portfolios, which in turn impacts our results
because a significant portion of our revenue is derived from fees that are calculated as a percentage
of AUA or AUM. While a growing economy is likely to lead to higher levels of investment that increase
our AUA and AUM, an economic downturn characterised by lower corporate earnings, lower business
investment, higher unemployment, lower household income and lower consumer spending, may
adversely affect the demand for savings products. Further, customer sentiment regarding the future
prospects of debt and equity markets, exchange rates and inflation, and more generally of the
economy and investment markets, could impact customer behaviour and impact demand for our
investment products and services. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—Difficult
_macroeconomic conditions could lead to asset price declines or volatility which may adversely affect_
_the market value of our AUA and AUM, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our_
_business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects”._


-----

The investment performance of each of the True Potential Portfolio and the underlying TPI Funds is a
factor that could impact inflows and outflows into these products because advisers and end clients are
attracted to products with a consistent, strong record of investment performance. Investment
performance will therefore continue to affect our AUA and AUM and, in turn, will have an impact on our
revenue and financial results as our revenue is derived as a percentage of our AUA and AUM.

_Accelerating Adoption of Financial Technology_

Consumers of financial services products and services are becoming increasingly technologically
aware, which is driving them and their assets to flow to online platform businesses such as ours. Our
technology platform offers a broad array of services catering to the needs of both advisers and clients.
Some of the key client-facing features (including those specific to True Potential) include Digital Direct
Offer (allowing customers to transfer products to True Potential through an entirely digital journey),
impulseSave (allowing customers to top up their ISA or other savings product directly with no minimum
amount), policy transfer, secure messaging, bank integration and the personal finance modules. Our
technology platform as well as reporting and processing tools also have a comprehensive suite of
services tailored for our advisers to run a day-to-day business and support our customers.

From the outset, our founding partners believed that technology would play a pivotal role in the wealth
management industry and our vision 14 years ago was to be an agile, innovative, end-to-end, multichannel “wealthtech” via an integrated technology platform. Our technology platform is the core of the
firm. It is a fully integrated tech stack for advisers and clients that enables better user experience and
enhanced cross selling and was built and developed in-house by a focused multi-disciplinary team led
by our founding partners and shareholders.

_Government Policy, Legislation and Regulation_

We are subject to detailed and comprehensive regulation. Changes in government policy, legislation
or regulation applied to companies in the financial services industry in the United Kingdom have
historically impacted and may continue to impact our results of operations. For example, changes in


-----

taxation legislation applicable to our products have impacted our results of operations in the past and
further changes in taxation legislation could impact our results of operations in the future.

A number of regulatory changes and government initiatives in the United Kingdom (including Pension
Freedom, the increasing ISA subscription limits and the continued shift from defined benefit to defined
contribution pensions) have put the onus of long-term and retirement savings on individuals rather
than the government or employers. This has led consumers to seek out financial advice from providers
such as us. Financial advisers have also increasingly moved their clients’ assets to platforms such as
ours where financial advice, investment platform services and portfolio investment solutions are all
available from a single provider.

The growth of the investment platform market has led to increased focus from the FCA and ongoing
review of the market, which may create an increasingly stringent regulatory regime for us to comply
with. Our compliance with changes in regulation have to an extent, and may in the future, lead to
increased operating and administrative costs. Recent and ongoing regulatory reform initiatives include
MiFID II, the PRIIPs regulation, Solvency II, the IFPR and GDPR. These regulations could make it more
expensive for us to conduct our business, require us to make changes to our business model, require
us to satisfy increased capital requirements, necessitate time-consuming and costly implementation
measures, or subject us to greater regulatory scrutiny.

We are also subject to regulatory review, whether as part of an industry-wide review, a firm-specific
assessment or otherwise. The outcome of such reviews, though difficult to predict, could have an
impact on our results of operations. For example, possible outcomes include a requirement to
compensate customers for losses or certain costs they have incurred as a result of the products they
were sold or services they received or the initiation of regulatory enforcement action against us,
potentially including the imposition of a fine. Further, even if we are not named specifically, these
reviews could negatively impact our reputation or demand for our products.

A number of studies and thematic reviews have been initiated or undertaken by the UK regulators.
These include the FCA’s asset management review, the findings of which were published on 28 June
2017, and the Investment Platforms Market Study, the terms of reference for which were announced
on 17 July 2017.

We may also be affected by future changes in government in the United Kingdom, which may lead to
changes in government policy, legislation or regulatory interpretation applied to us and may ultimately
influence investor decisions, change the structure of the market and the products offered or increase
the costs of doing business. Changes in government could also introduce a range of anti-wealth
policies.

**_Product Mix and Distribution Channels_**

True Potential Group Limited is the holding company of the subsidiaries described below. Although
True Potential Group Limited does not generate turnover, its activity accounts for our head office costs.

Flows onto the platform are generated from TPWM (Wealth Management Partners and Central Advice
Team), TPAS and D2C distribution channels. TPWM is a restricted advice firm. Wealth Management
Partners are contracted to invest in TPI Funds and the Central Advice Team also manages client assets
held on the platform and in the funds. Through TPAS, we provide back-office software to independent
financial advisers who are then able to choose to use the platform and funds or third-party alternatives.
And finally, D2C is a small component of our inflows where customers come direct onto the platform
(without advice). Our key revenue streams come from the subsidiaries as described below:

- True Potential Investments – generates platform fees, investment management fees and
performance fees.

- True Potential Wealth Management – (i) Wealth Management Partners generate revenue in the
form of advice fees, 90% of which the adviser retains, while True Potential gains the remaining


-----

10%, and (ii) Central Advice Team advisers also generate revenue in the form of advice fees,
where TPWM retains 100% of the fees.

- True Potential Adviser Services – typically charge fees based on adviser turnover in exchange for
back-office services.

_True Potential Investments_

As at 30 September 2021, the True Potential platform had AUA of £18.8 billion, of which £16.5 billion
were AUM invested in exclusive TPI Funds and the remainder were in third-party funds. AUA growth
from £7.7 billion as at 31 December 2018 through 30 September 2021 represents a CAGR of 38.2%.
TPI Funds AUM have grown at a CAGR of 44.9% from £6.0 billion as at 31 December 2018 to £16.5
billion as at 30 September 2021. TPI Funds AUM have also delivered better economics for True
Potential assets than AUA invested in third-party funds, while also delivering savings to clients as client
charges for the most invested portfolio, the True Potential Balanced Portfolio, decreased from 82 basis
points in 2018 to 80 basis points in 2021, while the net fund margin for TPI Funds increased from 80
basis points in 2018 to 100 basis points in 2021.

TPI receives platform fees, fund fees and performance fees. In addition, investors paid an average of
75 basis points for their financial advice from Wealth Management Partners during the twelve-month
period ended 30 September 2021, approximately 10% of which was recorded as revenue for True
Potential. For the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021, investors paid approximately 40
basis points for access to the True Potential platform. True Potential records around 66 basis points of
gross revenue as fund fees, with approximately 18 basis points of the fund fee being passed along to
sub-advisers for the TPI Funds. True Potential's Growth Aligned Fund range includes a performance
fee that only becomes payable if the unit price of the fund is above the high watermark, which is
measured as the highest unit price at each previous 30 April.

TPI’s revenue can be broken down into distribution channels as set out below.

- The Wealth Management Partners distribution channel contributed £63.5 million, or 46.7%, of

performance fees paid by clients. The Net Revenue contribution of platform fees and fund fees for
the restricted adviser channel were £26 million and £28.7 million, respectively, for the twelvemonth period ended 30 September 2021. Performance fees earned from this channel during this
period amounted to £8.8 million.

_True Potential Wealth Management_

TPWM generates fees from both the Wealth Management Partners and the Central Advice Team
channels. These fees are made up of advice fees and the previously stated flows onto the platform
through these two distribution channels. Clients pay ongoing advice fees to their Wealth Management
Partners of around 56 basis points of the amount invested and one-off fees of around 64 basis points
of the amount invested, 90% of which is retained by the Wealth Management Partners and 10% is
recorded as Net Revenue for True Potential. Clients pay ongoing advice fees of 50 basis points of the
amount invested to the Central Advice Team, which is 100% retained by True Potential. For the twelvemonth period ended 30 September 2021, advice fees for Wealth Management Partners contributed
£7.4 million of Net Revenue and for Central Advice Team contributed £18.3 million of Net Revenue.

TPWM-advised AUM has experienced significant growth supported by a multi-pronged sales strategy.
AUM for Wealth Management Partners grew from £1.6 billion at the end of 2015 to £2.3 billion at the
end of 2016, £3.3 billion at the end of 2017 and £4.1 billion at the end of 2018. In 2019, the Central
Advice Team recruitment programme started, adding additional AUM from the Central Advice Team to
total AUM. TPWM-advised AUM grew to £6.1 billion at the end of 2019, made up of £1.3 billion from
the Central Advice Team and £4.8 billion from Wealth Management Partners. At the end of 2020, total
AUM for TPWM grew to £9.0 billion, including £2.8 billion from the Central Advice Team and £6.2 billion
from Wealth Management Partners. As at 30 September 2021 total AUM for TPWM was £13.0 billion,
with £4.5 billion from the Central Advice Team and £8.5 billion from self-employed Wealth Management
Partners. The gross profit margin for TPWM was 11%, 13% and 9% in 2015, 2016 and 2017,
respectively, before growing to 11%, 14% and 23% in 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively. TPWM gross
profit margin for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021 was 28%.

In order to obtain more financial advisers, increase sales and thus our overall AUA, we buy advisers’
portfolios, through our client acquisition programmes, which are bought out at 2% or 8% of their total
value. See “Business—Client Acquisition and Adviser Recruiting Programme”.

Financial advisers are recruited one by one, with each individual being subject to a detailed review
against our robust recruitment standards. This includes an assessment of their solvency and personal
financial history, complaints record, key performance indicators, references for the previous six years,
qualifications, continuing professional development and previous firms’ competency assessments. We
will only approve an individual where we are confident they have not previously caused any client
detriment and that they will not cause client detriment or reputational risk to TPWM.


-----

TPAS provides a full suite of technology-led modern and convenient support services to advisers.
Advisers are charged a fee of 4% of their turnover for these services. TPAS administration services
contributed revenue of £4.9 million for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021.

**_Capital Requirements and Liquidity Management_**

The Group consolidated statement of financial position at 31 December 2020 showed a net liability
position of £170.8 million (31 December 2019: £182.6 million), however, based on the directors’
assessment, there are sufficient cash resources and financing facilities available to meet ongoing
operational and capital requirements.

As at 30 September 2021, the Group’s net liability position was £156.8 million. This includes a total of
£36.2 million, across both current and non-current liabilities, that. The ability of the Group to meet this
liability was supported with the available financing facility of £20.1 million plus further cash resources
of £52.6 million.

Management closely monitors the Group’s cash flow and financial position throughout the year,
running daily forward-looking modelling, to ensure there are sufficient funds available to meet liabilities
as they fall due and sufficient headroom on requirements.

**_Turnover_**

Group turnover is made up of three main components. TPI turnover represents fees earned from
provision of the True Potential Wealth Management platform and the annual management charge in
respect of the TPI Funds. TPWM turnover represents advice fees earned from our restricted wealth
management advice proposition. TPAS turnover represents fees earned from the provision of
back-office services to financial advice firms.

_True Potential Investments_

The principal activity of TPI is that of provision of a wealth management platform and investment
management firm.

Turnover is generated from: (i) the platform fee charged to clients for the administration and provision
of technology services to the client; (ii) an annual management charge payable by the client for the
investment in the TPI Funds; and (iii) a performance fee payable on the True Potential Growth Aligned
Fund Range, which only becomes payable if the unit price of the fund is above the high watermark.
The high watermark is measured as the highest unit price at each previous 30 April.

_Performance Fee_

The performance fee is calculated as 10% of the fund unit price growth above the high watermark,
which is measured as the highest unit price at each previous 30 April. Any performance fee payable is
accrued at a fund level on a daily basis. The final fee for the fund year is calculated as at 30 April each
year. The effect of only accruing this fee when the fund provides returns above the high watermark is
to align our goals with the goals of our clients.

Following a strong performance and highly positive returns to investors in the funds during 2020, the
performance fee accrued within the funds as at 31 December 2020 was £9.4 million. The related
revenue has been recognised in the year on the basis that it is probable that future economic benefits
will flow to the entity, following calculation of the final fee for the fund year as at 30 April 2021. The
weighted average unit price at 31 December 2020 was 111.10 against a weighted average high
watermark of 100.67, giving headroom of 10.36% above the high watermark.

The performance fee accrues daily, and the fund unit price was measured against the high watermark
as at 30 April 2021. The performance fee of £20.2 million was paid in cash in May 2021. If at 30 April
the fund price had fallen below the high watermark, then no performance fee would have been payable
to TPI.

_True Potential Wealth Management_

The principal activity of TPWM is that of a Wealth Management Firm. Wealth management advice is
provided to the clients via either a self-employed Wealth Management Partner or by the Central Advice
Team. Fees are charged to clients on an initial advice and recurring advice basis, as set out in the
contracts with the clients.

_True Potential Adviser Services_

The principal activity of TPAS is that of provision of services to financial services distribution firms and
their clients. Services include our award-winning technology, adviser support and compliance. Fees
are charged to the firms as a percentage of firm turnover based on the level of service undertaken.


-----

_True Potential Administration_

The principal activity of TPA is that of provision of authorised corporate director services. The service
is provided only to TPI.

**_Cost of Sales_**

Three of the Group’s entities generate cost of sales.

_True Potential Investments_

The cost of sales within TPI represents the fees paid to the sub-fund managers appointed by TPI. There
is no cost of sale with regard to the platform fee as the technology has been built in-house.

_True Potential Wealth Management_

The cost of sales within TPWM represents the payments to Wealth Management Partners in respect to
the financial advice fees generated. TPWM retains a percentage of the advice fee, paying away the
majority to the Wealth Management Partner. There is no cost of sales related to the advice fees
generated from Central Advice Team fees.

_True Potential Administration_

The cost of sales within TPA comprises depositary fees (including the depositary custody safekeeping,
asset servicing and transaction fees and charges), fund administration fees and fund audit fees.

**_Administrative Expenses_**

Our administrative expenses are set out below.

**_Goodwill and Brand Amortisation_**

Goodwill and brand amortisation represent the excess of the fair value of the consideration given over
the fair value of the identifiable net assets acquired. Goodwill is eliminated by amortisation through the
profit and loss account over ten years on a straight-line basis, which is the presumed useful economic
life of goodwill under UK GAAP. Our goodwill and brand amortisation relates directly to the 2016
investment in True Potential by FTV.

**_Interest Payable and Similar Charges_**

Interest payable and similar charges consist of the interest accruing in the year on all financial liabilities
with an implicit or explicit return, calculated by applying the effective interest method, irrespective of
measurement at fair value (except for those that might have arisen from derivatives).

**_Tax on Profit_**

Tax on profit consists of the tax payable on the taxable profit, adjusted by the amount of the year
changes in the assets and liabilities arising from temporary differences and of any tax credit or tax loss
carry forwards.

**_Profit for the Period_**

Profit for the period consists of gross income less administrative expenses, goodwill and amortisation,
interest payable and similar charges and tax on profit.

_Turnover_

_TPI Turnover_

Total TPI revenue increased by £51.3 million, or 67.6%, from £75.9 million for the nine-month period
ended 30 September 2020 to £127.2 million for the nine-month period ended 30 September 2021. This
increase was mainly driven by an increase in AUA of £6.5 billion to £16.5 billion which in turn led to a
rise in platform fees, and investment management fees, the main drivers of TPI Turnover. £10.9 million
of TPI Turnover was due to the performance fee.

_TPWM Turnover_

TPWM turnover increased by £24.3 million, or 50.7%, from £47.9 million for the nine-month period
ended 30 September 2020, to £72.2 million for the nine-month period ended 30 September 2021. This
increase was mainly driven by an increase in Wealth Management Partners from 656 as at
31 December 2020 to 844 as at 30 September 2021, which coincided with a £4.9 billion, or 35%, rise
in AUA, from £13.9 billion as at 31 December 2020 to £18.8 billion as at 30 September 2021. This
increase in turn led to a rise in advice fees for our Wealth Management Partners and our Central Advice
Team. In addition, turnover from advisers in our recruitment programme more than doubled.

_TPAS Turnover_

TPAS turnover increased slightly by £0.1 million, from £3.6 million for the nine-month period ended
30 September 2020, to £3.7 million for the nine-month period ended 30 September 2021. This is
expected as this is part of the business strategy to maintain a stable fee rates through long-term
contracts with firms.

increase was mainly driven by the amount paid to TPWM advisers, which grew by £14.3 million.

**Financial Condition**

**_Capital Ratios_**

We are regulated by the FCA and The Pensions Regulator. Due to the regulatory regimes applicable
to our businesses, we are required to comply with certain liquidity standards and capital adequacy
requirements as outlined in the EU Capital Requirements Regulation No. 575/2013, as it forms part of
domestic law in the United Kingdom by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (“UK
**CRR”) and the United Kingdom implementation of associated EU Capital Requirements Directives.**
Further to the UK’s exit from the EU, as an “investment firm”, we are subject to the UK Investment
Prudential Regime (“IFPR”) from 1 January 2022.


-----

**_Calculation of Capital Requirements and Risk Weighted Assets_**

We calculate our capital requirements for credit and counterparty risk, market risk and operational risk
in accordance with Article 95 of the UK CRR and applicable regulations, as described below.

In accordance with the guidelines on common procedures and methodologies for the supervisory
review and evaluation process (SREP), the European Banking Authority tends to adopt a Pillar 1‐Plus
approach in assessing capital requirements under Pillar 2 when performing the supervisory review.
Under Pillar 1‐Plus the same risk categories covered at Pillar 2 and the total figure the Pillar 2a risk
amounts to can be no less than that at Pillar 1. If a Pillar 1 risk is assessed as being greater at Pillar 2,
then the amount in addition to Pillar 1 is added, at Pillar 2a, to the Pillar 1 minimum.

_TPI Credit and Counterparty Risk_

TPI income is derived primarily from management fees and platform fees. A negligible portion of
income is derived from invoiced services, generated by the investment management team; however,
credit risk is not material in regard to the income so derived.

TPI exposure to credit risk results from UK credit institutions with whom TPI places its corporate cash
balances and settlement of market transactions (the intercompany balance arrangements are
discussed in an earlier section, as a 100% risk weighted credit risk consideration). TPI continually
reviews both its corporate cash balances and client money counterparties with whom it is placed to
ensure sufficient capital strength of the bank and is a key control as part of our client money and asset
oversight with credit exposure information for credit institutions used for both corporate cash balances
and segregated client money bank accounts reported to the CASS Committee monthly, following
regular due diligence reports and credit rating assessments.

_Capital Requirement_

As an investment firm with limited authorisation to provide investment services, on an individual basis
and in accordance with Article 95 (2) of the UK CRR, TPI calculates total risk exposure as the “higher
of”:

- the risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit risk and dilution risk;

- the fixed overheads capital requirement;

- the base capital requirement of €125,000; or

- the cost for an orderly wind down.

TPI assessed the Pillar 1 capital requirement for the year ended 31 December 2020 as the higher value
of the risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit risk and dilution risk, at £15,916,225. TPI assessed
surplus capital at £118,742,029 and an overall CET1 Ratio and Capital Ratio of 67.68%.

**_Market Risk_**

The two main prevalent market risks are the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit.

The COVID-19 pandemic negatively impacted commercial operations for much of the United Kingdom,
with monthly GDP consistently lower than previous years. Alongside this, record amounts of volatility
were reported in 2020 with both dramatic increases and decreases in equity markets. Moreover, the
realities of Brexit are starting to surface, with the latest examples being the fuel crisis, labour shortages
and product price increases.

Going forward these risks are being assessed, monitored and managed closely, both from an
operational and a financial perspective. We are maintaining operational resilience by ensuring that all
customer-facing and support staff can work remotely, with further steps in place for those working in
our offices to ensure social distancing.

**_Interest Rate and Price Risk_**

We are exposed to interest rate risk on debt balances held. The Group mitigates this risk with an
interest rate cap against 40% of group borrowings at a LIBOR rate at 2.0%, in place to December 2022.
The directors believe that a low interest rate environment will persist and any rises in the future will be
gradual.

We manage exposure to price risk by completing detailed forecasting and through continuous
examination of both the trading marketplace and current economic climate.

**_Exchange Rate Risk_**

There is currently no exchange rate risk as we are solely UK-based.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

The Group is a highly cash generative business and retains sufficient cash balances to reduce
exposure to liquidity risk. Alongside this, to track the liquidity risk of the Group, constant monitoring
processes are performed including, but not limited to, daily checks of the leverage position and
production of detailed cash flow statements.

**_Operational Risk_**

Operational risk means the risk of loss resulting from inadequate or failed internal processes, people
and systems or from external events, and includes legal risk. TPI has a low-risk appetite for operational
risk and seeks to mitigate risks through the continued development of robust infrastructure and
adherence to documented processes and controls, and enhancements to automated controls as
opposed to a reliance on manual controls. The effectiveness of internal controls is reviewed on a
risk-based approach and as part of the compliance monitoring plan. The compliance monitoring plan


-----

is a working paper that reflects the company’s assessment of current and future exposure to regulatory
risk on a recurring basis.

As TPI is at the forefront of cutting-edge technology in the financial services markets, this puts us at
risk of cyber-crime. TPI manage this risk with robust information security policies, procedures controls
and monitoring. TPI has in place business a continuity and disaster recovery plan which aims to ensure
that in the event of severe business disruption, the firm can operate on an ongoing basis, with the
preservation or restoration of key business services under interim arrangements, and that any losses
are limited.

There are risks associated with client redemptions and a reduction in fees earned by TPI as a firm
remunerated on funds under management. Charges that our clients pay for advice would also be
affected by a reduction in fees, as this is commonly a percentage of the value of the funds under
management. All funds operate under clear mandates governed by the products & investment team,
covering market, counterparty and liquidity risk, with outcomes of this due diligence being reported to
senior management. All funds are valued daily which helps increase identification and transparency of
risk positions. Monthly reporting and stress testing serve to highlight any issues with fund performance
to senior management, and regular performance attribution analysis provides insight into the drivers
of profits and loss.

Our internal operational risk teams are split between incident management and risk control
self-assessment (“RCSA”) implementation. In order to mitigate incidents in the future, we use an
in-house system for recording and tracking incidents then utilise an MI suite for the purpose of trend
analysis. The RCSAs plot every process and details the operational risk faced by the business if an
aspect of that process fails.

These systems are combined where the RCSA identifies the risk so we can set action plans to resolve
the incident. The management process directly links in to show where controls are starting to fail and
risks are materialising, and then evaluates the potential financial and reputational impact of such
incidents. As a result, we can now quickly identify any emerging trends and look to resolve them in a
much more efficient and effective way before issues become more widespread or have much
further-reaching consequences.

**Critical Accounting Policies**

The preparation of the financial statements in conformity with UK GAAP requires management to make
estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of turnover, expenses, assets and
liabilities. The estimates and judgements are based on historical experience and contracted rates,
including expectation of future events that are believed to be reasonable.

The key estimates in preparing these financial statements are set out below.

**_Carrying Value of Intangibles_**

Intangible assets represent the value of the customer relationships purchased by the firm. In
calculating the value of the intangible asset to be capitalised, a conversion rate has been calculated
based on a historical average conversion observed on transactions completed by the year end date.
Conversion rates are adjusted to reflect updated actual experience at each reporting date and at the
date of completion of the purchase. Intangible asset balances are stated at cost less accumulated
amortisation, where management determine their best estimate of the expected future value of the
asset.

Intangible assets are reviewed annually for impairment by the company. The potential impairment is
calculated as the expected future cash flows less the carrying value of the intangible asset at the
reporting date. Management is comfortable with the carrying value of intangible assets supported by
the future benefits of the client relationship.


-----

**_Useful Economic Life_**

Intangible assets are amortised over their expected useful life. Future results are impacted by the
amortisation periods adopted, and potentially, may differ between expected and actual circumstances.

Management has considered the wider market and analysed the expected length of the client
relationship when determining the useful economic life.

**_Carrying Value of Investments_**

Investments values are reviewed annually for impairment by the company. The investment value is
calculated as the expected future cash flows.

**_Debtors Due after More than One Year_**

Debtors due after more than one year represent the value of loans advanced to new True Potential
Wealth Management advisers based on the value of assets transferred, recognised at transaction cost.
Management closely monitors the recoverability of these loans and consider the risk of default on
repayment to be very low. The loans are only advanced as the assets are transferred and management
has comfort over the value of asset received to support the loan payments. Robust compliance
monitoring of the adviser is in place to ensure that the advisers are fit and proper to continue to provide
advice and service to clients. Management will continue to monitor the recoverability of the loans
closely. Where the amount of debtors due after more than one year is so material in the context of the
total net current assets, it is disclosed on the face of the statement of financial position to prevent
misinterpretation.

**_Performance Fee_**

The performance fee is recognised on an accruals basis when it is probable that future economic
benefits will flow to the entity. The recognition of the performance fee is subject to management’s
comfort around:

- the length of time to the fund year end;

- significant growth over the high-water mark; and

- an assessment of the equity and capital markets as well as the wider economy.

**Overall UK Wealth Market**

**_Overview_**

The United Kingdom has a potential addressable wealth market of £2.5 trillion (Source: Hardman & Co,
Platform Potential, May 2020), and is the fifth largest wealth market globally. The UK advised wealth
segment stands at £500 billion (Source: The Lang Cat), of which we hold approximately a 4% market
share (based on AUA of £18.8 billion as at 30 September 2021), which demonstrates the significant
headroom for us to continue growing our business. We have a market share under 0.5% of the current
UK D2C market of £165 billion (True Potential D2C AUM was £0.6 billion as at 30 September 2021),
and work with approximately 17% market share of UK advisers (based on approximately 27,000
financial advisers in the UK). (Source: FCA)

The wealth market in the United Kingdom can be sub-divided into four client segments (Source:
GlobalData’s Retail Investments Analytics, April 2021):

- Our retail client segment includes individuals with less than £100,000 investable assets. Although
this segment accounts for the vast majority (88%) of the adult population, the retail segment only
controls 29% of the wealth, which is primarily invested in pensions and ISAs and is therefore often
advised directly by the connected primary retail bank.

- The mass affluent segment covers 8% of the population, those within the £100,000 to £250,000
wealth band, and holds 20% of the wealth. Constituents of the mass affluent segment also invest
in ISAs and pensions, as well as unwrapped products, which are also quite standardised
products that require less complex advice.

- A smaller 3% of the population make up the affluent client segment, defined as individuals with
£250,000 to £1 million of investable assets, which holds 21% of the wealth. They also require
relatively standardised advice given the nature of their balanced investments across pensions,
ISAs and liquid assets.

- Finally, although the high net worth and ultra-high net worth categories account for less than 1%
of the population, they hold the largest share of wealth at 30%. These individuals focus on
equities, fixed income, cash and alternative investments, and allocate a lower proportion of their
wealth to pensions and ISAs, hence requiring bespoke advice through private banks or wealth
managers due to the complexity of these products.

In 2021, an estimated 46 million individuals made up the retail segment in which there is a substantial
level of auto-enrolment to ensure that savings and retirement needs are met. The mass affluent


-----

segment remains very fragmented, with approximately four million individuals who are serviced by
wealth managers, platforms and traditional life insurers. Finally, approximately 300,000 high net worth
and ultra-high net worth individuals, who have over £1 million in liquid assets, are generally served by
global private banks in the United Kingdom (Source: GlobalData’s Retail Investments Analytics, April
2021).

Wealth managers provide advice, platforms, investment management and wealth solutions. Some
firms target a specific segment of this value chain, while some firms pursue an integrated model with
provision of services across all aspects of the value chain. A broad categorisation of wealth managers
is listed below:

- Independent financial advice and advice-focused wealth managers primarily provide financial
advice and can be found in a range of different sizes from small independent financial advice firms
with a single adviser to larger network firms with 50+ advisers. These firms mainly focus on the
mass affluent and affluent client segments. Examples include Openwork, AFH Wealth
Management and Ascot Lloyd.

- Platforms provide an online service for financial advisers to manage their client’s investment
portfolios. The platforms are often based on a proprietary technology and offer a wide range of
portfolio solutions. Examples of these are Integrafin and AJ Bell.

- Discretionary wealth managers provide investment management services through which
investment decisions are made on the clients’ behalf. Through the provision of advice, platforms,
investment management and wealth solutions, they offer a broader service proposition and are
product and brokerage led. These firms focus on affluent and high net worth client segments.
Some examples are Brewin Dolphin, Investec, Rathbones and Tilney Smith & Williamson.

- Integrated wealth managers provide restricted advice, platform and investment management
thereby covering the entire value chain. Integrated managers typically originate clients and assets
under management by one of various channels. For example, St. James’s Place and Quilter focus
on originating assets under management by adding restricted advisers, which contrasts with
multi-channel integrated wealth managers such as True Potential, whose integrated business
model captures flows through multiple distribution channels: Wealth Management Partners,
Central Advice Team, TPAS and D2C. The flows sourced through these diverse channels are held
on the platform, which also houses the investment funds, hence allowing the wealth manager to
generate revenue across the whole value chain.

- D2C/Robo are self-directed digital platforms for do-it-yourself investing where no advice or
investment management service is provided, thus selling directly to the end client. Some
examples are Hargreaves Lansdown, AJ Bell, Interactive Investor and Wealthify.


-----

True Potential's core market segments of D2C/Robo and financial advisers and networks are the
fastest-growing segments in the UK wealth management market. UK wealth management growth by
