**_Market Trends_**

We expect the UK wealth market to continue to see growth and an increased demand for financial
advice as a result of several structural trends impacting the wealth management sector which have
been primarily driven by regulatory changes.

_Favourable Macro, Structural and Demographic Trends_

Wealth market flows (i.e. the net conversion of household deposit balances into financial assets) are
expected to grow driven by a long-term increase in the saver population segment (people from 30 to
60 years old). Moreover, the average life expectancy in the United Kingdom grew from 71 years in 1960
to 81 years in 2019 (Source: World Development Indicators) and the percentage of UK residents above
the age of 65 grew from 16% in 1999 to 20% in 2019 and is projected to reach 24% by 2039 (Source:
Office for National Statistics, January 2021). These factors have increased the saving requirements of
UK households.

We have surveyed over 50,000 people about the savings gap since 2013. The results show that only
a minority of savers will have enough funds to reach their financial goals. Our polling shows that people
expect they will need £23,000 a year in retirement to live comfortably. However, based on their actual
savings behaviour, UK citizens are on course to receive an income of just £6,000 per year from their
retirement fund. That leaves a savings gap of £17,000 every year. With such a significant shortfall, it is
clear that the UK needs to change the way it approaches its finances. We expect that this trend may
increase customers’ willingness to use wealth management products and rely on financial advice.

Furthermore, the ongoing shift from “defined benefit” to “defined contribution” pension plans is
projected to increase flows to the wealth management market. Defined benefit pension schemes are
considered traditional pension plans through which a specified payment amount is provided to
retirement. On the other hand, defined contribution schemes allow employees and employers
to contribute and invest funds at their discretion to save for retirement over time, allowing employers
to match the contributions that employees choose to allocate. The transition from defined benefit plans
to defined contribution plans over recent decades has shifted the responsibility of investing and saving
onto the client, rather than the employer, which has contributed to an increased demand for financial
advice. Additionally, following the introduction of the Pension Freedom legislative change in April 2015


-----

through the Pension Schemes Act 2015, those over the age of 55 have unrestricted access to their
pensions. As a result, savers are no longer required to purchase an annuity with their retirement fund
but instead have a variety of options as to how they can access their retirement income, hence also
presenting customers with an increased level of responsibility.

Finally, the attention to investing and saving was strengthened by the COVID-19 pandemic, which
increased families’ need to be financially stable. Household savings increased as a drop in household
spending was experienced, while household incomes remained reasonably stable as a result of
government policy, including the “Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme”. Analysis from the Bank of
England in November 2020 suggested that the accumulation of savings was particularly observed
among wealthier and less financially distressed households. Therefore, the pandemic spurred
long-term trends and urged many of these savers to invest for the first time in their lives. This
subsequently entailed an acceleration in the trend for increased on-demand advice.

_Government Policy Initiatives_

The growing demand for wealth management products and financial advice has also been driven by
government policies and regulatory changes, among which are the pension reforms, the tax relief on
private pension contributions under certain conditions, particularly the Pension Freedom legislative
change in 2015. The latter legislation allows clients to flexibly obtain their defined contribution pension
pots when they are 55 years old and use the funds to select from a broad set of investment
opportunities and retirement income products.

The government has also continued to adapt to consumers’ needs and the macro environment. The
introduction of Lifetime ISAs is a good example. Despite the fact that ISAs are a settled piece of the UK
savings landscape since their introduction in 1999, the government has continued to expand their
offering. In 2017, a new form of ISA named “Lifetime ISA” was created to help individuals get on to the
property ladder or save for retirement, where the Government applies a bonus of 25% to any money
deposited.

_Ongoing Regulatory Focus_

Regulators strengthened their approach to financial services regulation after the financial crisis of
2007-2008.

In the United Kingdom, the FCA aimed specifically at granting good customer outcomes by
introducing the RDR in 2013. MiFID II was introduced on 3 January 2018 to implement changes in
different areas of financial markets with a particular attention to conflicts of interest. Increased
disclosure requirements regarding costs and charges were introduced with MiFID II providing more
clarity to end clients. Finally, several market studies and thematic reviews have been carried out by the
FCA to assess the wealth asset management industry in the United Kingdom with the aim of improving
the transparency of customer’s fees and promoting the fair treatment of clients.

_Changing Customer Behaviour and Preferences_

Customer behaviour and preferences have experienced a shift over the last few years as digitalisation
has increased the need for ease of access and interaction via online or digital interfaces, for example,
websites and most recently, mobile applications. In the United Kingdom, the FinTech adoption rate,
which is defined as the percentage of consumers using technology to manage their finances, reached
86% in 2021, having been only 14% in 2015 (Source: Plaid). Those born after 1980, referred to as
‘millennials’, particularly display this trend due to their differing preferences compared to previous
generations. Given the expected wealth transfer to millennials of approximately £920 billion from those
aged over 55 to younger generations, they are becoming an increasingly prominent segment (Source:
Capital Economics, St. James’s Place). The COVID-19 pandemic led to an acceleration of this preexisting trend for increased on-demand advice. As a consequence, the increased focus on digital has
also brought to light the importance of cybersecurity and data protection, which is an increased area
of focus for the vast majority of companies.


-----

**UK Advice Market**

**_Overview_**

In the United Kingdom, the number of firms providing financial advice contracted slightly from 5,218 in
2016 to 5,137 in 2020. The number of advisers, however, grew at a CAGR of approximately 2%
between 2016 and 2020, standing at 27,501 at the end of 2020 (Source: FCA).

Financial advisers solely focus on providing financial advice and recommendations in accordance with
their client’s risk appetite and financial objectives, and hence do not have a mandate to buy, sell or
execute investment decisions on a discretionary basis. Financial advisers provide planning and advice
services that include wealth and investments, retirement, tax, estate and inheritance. Certain mortgage
and protection advisers in the United Kingdom also provide specialised advice on mortgage
applications and life insurance products. Financial advisers are increasingly acting as a “one-stopshop” by providing a range of services from portfolio management to insurance products.

As described by the FCA, there are two different types of financial advisers — independent and
restricted. Independent financial advisers provide unrestricted advice to recommend a wide range of
retail investment products in order to meet the client’s needs and financial objectives. On the other
hand, restricted advisers are limited to a specific selection of products or products from a narrow
selection of providers. Regulations are more stringent in the case of restricted advice and require the
adviser or firm to clearly explain to the customer the nature of the restriction of the advice. Restricted
advisers and firms cannot describe the advice they offer as “independent”. According to Platforum,
there continues to be a slight shift towards restricted advice as the proportion of restricted advisers has
increased from 34% in 2015 to 38% in 2019.

Furthermore, the introduction of the RDR in 2013 introduced the need for fee charges, usually as a
percentage of assets under advice, in exchange for advice as opposed to through commissions.
Before the implementation of RDR, in 2012, net commission income comprised 84% of total advice
income from retail investments in the United Kingdom, whereas only 11% was fee income (Source:
APFA). Following RDR, the customer model shifted entirely. In 2019, the proportion of net commission
income significantly decreased to 16% of total advice revenue in the United Kingdom, but fee income
rose to 82% (Source: Platforum, FCA Retail Intermediary Market 2019). RDR served to ensure greater
transparency in the investment industry and to increase the understanding of costs associated with
advice.

**_Competitive Landscape_**

The financial advice market is served by an intersection of wealth management firms. A small number
of integrated wealth managers dominate the UK advice sector: namely St. James’s Place, Quilter and
Tilney Smith & Williamson (Source: Financial Times), who all offer expert financial planning and advice
services. St. James’s Place services a broad spectrum of individuals (mass affluent, to affluent and
some high net worth) in the United Kingdom with restricted financial advisers, whilst Tilney Smith &
Williamson are available to private clients, their business interests and professionals, and Quilter
particularly caters to the affluent client segment but also serves high net worth individuals. Hargreaves
Lansdown also entered the advice market more recently, with 61 financial advisers spread across the
United Kingdom, as well as offering telephone advice.

On the other hand, there are specialised companies offering competing products with different value
propositions. For instance, Schroders Personal Wealth provides a bank-led offering solely focused on
the advice sub-market, through a partnership between Schroders and Lloyds Banking Group. The joint
venture seeks to grant more customers with access to financial and investment expertise and is
available to those with at least £100,000 in sole annual income, or £100,000 spread across sole or joint
savings, investments and personal pensions.

We also see smaller Independent Financial Adviser firms, representing the long tail of a fragmented
market.


-----

As at December 2020, the total number of financial advice firms in the United Kingdom stood at 5,137,
with 27,501 financial advisers. (Source: FCA). In 2018, these figures stood at 5,218 financial advice
firms and 25,611 financial advisers (Source: Platforum UK Financial Advisers, November 2020).
Despite the observable consolidation, the UK advice market continues to be highly fragmented, and in
2020 there were only 48 financial advice firms with over 50 financial advisers (Source: FCA) and only
two firms with more than 1,000 advisers (Source: Financial Times).

**_Market Trends_**

_Increasing Need for Financial Advice_

The last decade has brought increased responsibility for UK citizens regarding their long-term and
retirement savings. As detailed above, this shift has been exacerbated by (i) the demographic curve
transitioning to an ageing population and (ii) regulatory trends shifting the burden of investing and
saving to the consumer. By observing the number of advisers in the industry and the number of clients
receiving ongoing advice, it can be noted that the number of clients per adviser has steadily increased
over recent years, from 86 in 2016 to 106 in 2019 (Source: Platforum UK Financial Advisers, November
2020 FCA, The Retail Intermediary Market 2019, July 2020). This again highlights the imbalance
between the supply and demand of financial advice.

_Ageing Adviser Population_

The average age of independent financial advisers in the United Kingdom is 58 with one in five advisers
planning to retire in the next five years (Source: The Private Office, 2020). Moreover, some advisers are
qualified individuals who are not allowed to advise retail customers. In this situation, quality advice is
a scarce resource. Given the increasing demand for financial advice yet the slower increase in adviser
supply, an exacerbated gap between supply and demand may be observed in coming years.

_Impacts of RDR and Other Regulatory Changes to the Market for Financial Advice_

The implementation of RDR resulted in platforms only receiving remuneration through the fees paid by
investors instead of earning a commission fee from the sale of recommended products. In addition,
this led to far more transparency regarding the services offered by the adviser, the fund manager and
the investment platform, and what each respective party receives for its services. A further
consequence of the RDR was the stricter definition of independent and restricted advisers, causing
more advisers to be identified as restricted rather than independent.

The introduction of RDR led to a greater number of consumers being unable to access or afford
financial advice, therefore leading to an expansion of the possible D2C investment market. Moreover,
the regulatory cost of providing advice to consumers has risen, which has resulted in numerous
advisers moving funds to adviser platforms that have all the features to be RDR compliant.
Consolidation in the market has also been a consequence of the higher overhead and regulatory
costs.

_Focus on Suitability and Disclosure_

The FCA puts a lot of attention on customers’ fair outcomes and on the suitability of advice provided
to customers through COBS.

COBS 6.1A contains rules on adviser charging and remuneration that apply to firms making personal
recommendations to retail clients in relation to retail investment products and certain other products in
the United Kingdom. In particular, a firm must only be remunerated for a personal recommendation
and any other related services by adviser charges, and must not solicit or accept any other
commissions, remuneration or benefit of any kind in connection with the firm’s business of advising,
regardless of whether it intends to refund the payments or pass the benefits on to the retail client. An
appropriate charging structure for calculating the adviser charge must be used.

COBS 6.2B contains rules on describing advice services that apply to firms providing investment
advice to retail clients in the United Kingdom in relation to financial instruments, structured deposits or


-----

other retail investment products or basic advice to retail clients in the United Kingdom (as well as to
firms providing investment advice in the course of MiFID business in relation to financial instruments
and structured deposits, since COBS 6.2B also implements aspects of MiFID II). In particular, firms
holding themselves out as providing independent advice must assess a sufficient and diverse range of
relevant products available on the market. A firm must also disclose to a client whether its advice will
be independent advice or restricted advice, whether the advice will be based on a broad or more
restricted analysis of different types of relevant products and whether the range will be limited to
relevant products issued or provided by entities having close links or relationships with the firm.

_Increasing Penetration of Technology_

There is increasing evidence that advisers are embracing technology to improve their efficiency.
Advisers are looking at back-office systems, automated client communications to improve interactions
and more purpose-built suitability. Some of this has been prompted by regulation – specifically MiFID
II – and the additional constraints that this has placed on advisers. The COVID-19 pandemic has also
acted as a catalyst as advisers have had to do more remotely.

**UK Retail Platform Market**

**_Overview_**

As defined by the FCA, an investment platform arranges, safeguards and administers investments on
behalf of consumers and provides access to retail investment products from several different providers,
and is therefore an entity between funds and investors. As a popular means for financial planning, retail
platforms provide customers and financial advisers an interface through which they are able to view,
manage and administer investments online. Customers are able to use platforms in order to access
information and tools that inform them in making investment decisions. As such, with regards to
customers, platforms generally offer access to online valuations and financial information, they
facilitate the consolidation of investment holdings and provide tax efficient products, customer services
and performance tracking. On the other hand, platforms offer advisers back office and technical
support, aggregate customer relationships in a single interface and reporting services.

Platforms increasingly form a central part of the retail distribution landscape and have steadily grown
as a sector over the last decade, capturing a substantial share of UK retail savings and pension flows.
The total UK platform market has recorded a year-on-year growth of 9% from £546 billion of assets
under administration as at 31 December 2019, to £594 billion as at 31 December 2020 (Source:
Platforum: UK Adviser Platforms Market Overview, March 2021). The COVID-19 pandemic negatively
impacted financial advisers in 2020 and accordingly, platforms experienced a downturn in new
business during the second and third quarters of 2020, a period that would have otherwise
experienced much stronger flows (Source: Platforum: UK Adviser Platforms Market Overview, March
2021).

Platforms can be extremely valuable due to the exposure to markets granted through the provision of
access to investment products. The platform market can be sub-divided into three segments (i) the
retail advised platforms that play an intermediary role between financial advisers and customers,
(ii) the corporate and institutional platforms that are mainly used by discretionary fund managers,
employee benefit consultants and workplace pension providers and (iii) D2C platforms allow
customers to directly invest in stocks, bonds, mutual funds and other investment products on their own
account. Each of these segments has grown over the last few years. Within the retail advised segment,
the open market channel and the advised channel provide two different sources of fund flows. The
open market channel allows third-party independent financial advisers to direct flows onto the platform,
while the advised channel has requests for proposals linked to the platform provider direct flows.

Out of the three sub-segments, the most relevant when considering True Potential is the retail advised
segment. This segment had £496 billion of assets under administration as at 31 December 2020, which
represents 63% of total assets under administration, also Gross Asset Inflows of £59 billion,
representing approximately 46% of total Gross Asset Inflows. Secondly, the corporate and institutional


-----

market segment had £123 billion of assets under administration, 16% of total assets under
administration as at 31 December 2020 and with £42 billion of Gross Asset Inflows, which translates to
33% of total Gross Asset Inflows. Finally, D2C had £165 billion of assets under administration, 21% of
total assets under administration, and £26 billion of Gross Asset Inflows for 2020, 21% of total Gross
Asset Inflows (Source: Fundscape Platform Report, Q4 2020).

In the United Kingdom, retail platforms can be divided into the “wrappers” or the “non-wrapped” subsegments. ISAs, personal pension plans, such as flexible drawdown and Self-Invested Personal
Pensions and investment bonds are all considered tax-efficient “wrappers”. Non-wrapped products, in
contrast, include general investment accounts, which are most commonly used by customers once
their tax-free ISA allowance has been utilised. Self-Invested Personal Pensions were the largest
proportion of Gross Asset Inflows on platforms in 2020, accounting for 45% of assets under
administration. Non-wrapped products were 25%, ISAs were 24% and defined contribution pensions
were 6% (Source: Fundscape Platform Report, Q4 2020). 92% of the True Potential offerings are
wrapped.

**_Competitive Landscape_**

The UK retail platform market is comprised of both integrated incumbents as well as those who are
focused exclusively on the platform sub-market. The largest retail advised platforms are Abrdn, Quilter
and Aegon with £72 billion, £69 billion and £55 billion of assets under administration, respectively. The
next six largest platforms have between £25 billion and £50 billion assets under administration (Source:
Fundscape Q2 2021). Out of ten largest platforms, the tenth being True Potential, only half have their
own advisers (Abrdn, Quilter, Fidelity, Aviva and True Potential); the others rely on independent
financial advisers.

The largest companies solely focused on the retail platform market are Aegon, Transact and Integrafin,
who all offer technology, support, services and investments to their clients. Aegon, Transact and
Integrafin have £55 billion, £50 billion and over £40 billion assets under administration, respectively
(Source: Fundscape Q2 2021). On the other hand, Hargreaves Lansdown and AJ Bell, who are
specialised in this part of the value chain, offer D2C platforms with technology, customer services,
stocks, ISAs, pension solutions and investment solutions. In addition to these specialised providers,
Rathbones also launched its MyRathbones platform in July 2020.

Conversely, Abrdn, Aviva, Fidelity, Quilter, Hargreaves Lansdown and True Potential are examples of
integrated wealth managers that also offer a platform to their clients. These platforms have a wide
offering ranging from tailored services and technology to portfolios, investment solutions, financial
planning, financial advice, ISAs and pension solutions. In 2020, M&G entered the platform market
when M&G Wealth acquired the platform Ascentric, bringing it together with their in-house adviser arm
(Prudential Financial Planning) and network (The Advice Partnership).

**_Market Trends_**

_Platforms Capturing Majority of Retail Flows_

As interfaces that provide a tax-efficient way of holding investments with access to a wide fund range,
UK Platforms have been a key way for UK investors to access investment products every year for the
past decade and provided the majority of access for UK investors in 2020 with a net £16.3 billion inflow
(The Investment Association, September 2021). This reflects a trend in the market centred around
customers who are granted a greater degree of flexibility and are able to consolidate maturing
investments from more traditional pensions or savings products. In 2015, the Pension Freedom
legislation gave those over 55 years of age increased flexibility around when and how they are able to
monetise their defined contribution pension savings. Subsequently, pension savers were no longer
required to purchase an annuity for retirement, but instead had the flexibility to withdraw pension
savings. These reforms also led to increased decumulation product offerings that are available on UK
retail platforms in order to convert pension savings to retirement income. The transition over the past
few decades has seen a shift from traditional defined-benefit plan to the more contemporary defined
contribution plan, contributing to the growing fund flows onto platforms.


-----

_Differentiated Competitive Strategies_

As the sector continues to face substantial competition on pricing, leading to significant margin
pressure, some companies have tried to capture market share by offering a more comprehensive
product offering, or by enhancing their platform with other features. Value-added features that address
advisers’ and clients’ needs can represent a source of competitive advantage. For instance, some
platforms, alongside their standard proposition, also offer further technology-enabled services that
improve efficiency and client engagement, such as integrated technology that coordinates with clients
and head office to book appointments or access live chat. In the case of integrated players, these
additional features also help them secure flows across their entire value chain into multi-asset
solutions.

_Re-platforming_

The continuous introduction of new products, as well as the numerous changes in regulation, have led
various platforms to undertake various technology upgrades, also named replatforming. While some
replatforming exercises have been successful, others have not; for instance, in recent years, Aegon,
Ascentric and Aviva were all hit by glitches when moving to new software, resulting in issues with client
reports and logging on to the platforms. Despite the inherent operational risk of these upgrades, they
are becoming customary given the need to match the requirements and requests of clients and
advisers.

_Consolidation_

There are currently over 20 retail platforms in the United Kingdom with different levels of scale in terms
of assets under administration. A growing trend of consolidation prevails in the platform sector. Recent
transactions include AXA UK selling its Elevate platform to Standard Life, Aegon acquiring the Cofunds
platform from Legal & General and Lloyds Banking Group acquiring Zurich’s workplace pensions
intermediary platform. Cost efficiency and overall benefits of scale remain the primary drivers of
consolidation. Market commentators, including Calastone, believe there will likely be further
consolidation in the years ahead as a response to competitive dynamics and continued regulatory
burdens.

_FCA Investment Platforms Market Study_

In 2017, the FCA launched a market study that delved into the retail investment platforms market in the
United Kingdom following the increasing regulatory pressures across the wealth management value
chain. The report set out to analyse the impact of the platforms industry on competition in the United
Kingdom, and to assess whether the incumbents were working in the interests of investors. In their
2018 interim report, the FCA found the market to be functioning well for both advised and non-advised
consumers, with a high level of customer satisfaction. Those who pay more for platform services
generally have greater functionality. The concern for competition was reiterated, specifically including
the following points:

- Switching between platforms is quite challenging, so those who would benefit from doing so
suffer.

- Shopping around is also difficult and there are consumers who need to be able to find a
lower-cost platform.

- Consumers who hold large cash balances on D2C platforms may not be aware of the investment
returns, interest lost or charges paid they are overlooking.

- There is a lack of transparency and clarity surrounding the risks and expected returns that
consumers face using model portfolios.

- “Orphan clients” are those who were previously advised and no longer have a relationship with a
financial adviser and face the issue of higher charges and lower service.


-----

Rules introduced under MiFID II were believed to help in tackling the above concerns but additional
measures may be required to strengthen and drive competition. In their 2019 Final Report, the FCA
finalised their proposed solutions to ensure that both consumers and advisers are able to shop around
and switch with ease, at a low cost, when an alternative provider is better suited to their needs. Upon
assessment, the FCA proposed that exit fees be restricted through a cap or a ban, as well as
introducing rules for facilitating the switch of consumers’ investments between platforms without the
need for a cash out. The FCA will subsequently continue to monitor the industry to ensure progress
and potentially intervene further if necessary.

**Investment Solutions**

In a discretionary fund management (“DFM”) mandate, all investment and portfolio asset allocation
decisions are under the full responsibility of an investment manager who is completely authorised by
the client and manages the portfolio according to the client’s preferences.

DFM usually offers two portfolios:

- Managed Portfolio Service: designed to address the affluent market, these products are managed
by the investment manager and are risk-based model portfolios,

- Bespoke Discretionary portfolios: designed for high net worth clients, these portfolios are
specifically tailored and unique for each different client.

The distribution channel for DFM usually includes direct sales to customers or a financial adviser
marketing the products. However, recently DFM products are available also through platforms.

**_Competitive Landscape_**

The UK DFM sub-market is composed of companies that specialise in this segment as well as
integrated wealth managers. Regarding the wealth managers that solely focus on providing DFM in the
United Kingdom, the three largest are Brewin Dolphin with £50 billion assets under management (as
at 30 September 2021), Rathbones with £48 billion assets under management (as at 30 June 2021),
and Investec Wealth & Investment with £45 billion assets under management (as at 30 September
2021). Alongside DFM, Rathbones and Brewin Dolphin provide investment and wealth management
services, including financial planning, ISAs and multi-asset funds. Furthermore, Investec Wealth &
Investment offers a bespoke discretionary managed investment service.

When considering the integrated wealth managers who also offer investment solutions to their clients,
the leading companies are Tilney Smith & Williamson, Quilter, St James’s Place and True Potential.
These companies give clients access to discretionary portfolios, bespoke services and investment
management solutions, in addition to financial advice and direct access to equities, ISAs and pension
solutions. Quilter provides investment solutions through Quilter Cheviot and Quilter Investors, and
offers dedicated investment managers, while St. James’s Place hires external managers to manage
their range of funds.

**_Market Trends_**

_Increasing Demand for Sophisticated Solutions_

Financial advisers in the United Kingdom started outsourcing fund selection and investment
management after the introduction of RDR in order to better oversee advice risk and provide fair
customer outcomes. The new compliance costs linked to portfolio construction and advisory services
are not feasible for many small financial advisory firms. Hence, risk-based multi-asset solutions and
discretionary outsourcing are becoming an optimal choice for advisers to decrease their exposure to
the risks arising from the new regulations.

The current market environment where interest rates remain low has led investors to broaden their
portfolios and search for higher-yielding, risk-adjusted investment products. As a consequence, the


-----

simple balanced equity and bond portfolios have evolved into more sophisticated investment
strategies, including a more frequent use of alternative investments.

Finally, a fundamental demand for decumulation and income products to support retirees in the
drawdown phase started after the end of compulsory annuitisation and the introduction of Pension
Freedom. Data gathered by the FCA shows that after the two reforms, income drawdown accounted
for 76% of retirement income sales compared to only 19% in the previous periods.

_FCA Focus on Customer Outcomes and the Fair Treatment of Customers_

The FCA puts a lot of attention on customers’ fair outcomes and on fair treatment of clients in the
wealth and asset management industry. As multi-assets products are created for unique client needs
following their risk appetite, they are considered to be more transparent and thus demand for this type
of products has grown substantially, providing higher flows and assets under management.

_Rise of Passive Investment Strategies and Ongoing Fee Compression_

While investment markets have generally experienced sustained growth in recent years, many active
funds have not performed as well as passive investments, which has led some UK investors to
increasingly focus on fees and related expenses and in turn favour lower fee passive investment
products. As a consequence, passive funds constituted 31% of assets under management in the
United Kingdom in 2020 and are likely to grow further, compared to 26% of assets under management
in 2017. (Source: The Investment Association, September 2021 and September 2018). Moreover, the
increasing adoption of technology and the growth of digital advisers have further driven the demand
for passive investment products. This is expected to lead to lower levels of fees in the asset
management industry and could possibly result in the consolidation of smaller players as scale
becomes increasingly important. Moreover, investment managers who place a greater focus on
cost-efficient passive products are gaining market share. However, this migration to passive investing
is occurring at a slower rate in the retail wealth compared to the institutional investor pools and is
favoured by the younger investors who have a far lower level of assets under management than the
older investors who are less inclined to switch to passive investing. While we believe there will continue
to be demand in the United Kingdom for strong performing active management at attractive pricing,
we cannot predict how much market share competitors offering passive investment products will gain.

_Declining Revenue and Profitability Margins in DFM Segment_

DFMs were forced to change their revenue model after RDR from trail and rebate income to a fee
structure normally based on total portfolio value. The low yield ecosystem has also affected fee margin
lowering profitability especially for smaller firms which may not be efficient enough to sustain such low
prices.

_Consolidation in a Saturated DFM market_

In an attempt to increase their share of the market as well as their distribution competitiveness, the UK
DFM sector has already experienced consolidation. The underlying rationale for players choosing to
combine is that of cost. In fact, smaller firms in the sector are unable to benefit from any economies of
scale, as well as being faced with higher capital adequacy requirements. The increasing speed with
which companies need to adopt technological solutions and increased regulatory burdens have
contributed to these costs, hence further perpetuating this trend of consolidation.

###### OUR BUSINESS

_This business section includes certain technical terms that are commonly used in our industry. See_
_“Glossary of Asset Management Terms” for a detailed explanation of these terms._

**Overview**

True Potential is a fully integrated technology-led wealth manager, serving investors and advisers
across the United Kingdom. Total AUA on our platform as at 30 September 2021 were approximately
£18.8 billion, of which £16.5 billion were AUM, which are assets invested in our range of exclusive
investment funds. With our strong heritage in the North East of England, we have expanded, since
inception in 2007, to become one of the fastest growing financial services businesses in the United
Kingdom, employing approximately 380 full-time staff and working with approximately 4,500 financial
advisers. We provide financial advice, investment platform services and portfolio investment solutions
to UK retail clients.

Our aim is to revolutionise the way wealth management is delivered. We believe that by using
technology to deliver financial services, we empower financial advisers and their clients to take control
of their futures. By providing what we call “hybrid advice”, blending technology with expert financial
advice, we are able to offer clients the access and support they need 24/7, while ensuring that they
have an adviser to speak to whenever needed.

We are privileged to work with approximately 17% of UK financial advisers and their clients through
either our fully integrated model or through our software offering, meaning we can have a real impact
on how UK households invest their money and save for retirement.

We grow through accelerated adviser recruitment and client and AUM acquisition. We offer certain
advisers seeking capital to fund their growth a loan of 2% of their total assets under management when
they become Wealth Management Partners. Our recruitment programmes have contributed to rapid
growth in our AUM from £6.0 billion as at 31 December 2018 to £16.5 billion in our own funds as at
30 September 2021.

True Potential is primarily made up of the following businesses:

- TPI, which provides our purpose-built, in-house proprietary wealth management platform and our
own exclusive investment fund range;

- TPWM, which is our wealth management advice proposition with 844 self-employed Wealth
Management Partners as well as our 40-member in-house Central Advice Team;

- TPAS, which provides technology, adviser support and compliance services to approximately 598
financial advice firms with approximately 3,600 individual advisers representing more than one
million clients; and

- TPA, which is the in-house ACD for the TPI Funds.

As a fully integrated wealth manager participating in all parts of the value chain, we service all stages
of the wealth management process. We benefit from synergies across our ecosystem, with our
distribution, investment management and technology capabilities complementing each other. Our fully
integrated ecosystem enables and benefits from a multi-channel distribution model with multiple fee
streams. New investments pass through the True Potential platform and are invested in our ten True
Potential Portfolios, enabling us to capture economies across the value chain. Our multiple distribution
channels include (i) our wealth management advice channel TPWM, (ii) our adviser support services
channel TPAS and (iii) a D2C and auto-enrolment pension channel, where clients do not receive
financial advice. Assets that originated via these distribution channels then flow primarily to TPI, where
they are held and managed. Our multiple fee streams in TPI include (i) platform fees, (ii) fund fees and
(iii) performance fees, while TPWM also benefits from financial advice fees and TPAS also generates
revenue from service fees.


-----

Our revenue has become increasingly diversified across channels, resulting in robust AUA and AUM
expansion, supported by a growing recruitment programme that has led to double-digit revenue
growth and margin expansion. From 31 December 2018 to 30 September 2021, AUA on the True
Potential platform increased by £11.1 billion, or 143.6%, and AUM invested in TPI Funds increased by
£10.6 billion, or 177.3%. Our Net Revenue for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021 was
£165.3 million, which was generated from gross revenue of £260.4 million, and our EBITDA was
£122.6 million, representing an EBITDA Margin of 74.2% and an EBITDA CAGR of 67.8% from
31 December 2018 to 30 September 2021. Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve-month period ended
30 September 2021 was £160.0 million.

Gross Asset Inflows grew from £2.2 billion in 2018 to £4.2 billion in 2020 to £4.9 billion in the nine
months ended 30 September 2021. Over recent years, organic growth has been the “traditional” route
for Gross Asset Inflows through adviser and productivity growth and remains a strong underpin. The
majority of Gross Asset Inflows in 2018 and 2019 came from organic channels, most notably through
TPWM, which accounted for approximately 52% in 2018 and approximately 40% in 2019, and TPAS,
which represented approximately 43% in 2018 and 24% in 2019. In recent years, management has
been reinvesting cash flows into various recruitment initiatives, increasing the level of inorganic growth
given the market opportunity.

**Competitive Strengths**

**_Fully integrated business model drives capture of top of funnel flows and provides a competitive_**
**_edge_**

We have developed a full suite of capabilities across the value chain, all underpinned by a proprietary,
purpose-built and innovative technology platform that allows us to drive superior financial
performance.

The top of funnel flows are sourced through three distribution channels – (i) our wealth management
advice channel TPWM; (ii) our adviser support services channel TPAS; and (iii) a D2C and
auto-enrolment pension channel. These assets are held on the True Potential platform and are primarily
invested into TPI Funds held on this platform with a smaller portion of the AUA held in third-party funds.
As a consequence, we have well-diversified revenue attributable to the three distribution channels and
we earn fees across the whole value chain: advice, platform and investment management fees.

Each of our capabilities servicing the wealth management value chain has differentiating attributes,
such as:

- Advice: an at-scale national firm of advisers comprising a team of 844 Wealth Management
Partners and 40 Central Advice Team members, providing advice on True Potential’s investment
proposition.

- Platform: innovative platform seamlessly integrated with advice offering and unified with
investment solutions. The platform has won many awards over the years, most recently the UK
Platform Awards 2021, where True Potential’s platform was voted as the Best Platform Service and
Best Platform Provider.

- Investment solutions: offering competitively priced investment products that provide multi-layered
diversification and attractive risk adjusted returns. Recently, TPI has been named ‘Best for Digital
ISAs’ in the ‘Best Buys 2021 Awards’ by Boring Money.

The proportion of Integrated Flows, calculated as TPI flows divided by total flows, which increased from
89.3% in the year ended 31 December 2018 to 93.0% in the twelve-month period ended 30 September
2021, clearly demonstrates how unique our business model is. Even in absolute terms, Integrated
Flows have increased materially from £2.2 billion in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £6.3 billion
in the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021, representing a CAGR of 46.6%. The full
integration of True Potential’s business model allows us to offer clients significantly lower fees than
our main competitors, while maintaining strong profitability. While integrated solutions providers


-----

(e.g. St. James’ Place ISA/Unit Trust and Pension, Quilter PCA and Hargreaves Lansdown), wealth
managers (e.g. Schroders Personal Wealth, Rathbones and Brewin Dolphin) and independent financial
advice firms (i.e. firms representing a typical UK independent financial adviser charging structure and
having more than five advisers) charge all-in fees of approximately 2.3%, 2.3% and 2.0%, respectively,
True Potential charges clients all-in fees of approximately 1.7% of the amount invested.

Our £18.8 billion of AUA, of which 88% is AUM held in TPI Funds, and our network of 844 Wealth
Management Partners give us significant scale to operate in a very competitive market environment.
Additionally, the proprietary purpose-built technology platform operated by True Potential is already
used by approximately 17% of the total UK adviser population. Finally, we are fully licensed as a fund
manager (TPA), platform operator, investment manager, and pension operator and administrator (all
within TPI), and for advisory services (within TPWM). These attributes together underpin the significant
differentiation of our unique competitive strength.

**_High-quality, sticky adviser and client relationships drive high levels of recurring revenue_**

The differentiated technology and strong product set we offer have allowed us to attract and retain
productive advisers. This technology proposition offers full-spectrum support to advisers, driving
adviser productivity and satisfaction. Moreover, we leverage strong technology in the recruitment
process as this facilitates fast onboarding and, where required, a seamless asset transfer process.

We have also developed a structured recruitment process and targeted programmes, which allowed
us to rapidly expand our adviser firm from 456 advisers as at 31 December 2018 to 844 as at
30 September 2021, representing cumulative growth of more than 94%.

We have received consistent recognition from our adviser base for our platform quality, service ratings
and value for money propositions. In the Lang Cat Platform Analyser (Adviser Briefing, Issue Three:
June 2020), True Potential ranked:

- #1 for overall platform, achieving an NPS score of 4.48 (compared to the market average of 3.85);

- #1 for service rating, achieving an NPS score of 4.56 (compared to the market average of 3.59);
and

- #3 for value of fees charged, achieving an NPS score of 4.31 (compared to the market average
of 3.90).

The aforementioned high levels of satisfaction amongst advisers translate to sticky end clients,
demonstrated by our AUA retention rate of 93.4% over the last twelve months ended 30 September
2021. The highest retention rate is observed amongst clients who were transferred with advisers hired
under our client acquisition and adviser recruitment programme.

All of the above translate to a continued and sustained growth in Recurring Net Revenue, which
increased from £53 million in the year ended 31 December 2018 to £97 million in the year ended
31 December 2020, recording a CAGR of 35% and representing 89% of total Net Revenue.

**_Significant growth opportunity underpinned by structural market tailwinds_**

We operate in the fifth largest wealth management market in the world (Source: Global Wealth
Databook 2021), with £500 billion of assets managed by financial advisers in the UK (Source: The Lang
Cat). We have less than 4% market share of the £500 billion advice market, giving us plenty of
headroom to continue growing our business. In 2020, we were the fastest growing company in the
sector, achieving 34% growth in AUA; the next three fastest growing peers achieved assets under
administration growth rates of 32%, 18% and 17%, respectively (Source: Fundscape).

Within the UK wealth management market, we focus on the fastest growing segment of the UK wealth
market, the mass affluent, which includes investors with investable wealth between £100,000 and
£250,000. Given the tailwinds described below, this segment is expected to continue growing faster


-----

than the market average. Moreover, we are positioned to continue benefiting from these trends, given
our unwrapped products and hybrid advice model.

_Well-Positioned for Structural Market Growth_

We are well-positioned for tailwinds linked to the number of structural shifts that underpin the UK
wealth management market. According to an internal survey that started in 2013, we estimate that
there is a savings gap of £17,000 between the existing level of savings for retirement and the amount
necessary to generate a desirable income during retirement, and the UK government is expected to
continue adding initiatives that encourage consumers to save more, driving approximately 4% growth
in gross inflows each year. Recent initiatives included increasing tax savings and pension
auto-enrolment. Demographic trends are also favourable, with 22% of the population aged 65+ in 2030
(vs 18% in 2018), representing a source of sustained growth for us (Source: Office for National
Statistics).

_Growth from Adviser Recruitment_

The average age of independent financial advisers in the United Kingdom is 58 years, and one in five
advisers plans to retire in the next five years (Source: The Private Office, 2020). The recruitment
programmes we have developed provide us with a unique edge to capture the assets under
administration from advisers retiring in the near term.

_Regulatory Tailwinds_

In terms of regulatory developments, the sector has seen a transition from defined benefit plans to
defined contribution plans, which shift the investment responsibility to individuals, driving demand for
financial advice. With the end of compulsory annuitisation, members of defined pension schemes are
no longer required to purchase an annuity with their retirement fund but instead have a variety of
options as to how they can access their retirement income. The increase in accessibility from pensions
freedom has given savers in defined contribution schemes greater and earlier access to their cash,
thus allowing them to make investment decisions at an earlier age and with more capital available.
These changes in regulation represent enduring growth opportunities for us.

_Changing Consumer Trends and Preferences_

Furthermore, the FinTech adoption rate in the United Kingdom has increased significantly, going from
14% in 2015 to 86% in 2021 (Source: Plaid), which represents a great opportunity for True Potential to
leverage our proprietary technology platform by providing advisers and clients an enhanced user
experience. The higher adoption of financial technology platforms and other products, as well as the
greater awareness of the importance of saving and investing, are trends that were clearly identified by
our directors, leading to the development of unique products like impulseSave, the first-of-its-kind
technology that helps clients add money to their investments in an instant and as little as £1 at a time.

Also, the COVID-19 pandemic has helped to accelerate a pre-existing need for increased on-demand
advice that we successfully identified as a key client need. While some competitors are launching
similar services, we have in place a hybrid advice offering that addresses clients’ demand for more
ad-hoc services.

Finally, the level of engagement between our clients and our products is also observable through
several indicators. For instance, during 2021, there were approximately 5.5 million log-ins, of which
approximately 3.4 million (63%) were via the mobile app, through which clients are able to message
and interact more often. Our directors are confident that we are well-suited to meet shifting customer
preferences for digital and hybrid advice as it enables increased engagement.

**_operating leverage_**

Since 2008, we have patiently invested in our proprietary technology platform with the ambition to

including client access and quote panels, as well as to create an investment platform that was

Additionally, the strong infrastructure and fully cloud-based system further improve the scalability of the

With respect to our investment solutions, the ten portfolios offered by TPI are aligned with our ambition

**_Highly credible, visionary management team complemented by robust governance framework_**

We benefit from a well-established governance structure comprised of a highly credible and visionary
management team with a strong track record. Furthermore, our robust risk management and resilient
internal systems contribute to our success.

The five co-founders, Daniel Harrison, David Harrison, Neil Johnson, Mark Henderson and Earl
Glasgow, have each been with us since our inception. The five co-founders have 155 years combined
of experience in the industry. David Harrison has extensive experience in the wealth management
industry, having previously co-founded Positive Solutions, an independent financial advisory firm.
Daniel Harrison previously headed the Group’s marketing and technology teams. Neil Johnson also
serves as the Managing Partner of TPA. Mark Henderson was instrumental in enhancing the True
Potential Wealth Platform’s product range. Earl Glasgow is responsible for the sales activity on the True
Potential Wealth Platform. The senior leadership team also includes two non-executive directors,
George Peebles, who provides oversight on our strategic activities and specialises in M&A, and Peter
Coward, who previously worked as a tax partner at PwC for 27 years. The senior leadership is rounded
out by experienced individuals who have an average of 29 years in the industry and 12 years with us.

Our risk management strategy can be broken down to the individual entities: TPI and TPWM.

_TPI_

TPI seeks to reduce and mitigate operational risk where possible. This is achieved by identifying and
then implementing necessary actions to prevent such risks from occurring. We seek to achieve this


-----

through managing risk with two internal operational risk teams who are split between incident
management and Risk and Control Self Assessment (“RCSA”) implementation. In order to mitigate
incidents in the future, we use an in-house system for recording and tracking incidents then utilise a
management information suite for the purpose of trend analysis. The RCSAs plot every process and
detail the operational risk faced by the business if an aspect of that process fails.

These systems are combined, as the RCSA identifies the risk and we can set action plans to resolve
the incident. The process directly links in to show where controls are starting to fail, risks are
materialising and the financial and potential reputational impact of incidents. As a result, we can
quickly identify any emerging trends and look to resolve them in a much more efficient and effective
way before issues becoming more widespread or having much further-reaching consequences.

In addition to our personnel, our technology is pivotal in providing an instant and direct approach to
inform clients of transfers, updated policies, and movements of money, among other things.

_TPWM_

TPWM seeks to reduce and/or mitigate operational risk where possible, which is achieved through a
compliance monitoring plan that requires regular review and analysis of all risks and controls present
within the firm. Compliance staff are split between monitoring and control, which oversees day-to-day
compliance activities, and training and competence, which undertakes longer-term monitoring and
training of adviser activities.

Technology is integrated into all processes, ensuring risks are quickly and easily identified as they
materialise and can be dealt with effectively. Advice is provided through a technology-based solution
ensuring that consistent and compliant advice is provided by all advisers within the firm and enabling
automated monitoring of specific business types.

In addition, management expects to benefit from the business relationships, market knowledge,
leadership and experience of Cinven.

Cinven has invested in more than 130 companies, having raised €37 billion total funds since its
inception in 1977. Examples of Cinven’s prior investments in the financial services sector, and
particularly in highly regulated assets, include the acquisitions of Compre, Guardian Financial
Services, Miller, NewDay, Partnership Assurance and Premium Credit Limited, in the United Kingdom,
Ark Life and Avolon in Ireland, Heidelberger Leben (now renamed Viridium Group) in Germany,
Skandia in Germany and Austria and Ergo Italia and Old Mutual Wealth in Italy. In addition, Cinven
maintains transparent and constructive relationships with regulators, having achieved regulatory
approvals over 40 times in different European jurisdictions as well as in Bermuda and Singapore.

**Our Strategies**

We have developed the following strategies to maintain and expand our market-leading positions,
make our businesses more profitable and exploit market opportunities.

**_Continue to focus on adviser recruitment and client asset acquisition_**

We have a strong record in growing our adviser network with the TPWM partner firm having increased
from 456 Wealth Management Partners as at 31 December 2018 to 844 as at 30 September 2021. Our
network of Wealth Management Partners is further complemented by our Central Advice Team of
40 advisers and staff as at 30 September 2021. We have developed a proposition for advisers looking
to monetise their client books and/or raising capital to further grow their client networks. This
proposition is extremely compelling, especially as the transfer of client assets is entirely digitised which
leads to a high conversion rate.

Given our superior technology stack and its consequential impacts on customer experience, we
remain a partner of choice for advisers and clients. There remains a sizable opportunity to target
advisers with our recruitment proposition. We estimate that approximately 24,000, or 87%, of the
approximately 27,500 financial advisers in the United Kingdom are addressable to our recruitment


-----

proposition, with the small firms deemed the easiest to target. As reported by the FCA in July 2021, the
total number of financial advisers in the United Kingdom as at 31 December 2020 was 27,501.
Platforum has reported that 53% of UK financial advisers are in firms with fewer than 50 advisers
(Source: Platforum UK Financial Advisers, November 2020). The smaller firms in the market have seen
increasing regulatory costs and burdens over recent years, via increasing FSCS levy and additional
requirements relating to processing personally identifiable data; therefore, to run a small advice firm is
now particularly challenging. We are better equipped to target advisers from these smaller firms given
that we recruit adviser-by-adviser, rather than at firm level.

True Potential is targeting further productivity gains through specific initiatives, including:

- _Additional sales initiatives. We use Business Development Managers to target additional sales_
opportunities. By making our digital products – Digital Direct Offer, impulseSave, Client Site
Transfer – available to our advisers, we stand to benefit from additional new money inflows onto
our platform and fund products.

- _Advisers focused on OPT market. It is estimated that the current addressable market for defined_
benefit to defined contribution transfers is £782 billion (Source: True Potential Due Diligence
Report). The OPT process is centrally controlled with the entire transfer process digitised end-toend. Given the direct oversight from our head office, the OPT process allows advisers to focus on
the sales process while benefiting from the consistency of a seamless customer journey and
auditable transfer process. True Potential remains differentiated in its approach with limited
competitive threats given its technology advantage.

- _Client Service Transfer (CST) initiative. Advisers have the option to transfer their client business to_
our Central Advice Team. This allows the adviser to use the proceeds from the transfer to focus
on building new client relationships and to pay for client leads to accelerate rebuilding their client
books.

We have an innovative platform that underpins our advice offering. The benefit of having started with
an in-house, purpose-built technology platform from the outset is that we have captured material data
on how our users – both advisers and clients – interact with the technology and the functions they
value. This allows us to make targeted offers on the channel with the highest client engagement
translating to a higher success conversion rate.

**_Further improve operational efficiency_**

True Potential has consistently recorded yearly increases in EBITDA Margin. This metric increased from
51% for the year ended 31 December 2018 to 74% for the twelve-month period ended 30 September
2021. The primary driver of our EBITDA Margin is our fully invested, scalable and proprietary
technology platform.

The core architecture of the platform has been provisioned with significant growth potential. For
example, just in terms of storage we have has contracted for 70 terabytes of private cloud capacity and
are currently at 40 terabytes usage. To complement this, we have contracted for 2,800 gigabyte
storage on the public cloud with only approximately 900 gigabytes currently being used. In the future,
our strategy is to continue migrating from the private cloud to a public cloud, which is offered by
Microsoft Azure – a platform-as-a-service (“PaaS”) approach whereby Microsoft manages the ongoing
patching of components. This change will bring us several advantages:

- the ability to focus on developing the components to meet the business needs, instead of
spending too much time on the underlying requirements of infrastructure installations and
maintenance;

- a more flexible cost structure, as we will only pay for what we use, when we use it, and with the
option to turn it off when it is no longer needed; and


-----

- infinite scalability across the globe, as we will not need to project for and purchase expected
infrastructure upfront; we can initiate new projects instantly with the minimum required
infrastructure and scale up as we go.

We expect that the benefits of increasing scale through the business plan are also going to be evident
in the cost of the TPI Funds. The sub-fund managers are on tiered charging structures; as AUM
increases the effective pay away reduces as a result of the tiering. Enhanced scale will also allow us
to negotiate better terms with new sub-advisers we attract to the business.

Management actively reviews the operational set-up of True Potential to unlock cost savings. Two
recent examples include the insourcing of SEI activities and the recent ACD authorisation. SEI
provided the back-office technology and custodianship of the assets on the platform prior to 2018
when TPI built the platform in house. The re-platforming of the assets from the SEI system to the TPI
build system was seamless, which we believe is unprecedented in the platform industry. On the other
hand, Smith and Williamson provided the outsourced ACD function for the TPI fund range prior to the
launch of TPA in 2021.

**_Continue to develop True Potential’s investment solutions_**

Our objective is to deliver investment solutions that offer multi-layered diversification with attractive
risk/reward trade-off at a low cost. There is currently £16.5 billion of AUM in TPI Funds and 93% of total
inflows during the nine-months to 30 September 2021 have been invested in these funds. Since
inception, TPI Funds have delivered strong performance across its range of funds. Delivering the right
outcomes from the range of investment solutions is particularly important and TPI will continue to focus
on sustaining its record of investment outperformance for its customers.

We recently received FCA approval to launch seven new funds, two income funds and five funds
across our current risk categories, adding two new fund managers to our proposition. For the income
portfolios, these managers will provide further diversification to income sources and reduce the current
UK bias. Adding a new manager across our current risk profiles will bring a growth-orientated style
based on their thematic approach to equity selection in our strategies.

TPI, being an integral part of True Potential, provides distinct advantages and allows for close
integration and collaboration across the group. In the future, we expect to develop additional products
to directly meet the needs of customers, including those focused on sustainability.

**_Continue to invest in data and analytics_**

We use technology to ensure end clients have the best possible experience whilst also allowing us to
bulk service clients without significantly growing our teams. Our ability to enable and transition clients
to a state of comfort in managing their own financial affairs online or within the app is key to achieving
this objective. A clear example of our success in this initiative comes from the Central Advice Team,
where we have approximately 30,400 clients serviced by 40 people. Furthermore, we can see a
growing trend in the numbers of client log-ins and returning client log-ins from Central Advice Team
clients and, specifically, clients tend to log-in ten times per month on the app and four times per month
on the web.

Client engagement has always been a key aspect in our business model because the most engaged
clients generally have more assets on our platform. For instance, the Central Advice Team clients
categorised as “Super Engaged” have, on average, assets with £328,000 invested with us, compared
to “Not Engaged” clients worth £93,000 and “Not Activated” clients with £48,000.

As a higher level of client engagement is associated with larger average portfolios, we have been
developing several initiatives with the ultimate goal of improving the engagement level with our clients.
True Potential introduced the next instance of the client facing suite, cNext, in January 2022. This
upgrade is the next level of evolution for True Potential’s client portal which will embed enhanced
analytics and machine learning to identify and customise client-relevant information and product
marketing.


-----

As part of cNext, we have also laid the foundational client-visible features to enable improved
personalisation and hyper-personalisation going forward. The prior current client site had standardised
videos, blogs and articles for clients. In the new instance, these feeds are tailored to respective client
profiles and individual client circumstances and events building on insights gathered from the wealth
of personal information gathered within a standard factfind along with portfolio events, behaviour and
browsing history on the website and app. We also improved our capabilities to send tailored content
and push notifications on the web and our mobile app and enhanced our already available (via the
web) video chat to also be directly available within our mobile apps with no requirement for additional
third-party component installations (such as Zoom). Additionally, we are increasingly integrating open
banking features within our client site. This allows clients to aggregate their bank accounts and offplatform investments on a single view alongside their True Potential investments, in addition to allowing
the clients the ability to visualise their current spending habits and set budgeting targets for the future.
We are also offering rewards to clients as an additional pull feature. Engagement behaviour is useful
for us to improve targeted marketing by allowing relevant product information to be made available in
real time, which translates to a higher success rate. The key objective of these features is to encourage
the end client to self-service, but in doing so data is generated, tracked and analysed by us. We have
a deep data lake of approximately 40 terabytes developed over a span of 14 years that can be
leveraged to hyper-personalise and better service existing clients and enhance cross-selling.

In order to further leverage our well-established back-end system, we continue enhancing our
back-end data architecture and infrastructure with the development of our client analytics infrastructure
and cube. Client analytics is key to enabling the ease at which data are ingested from the various
facets of the True Potential system and denormalised from data into information that can be easily
interrogated by data analysts with a view to further understand clients, personalise our engagement
with each individual on a bulk scale and predict and influence their behaviour in future. Some
advantages coming from our improvements are easily and automatically identifying and acting upon
opportunities within the client bank, better predicting client behaviour based on categorisation and
clustering and hyper-personalising the engagement with and experience of the end client. A final key
component of our strategy is bringing this engagement information back into the vNext system, so that
if a client does need to speak to us, we have an unrivalled visual of the client history and behaviour
immediately visible, thereby ensuring that the end client gets the best possible support.

**Our History**

True Potential was founded in 2007 by our chairman, David Harrison, and senior partners, Daniel
Harrison, Neil Johnson, Mark Henderson and Earl Glasgow, with the establishment of TPAS. TPAS was
enhanced in 2008 with compliance consultancy services. The distribution expansion phase of our
development continued in 2010 with the receipt of FCA authorisation for TPWM.


-----

The next phase of our growth was focused on the development of our technology platform. We
launched our internally developed wealth management platform, the True Potential Wealth Platform, in
2011 and over time brought together the core elements of True Potential, including the back-office
system, the wealth management platform and client servicing tools, such as unique client websites.

From 2015, when we launched our own fund range and our discretionary service, our growth has
accelerated through the introduction of our own products. In 2016, we reached the milestone of
£1 billion invested in True Potential Portfolios eleven months after launch and achieved £2 billion only
five months later.

In 2018, we launched our in-house built, enhanced True Potential Wealth Platform, and in 2019 we
completed the migration of assets from the platform of our technology partner. In that year our total
assets under management reached £10 billion, and we launched our adviser recruiting and client
acquisition programme. In 2021, TPA became an internal ACD. Our recent development has been
further accelerated by the launch and rapid growth of our in-house team of financial advisers and
support staff (the “Central Advice Team”), which assists and advises clients directly. As at 30
September 2021, the Central Advice Team managed £4.5 billion of assets from approximately 30,600
clients.

On 8 September 2021 we announced an agreement to sell a majority stake in the business to Cinven,

**_True Potential Investments_**

_True Potential Wealth Platform_

TPI provides access to the True Potential Wealth Platform, which offers a range of investment solutions,
including diversified True Potential Portfolios managed on a nil cost discretionary basis. The in-house,
purpose-built proprietary platform underpins the client and adviser proposition, and serves
approximately 360,000 customers. Products offered include personal pensions, ISAs and general
investment accounts.

The True Potential Wealth Platform is engineered with the future in mind, delivering innovation, choice,
control and value. The platform is structured for growth and was built from the ground up for UK
financial advisers looking to maximise investment opportunities for clients. The platform uses True


-----

Potential’s award-winning in-house technology and integrates innovative features such as
impulseSave, which enables investors to “top-up” investments that have been previously advised upon
at the touch of a button by adding micro-payments to their investments at account level or at fund level,
and True Potential One, our financial planning system that consolidates all of a client’s savings and
investments in one convenient location.

The True Potential Wealth Platform offers a wide range of investments that allow investors to invest their
capital within innovative risk-rated investment options and gives them exposure to world-class
investment managers. Among the investment options are True Potential Portfolios, a range of ten
discretionary managed portfolios that blend together funds from a range of asset managers in our
wealth strategy fund range using advanced diversification. Advisers and investors can also choose to
construct a bespoke plan from the thousands of mutual funds, bonds (onshore and offshore),
exchange traded funds and equities that we have available. Investors also have access to a range of
exclusive tax wrappers, including our stocks and shares ISA and personal pension, to ensure
investments are as tax efficient as possible.

As at 30 September 2021, the True Potential platform had AUA of £18.8 billion, £16.5 billion of which
were AUM invested in exclusive TPI Funds, with the remainder being AUA invested in third-party funds.
AUA growth from £7.7 billion as at 31 December 2018 through 30 September 2021 represents a CAGR
of 26.8%. In addition, True Potential was the fastest growing company in terms of AUA growth in 2020,
where it recorded an AUA growth of 20%. TPI AUM growth at a CAGR of 31.3% from £6.0 billion as at
31 December 2018 to £16.5 billion as at 30 September 2021 has delivered better economics for True
Potential while also delivering savings to clients as client charges for the most invested portfolio, the
True Potential Balanced Portfolio, have decreased from 82 basis points in 2018 to 80 basis points in
2021 while the net fund margin for TPI Funds has increased from 80 basis points in 2018 to 100 basis
points in 2021.

_True Potential Portfolios_

Through the TPI platform, True Potential clients have access to ten exclusive True Potential Portfolios
made up of 34 underlying funds (the “TPI Funds”), 28 of which are sub-advised by a leading panel of
global investment firms and six of which are managed directly by True Potential’s in-house investment
team. The True Potential Portfolios are managed by our in-house team on a discretionary basis at no
additional cost to the end client. We use eight sub-advisers comprising a number of the world’s leading
investment management groups, delivering their expertise to True Potential’s clients at low cost. Our
eight sub-advisers are based in 174 global locations and include approximately 9,800 experts,
providing end clients access to investment solutions. We work with the following investment fund
managers that sub-manage the TPI Funds, blending their management styles for an extra layer of
diversification in our True Potential Portfolios: UBS, Allianz Global Investors, Goldman Sachs Asset
Management, Columbia Threadneedle Investments, Schroders, SEI, Close Brothers Asset
Management and Seven Investment Management. The 34 underlying funds can also be separately
accessed by our clients.

True Potential Portfolios are a suite of fully diversified, discretionary-managed investment solutions.
With wide exposure to world-class investment managers, as well as diversifying investments by asset
class and geographic region, investors benefit from having more potential to grow their money and
manage volatility, all in one portfolio.

We continually monitor our portfolios to make sure they perform as expected and remain within an
investor’s chosen risk profile. We also rebalance for the future, rather than the past, taking an active
approach to allocating investors’ money where we see the greatest potential for growth.

True Potential Portfolios are actively managed and controlled by True Potential’s investment team. As
at 30 September 2021, eight True Potential staff members were focused on data gathering and risk
analysis, including having full access to underlying portfolio data daily, having regular manager
discussion with the analyst team, aggregating data and risk modelling with capital market
assumptions, expected returns and volatility. A further ten staff members were engaged in fund
manager interview and analysis (e.g. analysing the portfolio position, analysing transactions and
development questions for managers), identifying key themes (e.g. analysing asset allocation and
asset class changes), portfolio decision-making (e.g. asset allocation, manager changes, portfolio
changes and optimisation for risk, cost, risk-adjusted return and long-term expected return) and
adviser and client communications (e.g. daily market updates, weekly webinars, podcasts and roundups, monthly updates and fact sheets and quarterly publications, seminars and workshops).
