**_True Potential Wealth Management_**

TPWM provides financial advice on a restricted basis for clients investing into funds and portfolios
offered by True Potential. It comprises more than 850 financial advisers, including 844 Wealth
Management Partners as well as the True Potential in-house Central Advice Team. True Potential offers
a highly competitive, lower annual all-in fee of approximately 1.7% of assets invested for clients for the
full wealth management range of services (advice, platform services and investment solutions) as
compared to the broader market, where charges are typically 2.0-2.3%.

TPWM benefits from three distribution channels: (i) Wealth Management Partners; (ii) occupational
pension transfer; and (iii) client acquisition through our recruitment programme. These distribution
channels generated revenue of £1.1 billion, £0.9 billion and £3.2 billion, respectively, for the
twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021.

Investors from each of these channels receive financial advice from either our Wealth Management
Partners, who are self-employed restricted advisers, or the True Potential Central Advice Team.

As at 30 September 2021, we had approximately 1.2 million total end clients using our services,
including approximately 30,600 clients receiving financial advice from our Central Advice Team. As at
that date, 844 Wealth Management Partners managed £8.4 billion of assets, receiving 90% of the
applicable advice fees while approximately 10% of the advice fee was retained by True Potential, while
40 Central Advice Team members provided financial advice covering £4.5 billion of AUM, with 100% of
advice fees retained by TPWM.

TPWM clients receive restricted wealth advice from advisers having access to TPI Funds and benefiting
from an integrated technology-enabled platform. We expect TPWM clients to be on the True Potential
platform for more than 25 years based on their ages, with a majority being 60 years old or younger.
TPWM clients are based all over the United Kingdom and come from varying wealth bands. The
highest proportion of clients are from the <25,000 wealth band, driven by our auto-enrolment pension
channel, where clients do not receive financial advice.

TPWM-advised AUM has experienced significant growth supported by a multi-pronged sales strategy.
AUM for TPWM Wealth Management Partners was £4.1 billion at the end of 2018. In 2019, we launched
our adviser and client recruiting programme and our Central Advice Team began advising clients,
adding to total AUM. Total AUM for TPWM grew to £6.1 billion at the end of 2019, made up of
£1.3 billion from the Central Advice Team and £4.8 billion from Wealth Management Partners. At the
end of 2020, total AUM for TPWM grew to £9.0 billion, including £2.8 billion from the Central Advice
Team and £6.2 billion from Wealth Management Partners. As at 30 September 2021, total AUM for
TPWM was £13.0 billion, with £4.5 billion from the Central Advice Team and £8.5 billion from Wealth
Management Partners. The gross profit margin for TPWM was 11%, 14% and 23% in 2018, 2019 and
2020, respectively. TPWM gross profit margin for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021
was 28.0%.

_Wealth Management Partners_

As at 30 September 2021, £8.4 billion of the AUA on the True Potential platform were assets of clients
of 844 self-employed restricted advisers who are focused on the investment opportunities on True
Potential’s platform and in its portfolios. We refer to these advisers as our “Wealth Management
**Partners”.**

Fees earned from Wealth Management Partner-managed assets contributed £70.9 million, or 42.9%, of
the Group’s Net Revenue for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021. This contribution
was made up of advice fees, platform fees, fund fees and performance fees paid by clients. Clients pay
advice fees to their advisers of around 75 basis points (blended basis of ongoing fees and one-off fees)
of the amount invested, 90% of which is retained by the Wealth Management Partner and 10% of which
is recorded as revenue for True Potential. For the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021,
advice fees for Wealth Management Partners contributed £7.4 million of Net Revenue.

**_True Potential Adviser Services_**

TPAS, which was established in 2007, provides back-office, IT and compliance services to financial
advisers and offers convenient and modern technology to help financial advisers do business from
anywhere in the world. TPAS works with approximately 4,500 financial advisers within around
714 directly authorised firms that had 1.2 million client records as at 30 September 2021.

The initial contract term for advisers using TPAS services is three years, which subsequently becomes
a twelve-month rolling agreement. The charge for TPAS services is typically 4% of adviser turnover.

TPAS provides a full-suite of technology-led modern and convenient support services to advisers who
continuously use the platform to focus on their “core” business, providing recurring positive flows to
the platform and TPI.

TPAS services provided include:

- _Back-Office Systems: client and policy data storage; client audit trail; fees & commission_
reconciliation; fees & commission statements; secure messaging; unlimited document storage;
CRM; professional indemnity insurance application assistance; retail mediation activities
returns/Gabriel reporting; real-time values and data feeds; data reporting; financial planning and
application tools; compliance systems; and integrated wealth platform;

- _Finance Support: escrow account; RMAR support; and support training for advisers;_

- _Compliance Systems and Support: bi-annual system compliance audit and review; treating_
customers fairly, management information and KPI system; agency set up; annual audit sign-off;
Gabriel completion; regulatory updates; AML training; annual knowledge assessment; fact find
updates/approval; recruitment guidance; financial promotions; FCA authorisation process;
business plan and templates; personal indemnity insurance; compliance procedures and
manuals; and suitability report templates;

- _Continuous Adviser Support: service level agreement on all communication forms; secure_
messages to client and support team; online ticketing system; online support guides; 24/7
support; and dedicated business development manager and head office account manager; and

- _Client Technology: personalised client website; mobile and tablet apps; real time valuations;_
secure adviser messaging; document storage; impulseSave/goal tracking; and personal finance
management.

Advisers continually use the TPAS platform, as demonstrated by growth in AUM, engagement in
training and utilisation of services. In the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021,
£355.9 million of TPAS occupational pension transfers were submitted through TPWM, £169.4 million
of TPAS client investments were moved using direct offers and client site transfers and £196.0 million
was added to the platform using impulseSave.


-----

TPAS provides recurring positive flows to the True Potential platform. For the twelve-month period
ended 30 September 2021, £1,108 million from TPAS sales was added to the True Potential platform,
representing 33% of total TPAS sales (including on other platforms). 79.3% of TPAS sales transferred
to the True Potential platform for the twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021 was subsequently
invested in True Potential Portfolios, a percentage that has continually increased since TPI Funds were
launched. As at 30 September 2021, a total of £4.9 billion from TPAS firms was on the True Potential
platform, of which £3.1 billion was invested in TPI Funds.

TPAS provides back-office software to independent financial advisers who are then able to choose to
use the platform and funds or third-party alternatives. Advisers are charged a fee of 4% of their turnover
for these services. TPAS administration services contributed revenue of £4.9 million for the
twelve-month period ended 30 September 2021.

TPAS contributed £26.5 million, or 16.0%, of the Group’s Net Revenue for the twelve-month period
ended 30 September 2021.

advisers either looking for capital to grow or, alternatively, to retire and manage client succession. We
have a strong track record of client acquisition and adviser recruitment, with a competitive advantage
driven by our ability to offer a better proposition to advisers and clients. An overview of the True
Potential recruiting programme is illustrated below.

The opportunities provide certain benefits to the adviser, including the ability to maximise capital now
and/or in the future. Advisers receive their agreed-upon share of advice fees daily. �

For independent financial advisers who are looking for capital to grow their client assets, we offer an
upfront payment of 2% of their assets under management when they transition their clients to True
Potential. When joining True Potential under this option the independent financial adviser becomes one
of our Wealth Management Partners. The Wealth Management Partners continue to advise and provide
services to their clients while retaining 90% or more of the total advice fees earned. If the adviser wishes
to fully transition their clients to the True Potential Central Advice team at a later date, they can sell their
portfolio for 2.75% of the value of the assets. We refer to this path as the “2% proposition” in our client
acquisition and adviser recruiting programme.

For independent financial advisers who are seeking to retire or otherwise exit the market, we offer a
loan of 8% of their assets under management to be paid in the first six months when they transfer
clients to the True Potential Central Advice Team. Payment is made on completion of the arrangement


-----

after 12-24 months. We refer to this path as the “8% proposition” in our client acquisition and adviser
recruiting programme.

Advisers onboarded as Wealth Management Partners through the recruitment programme go through
a rigorous rules-based process. As a first step, information is requested on the adviser and the
adviser’s end clients to ensure thorough due diligence by True Potential on the adviser and the client
portfolios. The adviser then completes a three-day modular online training course and provides
confirmation that references can be requested covering the last six years of authorisation from the
adviser’s previous firm or firms. Annual compliance reviews are then conducted on advisers.

As at 30 September 2021, £11.1 billion of AUA from approximately 24,000 clients had been added to
the True Potential platform since the start of the recruitment programme in July 2018. In addition,
clients from 244 advisers have been onboarded through the 8% proposition, and 204 of our 8%
advisers remain as Wealth Management Partners as at 30 September 2021.

The programme also provides a transparent and seamless transfer of assets onto the True Potential
platform for the end client where they are being transferred from independent financial advisers to the
Central Advice Team. Clients are requested to complete a detailed questionnaire providing information
on their assets, life goals and expectations. The data is then anonymised and the transferable assets
are confirmed, ensuring that they can be transferred without detriment to the client. An implementation
plan is then put in place where TPWM provides a welcome pack with information on the resources
available and relevant contact information. The focus is on understanding the client’s situation and her
or his expectations. The client is then onboarded as a True Potential client and serviced by our fully
dedicated, experienced and scalable in-house Central Advice Team.

The Central Advice Team’s onboarding process includes telephone, email and text engagement with
the client, an online demonstration of True Potential’s services, and engagement with the client on the
app and website through our daily, weekly and quarterly videos, podcasts and publications. The
Central Advice Team provides all client advice needs online and is available twelve hours per day on
weekdays.

The recruitment programme has resulted in strong client asset conversion rates, with 75% and 83% of
transferable client assets under the 2% proposition and the 8% proposition, respectively, being
transferred to True Potential.

Between 1 January and 30 September 2021, the Central Advice Team answered approximately 37,000
calls, 15,000 live chats and 23,000 secure client messages. Nearly 4,000 online demonstrations were
completed and clients had logged in over 1.1 million times. £35.0 million of additional assets had also
been added using impulseSave. Clients have saved approximately 20 basis points on financial advice
fees and approximately 80 basis points on platform and fund fees by virtue of being clients of the
Central Advice Team.

**Our Technology**

From the outset, our founding partners believed that technology would play a pivotal role in the wealth
management industry, and our vision 14 years ago was to be an agile, innovative, end-to-end,
multi-channel “wealthtech” via an integrated technology platform. Our technology platform is the core
of the firm. It is a fully integrated tech stack for advisers and clients that enables better user experience
and enhanced cross selling, and it was built and developed in-house by a focused multi-disciplinary
team led by our founding partners and shareholders.

**_Our Technology Platform_**

First launched as an adviser system in 2008, our award-winning technology platform is a single
end-to-end fully integrated multi-channel technology platform catering to all ecosystem needs, with the
purpose of enabling our vertically integrated model and delivering operational gearing and tangible
results, such as growth in AUA, efficiency savings and greater profit margins. With the help of our
technology platform, from 31 December 2018 to 30 September 2021, our EBITDA Margin increased by


-----

25.1 percentage points and AUA grew at a CAGR of 38.2%, while during the same time period, IT costs
decreased at a CAGR of -9%.

investments have been made through Digital Direct Offer since it was introduced in 2020. Digital Direct
Offer provides a client a personalised offer, via email or text, based on prior communication. After the
client accesses the offer through a link, the client can accept the offer, choose a portfolio and transfer
the funds. Another key client-facing feature offered by our technology platform is impulseSave, where

Our technology platform is also supported by our deep data lake, which is enhanced by multiple
touchpoints across the user base and provides distinctive insights to better service existing clients and
enhance cross-selling. Over the past 14 years, through our technology platform, we have processed
millions of documents, commission statements, secure messages and recommendations. The
in-depth client data allows for hyper-personalisation based on client behaviour, through providing
actionable insights to our advisers and enabling our service team to form a real-time view on changes
in client circumstances. For example, through open banking, traditional bank account transactions are
imported into the True Potential database through a third-party provider, with the data analysed to
provide budgeting and opportunity suggestions. In addition, the deep data lake also enables and
enhances up-selling and cross-selling of products and services through targeted marketing.

Moreover, our technology platform benefits from a fully cloud-hosted underlying infrastructure, which
improves some of the key features of our technology platform, such as the service-oriented
architecture, data storage, file storage, automation and integration. The cloud-hosted infrastructure
also supports future growth and scale-up of our business, and our data is hosted on both private and
public clouds.

In addition, we adopt state-of-the-art data protection with leading third-party certifications to protect our
data. We also have robust data recovery measures in place and a stable and consistent technology
stack, including support from Microsoft, Microsoft Azure, Xamarin, SQL Server and .NET Core.

**_Our Technology Team_**

We have a strong, dedicated and experienced technology team, with 50 full-time employees. The core
architecture and development team has 39 full-time employees with their average experience greater
than ten years. Our technology team is also growing in order to fulfil the needs of our clients and
advisers, with 16 technology staff hired in the last three years. Our technology team works across a
broad range of areas in order to support our goal to lead innovations through technical solutions.

- _Infrastructure and architecture: the infrastructure and architecture team focuses on implementing_
coding standards and managing hardware as well as software infrastructures.

- _Analysis and design: the analysis and design team focuses on researching ways to enhance user_
experience, as well as working with our business team to understand their requests for change.

- _Developers: currently, 20 out of the 50 full-time employees in our technology team are developers,_
who are mainly responsible for building all the in-house proprietary technology, as well as
supporting our academy learning.

- _Data and reporting: the data and reporting team works with business areas in order to understand_
the management information requirements. They are also responsible for providing functional
requirements to the development team and integrating internal systems.

- _Academy: the academy team is responsible for completing development training programmes_
and providing first line support to our business.

We may be involved in regulatory proceedings or disputes in our ordinary course of business. As at

###### REGULATION

There are currently three FCA regulated entities within the True Potential group:

- TPI is an investment firm with FCA regulatory permissions which include: (i) advising on
investments, P2P agreements, pension transfers and pension opt outs; (ii) arranging deals in
investments, regulated mortgage contracts and safeguarding and administration of assets;
(iii) dealing in investment as agent and dealing investments as principal; (iv) establishing,
operating or winding up a stakeholder pension scheme/personal pension scheme; (v) making
arrangements with a view to regulated mortgage contracts/transactions in investments;
(vi) managing investments; (vii) safeguarding and administration of assets (without arranging);
(viii) client money; and (ix) payment services (account information services).

- TPWM is authorised to provide advice on investments, pensions (including occupational),
mortgages and home finance and credit broking to retail and commercial clients. As at
30 September 2021, TPWM had more than 900 financial advisers who were authorised as
registered individuals under TPWM, all of whom other than Earl Glasgow (SMF27) are restricted
advisers, primarily advising on the products and funds offered by TPI.

- TPA is the management company within True Potential’s asset management business. The
authorised funds are all UK UCITS schemes. TPA is an authorised fund manager (ACD to the
OEICS and Manager to the authorised unit trust). TPA has permission for managing a UK UCITS
and may only carry on the activities specified in COLL 6.9.9R(1) to (3) which include: (i) managing
a UK UCITS; (ii) activities in respect of (i); and (iii) collective portfolio management. Investment
management is delegated to TPI, which may sub-delegate to agreed delegates. TPA does not
hold client money.

TPI, TPWM and TPA operate in a highly regulated environment which is subject to a very high degree
of focus by the FCA. A significant amount of resources is typically required by firms who operate within
the private wealth management space to ensure that adequate processes are in place to monitor,
manage and mitigate relevant risk exposure.

**Regulation in the United Kingdom**

**_Financial Services Act 2012_**

Prior to 31 March 2013, UK regulated firms in the True Potential group were required to be authorised
by the Financial Services Authority (the “FSA”). Accordingly, those firms were required to comply with
the rules and guidance made by the FSA pursuant to the FSMA and set out in the FSA Handbook of
rules and guidance.

The Financial Services Act 2012 (“FS Act”) (and the secondary legislation made under it) reformed the
framework for financial regulation in the United Kingdom. In 2013, the FSA was replaced by the FCA,
the Prudential Regulation Authority (“PRA”) and the Financial Policy Committee (the “FPC”). With
effect from 1 April 2013, the UK regulated firms in the Group became authorised and regulated by the
FCA. UK regulated entities in the Group must comply with the rules and guidance of the FCA (as
applicable) made under the FSMA.

The FPC is a subcommittee of the court of directors at the Bank of England and has powers and
responsibilities in relation to systemic risk within the financial services sector, responding to sectoral
issues that could threaten UK economic and financial stability. The FPC has powers to give directions
to the PRA and the FCA.

**_Financial Conduct Authority_**

The FCA regulates the conduct of every authorised firm. Its “operational objectives” are to secure an
appropriate degree of protection for consumers, protect and enhance the integrity of the UK financial
system and promote effective competition in the interests of consumers. The FCA also has a “strategic
objective” of ensuring that relevant markets function well.


-----

**_Financial Services and Markets Act 2000_**

_FCA Rule Making Powers_

The FCA has powers under the FSMA and the FS Act to make rules, which are set out in the FCA
Handbook. These rules are legally binding. The FSMA contains checks and balances in relation to the
exercise of these powers, including the procedures that the regulators must follow in the exercise of
their rule-making powers. The FCA has the statutory power to make general rules applying to firms for
which it is the sole regulator.

_Permission to Carry out Regulated Activities in the United Kingdom_

In order to authorise a person to carry on regulated activities in the United Kingdom, the FCA must
determine that the applicant meets regulatory requirements, including certain “threshold conditions”.
The threshold conditions are the minimum conditions which must be satisfied (both at the time of
authorisation, and on an ongoing basis) in order for a firm to gain and continue to have permission to
carry on the relevant regulated activities under the FSMA. These relate to matters including the
applicant’s legal form, whether the applicant has adequate resources (both financial and non-financial)
to carry on its business and whether, having regard to all the circumstances (including whether the
applicant’s affairs are conducted soundly and prudently), and the applicant is a fit and proper person
to conduct the relevant regulated activities.

Firms are authorised to carry on only those regulated activities for which they been granted permission
under the FSMA and are not permitted to carry on any other regulated activities. Once authorised, in
addition to continuing to meet the threshold conditions, firms must comply with the provisions of the
FSMA, related secondary legislation and the rules made by the FCA under the FSMA. Failure to
continue to meet the threshold conditions may lead to revocation of a firm’s authorisation.

_Supervision and Enforcement_

The nature and extent of the FCA’s supervisory relationship with a firm depends on, among other
considerations, how much of a risk the FCA consider that firm could pose to the achievement of its
statutory objectives.

The FCA has powers to take a range of enforcement actions, including the ability to sanction
UK-authorised firms. In particular, enforcement action may include restrictions on undertaking new
business, public censure, restitution, fines and, ultimately, revocation of permission to carry on
regulated activities. The FCA may also take enforcement action against individuals performing certain
controlled functions in relation to authorised persons.

The FCA has further powers to obtain injunctions against UK-authorised firms where a UK-authorised
firm has breached relevant requirements, including requirements imposed by or under the FSMA or
under certain EU legislation, and to impose or seek restitution orders where clients or other affected
parties have suffered loss, or the firm has obtained a profit as a result of a breach of a relevant
requirement. In certain circumstances, the FCA also has the power to take action against unauthorised
parent undertakings of UK-authorised persons, including by issuing directions to do or refrain from
doing a particular activity.

_Principles for Businesses and Fundamental Rules_

The FCA’s Principles for Businesses (the “Principles”) set out high-level principles that apply to all
authorised persons in the United Kingdom. Amongst other things, the Principles require firms to treat
customers fairly, maintain adequate financial resources and communicate with customers in a way that
is clear, fair and not misleading.

The FCA has also established six key outcomes it expects firms to focus on in order to ensure that they
are treating customers fairly in accordance with the Principles. These include ensuring that consumers
can be confident they are dealing with firms where the fair treatment of customers is central to the


-----

firm’s corporate culture, and that products and services marketed and sold in the retail market are
designed to meet the needs of identified consumer groups and are targeted accordingly.

The emphasis and reliance on these overarching rules and principles by the FCA has marked a move
to more judgment-based regulation in recent years, focusing on the achievement of positive outcomes.

**_Senior Management, Systems and Controls_**

Within the FCA Handbook, the Senior Management, Systems and Controls (“SYSC”) Sourcebook
contains general organisational requirements that apply to a number of different types of
UK-authorised firms, including UK-authorised asset management and investment firms. These
requirements elaborate on Principle 3 of the FCA Principles for Businesses, which requires firms to
take reasonable care to organise and control their affairs responsibly and effectively, with adequate risk
management systems.

Among other things, in broad terms, the SYSC Sourcebook contains rules relating to the persons who
effectively direct the business of a MiFID investment firm, UCITS management company or AIFM. It
requires firms to employ personnel with the skills, knowledge and expertise necessary for the
discharge of the responsibilities allocated to them, requires firms to implement systems and controls
relating to compliance and risk controls and contains requirements relating to outsourcing and
conflicts of interest, amongst other things.

**_Senior Managers and Certification Regime_**

The SMCR came into force in the United Kingdom for nearly all solo-regulated firms in December 2019.
The SMCR, as it applies to such firms, requires firms to allocate responsibility for certain senior
management functions to individuals pre-approved by the FCA (“Senior Managers”). The SMCR also
introduced a certification regime for staff employed in positions where they could pose a significant
risk of harm to their firm or its customers. A new set of conduct rules were also introduced that apply
to Senior Managers, certified employees and almost all other individuals working for firms that are
subject to the SMCR. Additional conduct rules apply to Senior Managers. SMCR requires firms to
assess the fitness and propriety of certified persons on an ongoing basis, and at least once a year.

Solo-regulated firms were required to submit data for a publicly available directory of SMCR individuals
and to carry out their first assessment of the fitness and propriety of certified employees by 31 March
2021. The conduct rules began to apply to staff who are not Senior Managers or certified employees
as at the same date.

**_Conduct of Business Requirements_**

The FCA regulates, through the COBS, the Mortgage and Home Finance: Conduct of Business
Sourcebook (“MCOB”) and the Insurance Conduct of Business Sourcebook (“ICOBS”), the
distribution and sale of certain investment products. COBS applies to various firms in the True Potential
group.

The scope and range of the obligations imposed on an authorised firm under COBS, MCOB and
ICOBS vary according to the scope of the firm’s business and the nature of its clients. By way of
example, the rules in COBS, MCOB and ICOBS require firms to provide clients with information about
the firm, meet certain standards of product disclosure, assess suitability when advising on certain
products, report appropriately to clients and provide certain disclosures, including in relation to client
assets held in custody.

**_Rules Applicable to Distribution_**

Authorised firms that are involved in the manufacture or distribution of retail investment products are
subject to a number of rules and regulations that aim to ensure that firms act in the best interests of
customers and treat customers fairly. For example:


-----

- MiFID II, the UK implementation of which remains part of domestic law in the United Kingdom by
virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 contains a range of investor protection
measures applicable to firms subject to MiFID II, including a prohibition on independent advisers
retaining commission from third parties, product oversight and governance rules and rules on
inducements. See “—Markets in Financial Instruments Directive II” below.

- COBS 6.1A contains rules on adviser charging and remuneration that apply to firms making
personal recommendations to retail clients in relation to retail investment products and certain
other products in the United Kingdom. In particular, a firm must only be remunerated for a
personal recommendation and any other related services by adviser charges, and must not solicit
or accept any other commissions, remuneration or benefit of any kind in connection with the
firm’s business of advising, regardless of whether it intends to refund the payments or pass the
benefits on to the retail client. An appropriate charging structure for calculating the adviser charge
must be used.

- COBS 6.2B contains rules on describing advice services that apply to firms providing investment
advice to retail clients in the United Kingdom in relation to financial instruments, structured
deposits or other retail investment products or basic advice to retail clients in the United Kingdom
(as well as to firms providing investment advice in the course of MiFID business in relation to
financial instruments and structured deposits, since COBS 6.2B also implements aspects of
MiFID II). In particular, firms holding themselves out as providing independent advice must assess
a sufficient and diverse range of relevant products available on the market. A firm must also
disclose to a client whether its advice will be independent advice or restricted advice; whether the
advice will be based on a broad or more restricted analysis of different types of relevant products;
and, where the advice will be restricted advice, whether the range will be limited to relevant
products issued or provided by entities having close links or relationships with the firm.

- The FCA Training and Competence sourcebook requires retail investment advisers to meet
specific requirements, including requirements in respect of continuing professional development,
appropriate qualifications and professional standing.

- The UK PRIIPs Regulation (as defined below), requires manufacturers of packaged retail
investment products and insurance-based investment products to provide a key information
document (“KID”) containing certain pre-contract product disclosures to retail consumers when
they are considering buying a PRIIP.

**_Client Assets_**

Principle 10 of the FCA’s Principles for Businesses requires firms to arrange adequate protection for
assets when the firm is responsible for them. The FCA’s Client Assets Sourcebook (“CASS”)
elaborates on this requirement, setting out the rules that apply to firms that are permitted to hold client
money and assets.

The requirements set out in CASS aim to protect money and assets belonging to a firm’s clients from
the insolvency of that firm and to ensure that, if a firm is subject to insolvency proceedings, client
money and assets can be promptly returned to the client. The rules seek to achieve this by requiring
firms to keep client money and assets separate from their own, by preventing firms from using client
money and assets for their own purposes and by requiring firms to keep records of the client money
and assets that they do hold.

**_Prudential Requirements_**

Regulatory capital requirements form an integral part of the FCA’s prudential supervision of True
Potential’s solo regulated UK-authorised firms. The FCA has detailed rules relating to the maintenance
of minimum levels of regulatory capital for authorised firms, which amplify the general principle under
which a firm must maintain adequate financial resources in order to be able to meet its liabilities as they
fall due. The adequacy of a firm’s financial resources is assessed in relation to the particular risks to


-----

which the firm may be exposed, given its business activities. The FCA also expects firms to take a
proactive approach to monitoring and managing risks.

Regulatory capital requirements exist on two levels. The first is a solo requirement aimed at individual
authorised entities (with the relevant firm being required to submit periodic returns to demonstrate
compliance with the relevant requirement). The second is a consolidated (or group) requirement and
relates to a part of, or the entirety of, the group of which an authorised firm or firms form part. The solo
prudential requirements that apply to FCA-authorised firms depend on the FCA’s prudential
classification of individual firms. This in turn depends on the level of risk involved in performing the
activities the relevant entity is authorised to perform.

The UK CRR, which forms part of domestic law in the UK by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal)
Act, previously applied to all investment firms. The meaning of the term “investment firm” for these
purposes is narrower than the meaning of the same term under MiFID II. The FCA categorised
investment firms for prudential purposes according to services and activities performed. Investment
firms meeting the narrower UK CRR definition were subject to regulatory capital requirements set out
in UK CRR, in the Prudential sourcebook for Investment Firms and GENPRU in the FCA Handbook.
Other MiFID II investment firms that do not meet this definition – in particular Building Societies and
Investment Firms (“BIPRU”), local firms and exempt CAD firms – were instead subject to less stringent
rules set out in the FCA Handbook in the Prudential sourcebook for Banks, BIPRU and GENPRU, or in
the Interim Prudential sourcebook for Investment Businesses, depending on their prudential
categorisation.

As a general matter, most investment firms are required to hold a sum of initial capital and additional
amounts against operating risk and (if relevant) interest rate, market and counterparty risks. A firm’s
capital requirements may increase, which may affect return on capital for investors. As at 1 January
2022, the IFPR (including the Prudential sourcebook for MiFID investment firms) has replaced the UK
CRR regime as regards capital requirements for UK investment firms other than PRA-designated
investment firms. The IFPR regime set out a new methodology for the calculation of capital
requirements, based on “K-factors”, which are applied to a firm depending on the nature of the
activities it undertakes and the permissions that it holds; specifically, the IFPR sets out “risk to
customer” K-factors that are potentially applicable to all firms, based on AUM, client money held,
assets safeguarded and administered, and client orders handled (i.e. orders received/transmitted or
executed for clients); additional K-factors apply where a firm holds permission to deal as principal,
relating to “risk to market” and “risk to firm” categories. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to
_Regulation—Compliance with the Investment Firms Prudential Regime may involve costs and could_
_result in burdens on our business, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial_
_condition, results of operations and prospects”._

**_Data Protection_**

Firms that handle personal data and therefore classify as a “controller” or “processor” must comply
with the requirements established by the UK GDPR and Data Protection Act 2018 in relation to
processing the personal data of our customers. When GDPR became applicable in all Member States
from 25 May 2018, it made substantial changes to the EU data protection regime. The GDPR set a
higher standard for personal data protection. The Information Commissioner’s Office (“ICO”) is an
independent authority responsible for maintaining, upholding and promoting the best business
practices and legislative requirements for processing personal data and safeguarding the information
rights of individuals and their rights to access their personal data. Any business processing personal
data must pay a data protection fee to the ICO, unless it is exempt. True Potential maintains and
processes significant amounts of personal data; therefore, it therefore maintains a data protection
policy and has established data protection processes to comply with the requirements of the UK GDPR
and the Data Protection Act 2018 and the applicable guidance issued from time to time by the ICO,
such as the handling of data subject access requests from individuals. The ICO is empowered to
impose requirements or stop orders, issue monetary fines and prosecute criminal offences under the
Data Protection Act 2018.


-----

As a controller, True Potential are subject to requirements under the UK GDPR. Obligations are placed
on both controllers and entities that process data on behalf of controllers (“processors”). True Potential
is subject to the UK GDPR both as “controllers” and “processors”. True Potential must comply with and
demonstrate compliance with a set of data protection principles under the UK GDPR. The principles
include, among others, obligations to process data lawfully, fairly and transparently, to collect data for
specified, explicit and legitimate purposes, to collect the least amount of data required to fulfil the
relevant purpose, to keep accurate and up to date data, to keep data in a form which permits the
identification of data subjects for no longer than necessary and to process data in a secure manner.
Firms also need to ensure that they comply with other requirements of the UK GDPR, which include,
among other things, changes to the rules on how consent is provided by data subjects for processing
their data, providing information notices to data subjects about how their data is processed, and
impact assessments on our data protection systems and policies, and an obligation to notify data
breaches. Under UK GDPR, the maximum fine that can be imposed as a penalty for a breach of its
terms is the greater of 4% of total worldwide annual turnover or £17.5 million. In addition, regulators
are currently particularly focused on data security and protection of personal data from systems failure
or cyber-crime.

**_Consumer Complaints and Compensation_**

_Financial Ombudsman Service_

UK-authorised firms fall under the compulsory jurisdiction of the FOS, which is a body established
under the FSMA. Authorised firms are required to have adequate complaints handling procedures in
place but, where these are exhausted and the complaint or dispute has not been resolved, the FOS
provides for dispute resolution in respect of certain categories of customer complaints brought by
individuals and small business customers. Firms covered by the FOS are required to pay levies and
case fees, which provides the funding for the FOS.

_Financial Services Compensation Scheme_

The FSCS, established under the FSMA, seeks to protect customers of UK-authorised firms that are
unable or unlikely to be able to meet their financial obligations to customers. The FSCS provides
compensation to certain categories of customer who suffer loss as a consequence of the failure by a
regulated firm to meet its liabilities arising from claims made in connection with regulated activities. The
FSCS is funded by way of levies imposed on all of its participating financial services firms.

**_On-shored EU Regulation_**

_Markets in Financial Instruments Directive II_

MiFID II (the UK implementation of which remains part of domestic law in the United Kingdom by virtue
of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018) and MiFIR (which applied from the same date and forms
part of domestic law in the United Kingdom (as “UK MiFIR”) by virtue of the European Union
(Withdrawal) Act 2018) set out the framework for the regulation of firms in the United Kingdom that
engage in certain investment activities, such as (in certain circumstances) investment advice and
portfolio management. The UK implementation of MiFID II and UK MiFIR, which are intended to make
financial markets more efficient and resilient, increases transparency of both equity and non-equity
markets, reinforces supervisory powers, and strengthens investor protection, set out detailed and
specific requirements relating to investment firms within their scope, including provisions relating to
systems and controls, outsourcing, customer classification, conduct of business, costs and charges
disclosure, product governance, conflicts of interest, best execution, client order handling, suitability
and appropriateness, transparency and transaction reporting.

UK MiFID II and UK MiFIR contain requirements relating to transaction reporting, costs and charges
disclosure, product governance and conduct of business that affect True Potential’s operations. True
Potential has identified the impacts of MiFID II and has implemented changes to systems and business
practices. In the United Kingdom, aspects of MiFID II were also extended to firms not otherwise


-----

governed by MiFID, such as AIFMs and UCITS managers. This includes the ban on soft commission
and detailed telephone taping requirements.

The UK government has established a Wholesale Markets Review, which makes proposals for possible
amendments to aspects of the UK’s implementation of MiFID II. See “—Wholesale Markets Review”
below.

**_Alternative Investment Fund Managers Directive_**

The Alternative Investment Fund Managers Directive (“AIFMD”) (the UK implementation of which
remains part of domestic law in the UK by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018) sets
out the framework for the regulation of the management of certain non-UCITS collective investment
undertakings. The UK implementation of AIFMD applies to AIFMs, that is, to legal persons whose
regular business it is to manage an alternative investment fund (“AIF”) within the meaning of AIFMD.
In broad terms, an AIF is a non-UCITS collective investment undertaking that raises capital from a
number of investors with a view to investing it in accordance with a defined investment policy for the
benefit of those investors.

The UK implementation of AIFMD covers matters such as authorisation, capital requirements, conduct
of business standards, remuneration, the valuation of assets, delegation, depositaries, transparency
and marketing.

**_Undertakings for Collective Investment in Transferable Securities Directive_**

The UCITS Directive (the UK implementation of which remains part of domestic law in the UK by virtue
of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018) sets out the framework for the regulation of UCITS and
UCITS management companies. The UK implementation of the UCITS Directive includes rules on
authorisation, the operation of management companies, depositaries, mergers and investment
policies, and on the information that must be provided to investors. It also requires UCITS management
companies to establish and apply remuneration policies and practices consistent with sound and
effective risk management.

**_PRIIPs Regulation_**

The PRIIPs Regulation applied in EU member states from 1 January 2018, now forms part of domestic
law in the UK (as the “UK PRIIPs Regulation”) by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018.
The UK PRIIPs Regulation requires manufacturers of PRIIPs to provide a KID containing certain precontract product disclosures to retail consumers when they are considering buying a PRIIP. The KID
must provide a comprehensible explanation of the PRIIP, as well as enable retail investors to compare
the KID with other similar investment product KIDs and is intended to enable investors to make more
informed investment choices. This includes, for example, details of future performance scenarios and
the assumptions made to produce them but does not include details of past performance.

PRIIPs include both packaged retail investment products (that is, investment products in relation to
which the amount repayable to the retail investor fluctuates because of exposure to reference values
or to the performance of one or more assets that are not directly purchased by the retail investor) and
insurance-based investment products (that is, insurance products that offer a maturity or surrender
value that is directly or indirectly exposed to market fluctuations). Subject to limited transitional
provisions, this includes products such as units in an investment fund, life insurance policies with an
investment element and structured deposits.

The FCA has consulted on targeted amendments to the UK PRIIPs regime and intends to publish a
policy statement in Q1 2022. See “—Proposed amendments to the UK PRIIPs Regulation” below.

**_Capital Requirements Directive IV and Regulation_**

The CRD IV package (the UK implementation of which remains part of domestic law in the UK by virtue
of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018) sets out the EU framework for the regulation of credit
institutions and certain investment firms, applicable in the main since January 2014, in particular in


-----

respect of capital adequacy. Certain MiFID investment firms and, in particular, those with permissions
relating to the safeguarding of client assets or handling of client money, are subject to the UK
implementation of CRD IV as regards prudential and capital standards.

**_Fourth and Fifth Money Laundering Directives_**

The Fifth Money Laundering Directive (“MLD5”) (the UK implementation of which remains part of
domestic law in the UK by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018) made key amendments
to the Fourth Money Laundering Directive (“MLD4”), including extensions to the scope of the regime
to keep track with evolving technology and clarifications to due diligence requirements for high-risk
countries. MLD5 also provided for greater enforcement powers and new provisions on cooperation
between anti-money laundering authorities to promote enforcement practices.

MLD4 entered into force on 25 June 2015 and was required to be transposed into UK law by 26 June
2017. Key changes introduced by MLD4 include changes to the scope of the anti-money laundering
regime, measures designed to provide enhanced clarity and accessibility with regard to beneficial
owner information, and a tightening of the rules on when simplified due diligence can be used. MLD4
(as amended by MLD5) applies to all of the regulated entities in the True Potential group.

**_Market Abuse Regulation_**

The FCA has the power to impose fines and other civil sanctions on individuals and firms that commit
market abuse. The definition of market abuse is set out in the Market Abuse Regulation, which
repealed and replaced the Market Abuse Directive and its implementing legislation with effect from
3 July 2016 and now forms part of domestic law in the UK (as “UK MAR”) by virtue of the European
Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018. UK MAR refers to three abusive behaviours which, when committed in
relation to publicly traded financial instruments, commodity derivatives or emission allowances,
constitute market abuse. The relevant behaviours are insider dealing, the unlawful disclosure of inside
information and market manipulation.

The FCA may impose an unlimited fine on any person that engages in market abuse, or who has
encouraged or required another person to do so. As an alternative to imposing a fine, the FCA may
publish a statement of public censure or apply to the court under the FSMA for an injunction or
restitution order. The FCA also has the power to impose other administrative sanctions, including the
power to enter premises under a warrant and the power to cancel or suspend trading in financial
instruments.

In addition to the civil regime under the FSMA and MAR, the FCA has the power to prosecute the
criminal offences of insider dealing under the Criminal Justice Act 1993 and the criminal offences of
making false or misleading statements and creating a false or misleading impression in relation to
specified benchmarks under the FS Act.

One of the Principles requires a firm at all times to observe proper standards of market conduct. See
“—Principles for Businesses and Fundamental Rules” above.

**_Insurance Distribution Directive_**

IDD came into force on 22 February 2016 and was required to be implemented by 23 February 2018.
The UK’s implementation of IDD remains part of domestic law in the United Kingdom by virtue of the
European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018. The UK’s implementation of IDD provides for the authorisation
of insurance and reinsurance intermediaries on the basis of minimum professional and financial
requirements and imposes requirements on insurance intermediaries to provide specified minimum
information to potential customers. It also contains organisational and conduct of business rules
applicable to insurance and reinsurance undertakings.

IDD amended and replaced the Insurance Mediation Directive. The IDD significantly raises the
minimum standards set out in the Insurance Mediation Directive and is intended to strengthen
policyholder protection and make it easier for firms to provide services cross-border.


-----

**_European Market Infrastructure Regulation_**

The European Market Infrastructure Regulation (“EMIR”) (which came into force on 16 August 2012
and now forms part of domestic law in the UK (as “UK EMIR”) by virtue of the European Union
(Withdrawal) Act 2018) introduced a number of requirements for counterparties to derivative
transactions, including (i) the mandatory obligation to clear certain classes of over-the-counter (“OTC”)
derivative contracts via a central counterparty (“CCP”); (ii) risk mitigation requirements relating to
uncleared OTC derivative contracts including collateral exchange and daily valuation; and (iii) reporting
and recordkeeping obligations for all derivatives contracts. The application of UK EMIR requirements
to a derivatives counterparty pairing will depend on the classification of the counterparties to such
derivative transactions. The initial margin compliance date for the most systemically important
counterparties was 4 February 2017, with the compliance date for other in-scope counterparties being
phased in from 1 September 2017 to 1 September 2022 (following amendments to incorporate a final
implementation phase and amendments to delay implementation following the COVID-19 pandemic).
The phase-in of clearing requirements for certain interest rate swaps and index credit default swaps
has taken place. There have since been packages of amendments to EMIR and UK EMIR, in particular
“EMIR Refit”, which made amendments including reclassifying certain counterparties, and “EMIR 2.2”,
which made amendments including in relation to the authorisation and supervision of third country
CCPs.

**_Securities Financing Transactions Regulation_**

The Securities Financing Transactions Regulation (“SFTR”), which entered into force on 12 January
2016 and now forms part of domestic law in the United Kingdom (as “UK SFTR”) by virtue of the
European Union (Withdrawal) Act, imposes a number of requirements on the parties to securities
financing transactions (“SFTs”) and other market participants including (i) reporting and
record-keeping requirements for certain counterparties to SFTs; (ii) limitations on the reuse of collateral
(not only in the securities financing markets but also in the wider collateral markets); and (iii) new
investor disclosure rules for management companies of UCITS, UCITS investment companies and
AIFMs.

In broad terms, the UK SFTR requires the conclusion, modification or termination of an SFT to be
reported to a trade repository which is registered or recognised in accordance with the SFTR.
Counterparties are also required to keep a record of any SFT that they have concluded, modified or
terminated for at least five years following the termination of a relevant transaction. An SFT is defined
as (i) a repurchase transaction; (ii) securities or commodities lending and securities or commodities
borrowing; (iii) a buy-sell back transaction or sell-buy back transaction; and (iv) a margin lending
transaction, each as further defined in the UK SFTR.

A right of reuse of financial instruments received as collateral is subject to at least both of the following
conditions: (i) risks and consequences have been communicated in writing; and (ii) prior express
consent of the providing counterparty has been granted. In addition, the exercise of a right of reuse is
subject to meeting at least both of the following conditions: (i) reuse is undertaken in accordance with
the terms specified in the relevant collateral arrangement; and (ii) financial instruments are transferred
from the account of the providing counterparty.

UK SFTR imposes investor disclosure rules for management companies of UCITS, UCITS investment
companies and AIFMs in respect of the use they make of SFTs and total return swaps in periodical
reports and in precontractual documents.

**Recent and Future Regulatory Developments**

**_Brexit_**

Following a referendum vote on 23 June 2016, the United Kingdom exercised Article 50 of the Treaty
on the European Union, which gives a member state the right to withdraw from the European Union,
and gave the European Union a formal notice that it will leave the European Union. The United
Kingdom left the European Union on 31 January 2020 at 11 p.m. local time. At that time, the EU treaties


-----

ceased to apply to the United Kingdom. As part of the withdrawal agreement agreed between the
United Kingdom and the European Union, a transitional period was agreed which extended the
application of EU law and provided for continuing membership of the EU single market until
31 December 2020.

Following 31 December 2020, the transitional period expired, and EU law ceased to apply in the United
Kingdom. On 24 December 2020, the European Union and the United Kingdom agreed on the Trade
and Cooperation Agreement, which sets out the principles of the relationship between the European
Union and the United Kingdom following the end of the transitional period. The Trade and Cooperation
Agreement took effect provisionally from 1 January 2021 pending formal ratification from the European
Union and the United Kingdom. The UK Parliament ratified the Trade and Cooperation Agreement on
30 December 2020 and the European Parliament on behalf of the European Union ratified it on 28 April
2021. The Trade and Cooperation Agreement does not replace the withdrawal agreement.

Explicit agreement on future access in the financial services sector was not included in the Trade and
Co-operation Agreement, and so the future framework between the European Union and United
Kingdom in this space is not currently certain. Future regulatory divergence and further legal
uncertainty are possible. The United Kingdom’s exit from the European Union is likely to significantly
affect the political, fiscal, legal and regulatory landscape in the United Kingdom and could have a
material impact on its economy and the future growth of its various industries. The impact on the UK
economy could reduce, amongst other things: its share of world exports compared with the United
States, and the number of the world’s top 100 multi-national companies headquartered in the United
Kingdom. Although it is not possible to predict fully the effects of the United Kingdom’s exit from the
European Union, it could have a material adverse effect on, amongst other things, UK fund managers,
companies and investors, and could therefore have a material adverse effect on the business of True
Potential.

**_Wholesale Markets Review_**

In July 2021, HM Treasury published a consultation on the Wholesale Markets Review, which was
established to examine the need for the United Kingdom to adapt its regulation of wholesale markets
following its departure from the European Union.

Proposals under consideration as part of the Review include the removal of the share trading
obligation, a reduction in the scope of the position limits regime, amendments to the scope of the
derivatives trading obligation, clarifications and revisions to the scope of the pre- and post-trade
transparency regimes and amendments to the tick size regime.

The consultation on the Wholesale Markets Review closed in September 2021 and HM Treasury will
respond in due course, with FCA consultations to follow in the first and second quarter of 2022. HM
Treasury will consider responses to the consultation in parallel with the Future Regulatory Framework
Review, which has been established to examine the need for the United Kingdom to adapt its financial
regulatory framework generally following its departure from the European Union.

**_Review of the UK Funds Regime_**

In January 2021, HM Treasury published a call for input relating to its review of the UK funds regime.
The review covers (in addition to fund taxation issues) the UK’s approach to funds regulation and
opportunities for wider reform on issues cutting across tax and regulatory issues relevant to the UK
fund regime. As regards the UK’s approach to fund regulation, the call for input requests stakeholder
input on issues including the benefits of fund authorisation, timescales for fund authorisation, the
qualified investor scheme fund structure and operational efficiency. In the context of wider input, the
call for input requests input in particular on enhancing the attractiveness of the UK funds regime and
whether it should focus on appealing to AIFs targeting international markets, spreading the benefits of
fund administration across the UK, enhancing existing fund structures and new fund structures.

The call for input closed in April 2021 and the government intends to consult on specific proposals for
reform once it has analysed responses to the call for input.


-----

**_Proposed Amendments to the UK PRIIPs Regulation_**

In July 2021, the FCA published a consultation paper consulting on targeted amendments to address
concerns relating to the UK PRIIPs disclosure regime. In particular, the consultation proposes
amendments that seek to clarify the scope of the UK PRIIPs Regulation to address concerns about
uncertainty relating to the application of the regime to corporate bonds, in particular those which have
features such as make-whole clauses and change of control puts. The consultation also proposes to
replace the requirement for the presentation of performance scenarios in a KID with a requirement
to include a narrative description of performance, to address misleading summary risk indicators and
to address concerns with the calculation methodology for transaction costs. The consultation closed
in September 2021 and the FCA intends to publish a policy statement in Q1 2022.

**_Consultation on the Regulation of Non-transferable Debt Securities (Mini-bonds)_**

In April 2021, HM Treasury published a consultation pertaining to the regulation of illiquid nontransferable debt securities often referred to as “mini-bonds”. The consultation examines the case for
further regulation of direct-to-market issuance of mini-bonds and proposes two policy options, the first
of which is making the issuance of mini-bonds a regulated activity under the FSMA and the second of
which is extending the scope of the UK Prospectus Regulation to cover public offers of mini-bonds.
The consultation closed in July 2021.

**_Sustainable Finance Legislation_**

Regulation (EU) 2019/2088 on sustainability-related disclosures in the financial services sector
(“SFDR”) entered into force on 29 December 2019. Most of its provisions have applied in the European
Union since 10 March 2021.

It applies to AIFMs and contains transparency and disclosure requirements, including:

- what firms must disclose and maintain on their websites;

- the information that must be provided to investors; and

- periodic reporting to investors.

The SFDR forms part of a package of reforms relating to sustainable finance (including for example
Regulation (EU) 2019/2089 amending Regulation (EU) 2016/1011 as regards EU climate transition
benchmarks, EU Paris-aligned benchmarks and sustainability-related disclosures for benchmarks (the
“Low Carbon Benchmark Regulation”) and the EU's Regulation on the establishment of a framework
to facilitate sustainable investment (the “Taxonomy Regulation”)).

Following ESMA’s May 2019 final report on technical advice to the European Commission on
integrating sustainability risks and factors in the UCITS Directive and the AIFMD (ESMA34-45-688), the
European Commission adopted a delegated regulation to amend the AIFMD Level 2 Regulation.

Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/1255 of 21 April 2021, amending Delegated Regulation
(EU) No 231/2013 as regards sustainability risks and sustainability factors to be taken into account by
alternative investment fund managers, amends the AIFMD Level 2 Regulation to include the
consideration of sustainability risks in due diligence requirements, to require AIFMs to retain the
necessary resources and expertise for the effective integration of sustainability risks, and to state that
the identification of conflicts of interest must also include those conflicts of interest that may arise as a
result of the integration of sustainability risks. The amendments will also require senior management
of AIFMs to be responsible for the integration of sustainability risks and will require risk management
policies to consider exposures to sustainability risks.

The United Kingdom has not fully onshored these EU sustainable finance reforms. However, similar
themes are emerging in legislative and policy development in the United Kingdom. For example, in
June 2021, the UK government appointed a green technical advisory group, which is tasked with
overseeing the UK government’s development of a UK Green Taxonomy. The United Kingdom will also
have its own sustainability disclosure framework.

**Revolving Credit Facility Agreement**

**_Overview and Structure_**

On the Completion Date, the Issuer as company (the “Company”) and original guarantor (the
“Guarantor”), Credit Suisse International, Goldman Sachs International, UBS AG, London Branch,
Barclays Bank PLC, Lloyds Bank Corporate Markets plc, The Royal Bank of Scotland International
Limited, London Branch and SMBC Bank International PLC as mandated lead arrangers (together, the
